Question: An insulation resistance reading is taken at 20C and found to be 10 megohms. What would you expect the resistance reading to be at 40C?

An insulation resistance test is performed on a particular piece of electric equipment. In addition to the resistance reading and date of test what information listed below should be entered in the electrical log?
Response 1: The maximum allowable operating temperature of the machine.
Response 2: The temperature of the machine at the time the resistance reading was taken.
Response 3: The normal temperature rise of the machine.
Response 4: The complete nameplate data from the resistance test instrument used to obtain the reading.

Question: The electrician reports to you that he has obtained low (but above 1 megohm) megger readings on the windings of a deck winch motor. Upon checking the records of that motor you find the readings have consistently been at that level for the last six years. What should be your recommendation?
Which of the listed conditions could indicate the need for cleaning electrical insulation?
Electrical failures in motors are caused by the breakdown of insulation which is a function of the aging process. What is another contributing factor to insulation breakdown?
Response 1: habitually running of a motor at low loads
Response 2: chronic overheating of a motor regardless of reason
Response 3: failure to run a continuous duty motor on a continuous basis
Response 4: habitual operation of a motor at low ambient temperatures

Question: Which of the conditions listed will indicate the need to clean the insulation on the windings of an electric motor?
When using the test set-up shown in figure "A" of the illustration besides the motor windings and the motor feeder cable what circuit components are actually being meggered? See illustration EL-0027.
Response 1: the entire starter including the power and control circuits up to the load side of the disconnect switch
Response 2: the power circuit of the starter up to the load side of the disconnect switch
Response 3: the power circuit of the starter up to the load side of the main contacts
Response 4: The power circuit of the starter up to the load side of the overload relay heaters

Question: In conducting a megger test as shown in figure "A" of the illustration a ground is detected. For testing purposes how can the motor itself be eliminated or confirmed as the source of the ground? See illustration EL-0027.
Response 1: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at the motor and perform the megger test again at the disconnected motor feeder cable leads.
Response 2: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at the motor starter and perform the megger test again at the disconnected motor feeder cable leads.
Response 3: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at both ends and perform the megger test again at either end of the motor feeder cable leads.
Response 4: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads from the motor itself and perform the megger test again as shown in figure "B".

Question: In conducting a megger test as shown in figure "A" of the illustration a ground is detected. For testing purposes how can the motor feeder cable itself be eliminated or confirmed as the source of the ground? See illustration EL-0027.
Response 1: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at the motor and perform the megger test again at the disconnected motor feeder cable leads.
Response 2: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at the motor starter and perform the megger test again at the disconnected motor feeder cable leads.
Response 3: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads at both ends and perform the megger test again at either end of the motor feeder cable leads.
Response 4: Disconnect the motor feeder cable leads from the starter and perform the megger test again at the T1 T2 and T3 terminals of the motor starter. .

Question: When insulation failure produces a low resistance current path between two conductors the result is an electrical fault. What is this fault condition known as?
On tank vessels with an electrically-driven capstan the motor should be meggered periodically. What is being tested for when meggering?

A generator has been exposed to water and needs to be checked before it can be operated safely. After performing the necessary procedures for drying the generator what test needs to be performed before safe operation can resume?
Response 1: check for shorted coils with a growler
Response 2: take moisture readings with a hydrometer
Response 3: test insulation values with a megger
Response 4: ground the commutator or slip rings and run it at half load for 12 hours

Question: To perform an insulation resistance test of an individual electric motor winding where should the megohmmeter leads be connected?
Response 1: to opposite ends of the winding
Response 2: the input line lead and to one end of the winding
Response 3: one end of the winding and to the frame of the machine
Response 4: the armature brush pigtail and to the input line lead

Question: Large machines undergoing a resistance insulation testing using a megohmmeter should be discharged to remove any accumulated electrostatic/capacitive charge stored. When should this discharge be performed?
Response 1: prior to conducting the insulation resistance check only
Response 2: while performing the insulation resistance check only
Response 3: after conducting the insulation resistance check only
Response 4: prior to and after conducting the insulation resistance check

Question: When a megohmmeter is being used to test insulation resistance current leakage along the surface of the insulation is indicated by a very specific megohmmeter pointer movement. What would be the characteristic of the pointer movement under these conditions?
Response 1: fluctuating around a constant resistance reading
Response 3: kicking slightly downscale as voltage is applied
Response 4: continually rising as the test voltage is applied

Question: When using a megohmmeter to test the dielectric strength of wire insulation a continuous series of slight downscale kicks by the pointer results. What does this indicate?
Response 2: the leakage of current along the surface of dirty insulation
Response 4: the dielectric-absorption effect of the insulation

Question: When a megohmmeter is being used to test insulation resistance current leakage along the surface of the insulation is indicated by the megohmmeter's pointer responding in a very unique way. What would be the response of the pointer?
Response 1: dipping toward zero then raising slowly
Response 2: continually rising as test voltage is applied
Response 3: kicking slightly down scale as voltage is applied
Response 4: fluctuating around a constant resistance reading

Question: When a megohmmeter is used to test the insulation of a large motor what causes the initial dip of the pointer toward 'zero'?
Response 3: the leakage of the current along the surface of dirty insulation
Response 4: the dielectric-absorption effect of the insulation

Question: When a megohmmeter is used to test the dielectric strength of wire insulation what causes the initial dip of the pointer toward 'zero'?
Response 2: the leakage of current along the surface of dirty insulation
Response 4: the dielectric absorption effect of the insulation

Question: When a megohmmeter is being used on a alternating current machine under certain conditions the meter pointer will dip toward 'zero' and then gradually rise to the true resistance value of the motor insulation. What does this indicate in terms of the machine windings?
When a megohmmeter is used to test the winding insulation of a large motor what causes an initial dip of the pointer toward 'zero'?
Response 1: an open in the winding being tested
Response 3: the absence of current along the surface of clean insulation

Question: When a megohmmeter is used to test insulation what condition causes the gradual rise of the pointer reading as a result of continued cranking?
Response 2: the leakage of current along the surface of dirty insulation
Response 3: the inductive reactance of the windings
Response 4: the dielectric-absorption effect of the insulation

Question: When using a megohmmeter to test insulation what will be the indication of good insulation?
Response 1: slight kicks of the needle down scale
Response 2: a downward dip followed by a gradual climb to the true resistance value
Response 3: a gradual rise in the pointer reading at the outset
Response 4: the initial dip of the pointer

Question: You are testing the insulation in an AC generator with a megohmeter. What would be the indication of a resistance value associated with a dry clean winding?
Response 1: the resistance will continue to rise as the test potential is maintained becoming fairly steady as the leakage current stabilizes
Response 2: the resistance will remain constant as the temperature of the windings increases
Response 3: the resistance will continue to drop as the potential is maintained becoming fairly steady after 5 to 7 minutes
Response 4: the resistance will stabilize after approximately 2 to 4 minutes of fluctuation

Question: A megger is being used to test the insulation of an AC generator. What will be the measured resistance value of a dry clean winding?
Response 1: continue to rise as test potential is maintained becoming fairly steady as the dielectric-absorption effect of insulation stabilizes
Response 2: remain constant as the temperature of the windings increases
Response 3: continue to drop as test potential is maintained becoming fairly steady after 5-7 minutes
Response 4: stabilize after approximately 2-4 minutes of fluctuation

Question: In which of the situations listed will a megohmmeter give the most accurate readings?
Response 1: While the machine is in operation.
Response 2: While the machine is discharging static electricity.
Response 3: Immediately prior to restarting the machine.
Response 4: When the machine has been shut down and grounded for a period of 15 minutes.

Question: Before testing insulation with a megohmmeter the windings of large machines should be grounded for about 15 minutes just prior to the test. Why is this recommended?
Response 1: static charge of the machine may give a false reading
Response 2: armature will have a greater number of leakage paths
Response 4: insulation may be covered with moisture

Question: Before testing insulation with a megohmmeter the windings of large machines should be grounded for about 15 minutes just prior to the test. Why is this procedure recommended?
Response 2: insulation may be covered with moisture
Response 3: armature windings will have a greater number of leakage paths
Response 4: larger machines may acquire a charge of static electricity during operation

Question: In preparing to take insulation resistance readings on a main generator the windings should be grounded for about 15 minutes prior to the test. For what reason should this be done?
Response 1: allow accurate zeroing of the meter
Response 2: help the windings to cool to ambient temperature
Response 3: release any residual capacitive charge from the windings
Response 4: help the windings to cool to the same temperature as the ground test connection

A megohmmeter is connected to opposite ends of an individual motor winding. What would a low ohm reading indicate?

Response 1: immediately after shutting down the machine

Question: Which of the following statements represents the reading display of a hand-cranked megohmmeter when testing a capacitor start motor start capacitor in good condition that has been properly discharged prior to the test?
Response 1: The needle should immediately deflect to infinity and remain there while cranking
Response 2: The needle should immediately deflect to a very low resistance value and then gradually increase to infinity while cranking.

Response 4: The needle should immediately deflect to a very low resistance value and remain there while cranking.

Question: As shown in the illustrated plots of uncorrected and temperature corrected insulation resistance readings for a particular piece of equipment at what point in time should the equipment have been refurbished or replaced? See illustration EL-0120.

Question: In performing the insulation resistance tests as indicated by figures "1" and "2" what conclusion may be drawn? See illustration EL-0130.
Response 1: Circuit #1 is grounded at phase "a" and circuit #6 is grounded at phase "c".
Response 2: Circuit #1 is grounded at phase "a" and circuit #6 is clear of grounds at phase "c".
Response 3: Circuit #1 is clear of grounds at phase "a" and circuit #6 is grounded at phase "c".
Response 4: Circuit #1 is clear of grounds at phase "a" and circuit #6 is clear of grounds at phase "c".

Question: In performing the insulation resistance tests as indicated by figures "3" and "4" what conclusion may be drawn? See illustration EL-0130.
Response 1: Circuit #1 is grounded somewhere along the conducting path of conductors "u" "v" and "w".
Response 2: Circuit #1 is grounded somewhere along the conducting path of conductors "x" "y" and "z".
Response 3: Circuit #1 is grounded along the conducting path of conductor "u" while the conducting path of conductors "v" and "w" are clear of grounds.

Question: In performing the insulation resistance tests as indicated by figures "5" and "6" what conclusion may be drawn? See illustration EL-0130.
Response 1: Circuit #1 is grounded somewhere along the conducting path of conductors "v" and "w".
Response 2: Circuit #1 is clear of grounds along the conducting path of conductors "v" and "w".
Response 3: Circuit #1 is grounded along the conducting path of conductor "v" while the conducting path of conductor "w" is clear of grounds.
Response 4: Circuit #1 is clear of grounds along the conducting path of conductor "v" while the conducting path of conductor "w" is grounded.

Question: In testing a hand cranked megger prior to use what statement is true?
Response 1: With the test leads shorted the pointer should go to infinite ohms and with the tests leads open the pointer should go to zero ohms.
Response 2: With the test leads shorted the pointer should go to zero ohms and with the tests leads open the pointer should go to infinite ohms.
Response 3: With the test leads shorted or open the pointer should go to infinite ohms.
Response 4: With the test leads shorted or open the pointer should go to zero ohms.

Response 1: lower switchboard wattmeter reading than normal
Response 2: reading of 1.0 on the power factor meter

Question: Using the temperature correction factor for the winding insulation temperature graph illustrated what would be the correction factor and the corrected temperature to 40C for a motor with a insulation resistance of 4 megohms measured at 50C? See illustration EL-0046.

Response 3: The temperature correction factor is 0.25 and the corrected resistance is 2 megohms at 40C.
Response 4: The temperature correction factor is 0.25 and the corrected resistance is 32 megohms at 40C.

Question: Using the temperature correction factor for the winding insulation temperature graph illustrated what would be the correction factor and the corrected temperature to 40C for a motor with a insulation resistance of 4 megohms measured at 30C? See illustration EL-0046.
Response 1: The temperature correction factor is 2 and the corrected resistance is 8 megohms at 40C.
Response 2: The temperature correction factor is 2 and the corrected resistance is 2 megohms at 40C.
Response 3: The temperature correction factor is 0.5 and the corrected resistance is 8 megohms at 40C.
Response 4: The temperature correction factor is 0.5 and the corrected resistance is 2 megohms at 40C.

Question: Using the temperature correction factor for the winding insulation temperature graph illustrated what would be the correction factor and the corrected temperature to 40C for a motor with a insulation resistance of 8 megohms measured at 60C? See illustration EL-0046.

Response 2: The temperature correction factor is 4 and the corrected resistance is 32 megohms at 40C.

Response 4: The temperature correction factor is 0.25 and the corrected resistance is 32 megohms at 40C.

Question: Which of the following is the only known perfect dielectric for the purpose of serving as electrical insulation?
What is "the voltage per millimeter of insulation thickness that the insulation can withstand without breaking down" called?
What happens to the life expectancy of insulation for each 10 C rise in operating temperature?
Suppose it is desired to determine the integrity of the insulation of a 4160 VAC motor. What type of insulation resistance tester (megger) would be suitable?
For a motor rated at 3.3 kV what would be a minimum accepted insulation resistance to hull ground as tested by an appropriate megger (insulation tester)?

You direct the electrician to take quarterly insulation resistance reading of the ship's critical motors. What additional directions would you give to ensure accurate readings are taken that will allow for the logical comparison of prior and current readings?
Response 1: Use a different megohmmeter from previous tests.
Response 2: While using a hand crank megohmmeter take a reading after 30 seconds of cranking the handle.
Response 3: Correct the readings to a reference temperature; reference temperature should be recorded in prior readings history.
Response 4: While using a hand crank megohmmeter take a reading after 3 minutes of cranking the handle.

Question: The electrical officer is about to check the insulation resistance. When advice should you give to him as to what temperature and or when he should check the motor insulation?
Response 1: Allow the motor to cool down and check insulation.
Response 2: Testing should be done at or near the motor temperature as the insulation becomes leaky at high temperatures. .
Response 3: Check the insulation when the motor is live.
Response 4: Insulation resistance need not be tested.

Question: Suppose it is desired to determine the integrity of the insulation of a 4160 VAC motor. What type of insulation resistance tester (megger) would be suitable?
For a motor rated at 3.3 kV what would be a minimum accepted insulation resistance to hull ground as tested by an appropriate megger (insulation tester)?
When an high voltage system insulation test value is suspect or recorded during an annual survey a polarization index test is performed. What is the polarization index?
Response 1: The polarization index is the ratio of the insulation resistance taken at one minute to the insulation resistance taken at ten minutes.
Response 2: The polarization index is the ratio of the insulation resistance taken at thirty minutes to the insulation resistance taken at one minute.
Response 3: The polarization index is the ratio of the insulation resistance taken at ten minutes to the insulation resistance taken at one minute.
Response 4: The polarization index is the insulation resistance taken at ten minutes.

Question: As shown in the illustration which of the following statements is correct concerning the circuits in a sound powered telephone system? See illustration EL-0093.
Response 1: Both the talking and ringing circuits are common circuits.
Response 2: The talking circuit is a common circuit and the ringing circuit is a selective circuit.
Response 3: Both the talking and ringing circuits are selective circuits.
Response 4: The talking circuit is a selective circuit and the ringing circuit is a common circuit.

Question: In the system shown in the illustration the engine room station is unable to signal any other station nor is any other station able to signal the engine room station. The engine room station can however ring itself by proper positioning of its selector switch. What is the most probable cause of this problem? See illustration EL-0093.
Response 1: The selector switch is grounded at the problem station diverting current from the other stations' ringing devices.
Response 2: There is an open between terminal "C" of the problem station and the common wire of the multi-conductor cable to the other stations.
Response 3: The coil of component "C" of the problem station is open circuited.
Response 4: The switch at component "A" of the problem station is stuck open.

Referring to the sound-powered telephone circuit shown in illustration what statement is true concerning the button on the handset as represented by the component labeled "A"? See illustration EL-0093.
Response 1: The push-button is depressed for the purposes of listening and talking.
Response 2: The push-button is depressed only for the purposes of listening and it should be released for talking.

A shown in the illustration which of the lighting fixtures represents an incandescent bulb? See illustration EL-0122.
A shown in the illustration which lighting fixture represents a low pressure sodium lamp? See illustration EL-0122.

Question: When a fluorescent lamp fails to light and both ends of the tube are severely darkened what must usually be replaced?

Response 1: The unit is in danger of exploding.

Question: During the start-up of the circuit shown in figure "B" of the illustration it is noted that the ends of component "4" remain lighted but the tube does not illuminate. What is likely the cause of this problem? See illustration EL-0081.

During start-up of the circuit shown in figure "B" of the illustration it is noted that the ends of component "4" alternately glow and become dark without the tube illuminating. What is the most probable cause for this condition? See illustration EL-0081.

Question: What type of circuit is represented by the diagram shown in the illustration? See illustration EL-0058.

Question: As shown in the illustration what maintenance would be required of the circuit components? See illustration EL-0058.

Question: As shown in the illustration of a vessels navigational lighting circuit if port running light "1" burns out the trouble buzzer will sound and the port running light trouble lamp will illuminate. Switching to port running light "2" clears the alarm. Response 1: The new lower wattage light at port running light "1" will immediately burn out.
Response 2: The trouble relay coil will overheat.
Response 3: The trouble buzzer may not have sufficient voltage to provide sound.

Question: As shown in the illustration if one of the navigation running light bulbs on service burns out the operator will receive an alarm. After renewing the burned out light bulb and restoring service to that running light bulb it is found that the alarm still cannot be silenced. What is the probable cause for this condition in terms of the replacement component? See illustration EL-0058.
Response 1: it burned out rapidly due to its higher voltage rating
Response 2: it burned out rapidly due to its higher wattage rating
Response 3: it caused component 'F' to burn out
Response 4: it is of a lower wattage rating than required for the alarm relay circuit to activate due to insufficient current flow

Question: As shown in the wiring diagram of the semi-automatic navigation lighting panel circuit what would cause the buzzer to sound and for the indicator light to illuminate in the line section for a particular navigation running light? See illustration EL-0108.
Response 1: a blown 10 amp fuse in master section
Response 4: a blown 3 amp fuse in effected line section

Question: As shown in the wiring diagram of the semi-automatic navigation lighting panel circuit what would cause the buzzer to sound and for the indicator light to illuminate in the line section for a particular navigation running light? See illustration EL-0108.
Response 1: a blown 10 amp fuse in master section

Question: What type of circuit is represented by the diagram shown in the illustration? See illustration EL-0058.
As shown in the illustration the change-over switch is what type of device? See illustration EL-0058.
As shown in the illustration the change-over switch is what type of device? See illustration EL-0058.
What type of circuit is represented by the diagram shown in the illustration? See illustration EL-0058.
As shown in the illustrated alternator protection scheme diagram what function does the negative phase sequence relay (NPS) perform? See illustration EL-0067.
Response 1: trips the alternator circuit breaker due to extremely high over current caused by a short-circuit fault
Response 2: trips the alternator circuit breaker due to sustained motor overload current where the trip delay is directly proportional to the overload current
Response 3: trips the alternator circuit breaker due to sustained motor overload current where the trip delay is inversely proportional to the overload current
Response 4: trips the alternator circuit breaker in the event of unbalanced stator currents

Question: In the illustrated switchboard if one of the devices labeled 'Turbine' should fail due to a throttle trip what will happen? See illustration EL-0003.
Response 1: device labeled 'Exciter' will drive the alternator
Response 2: device labeled 'Circuit Breaker' for that alternator should automatically open because of the reverse power relay
Response 3: operator must open all the devices labeled 'Circuit Breakers' to reduce the load on the remaining turbo-alternator
Response 4: emergency generator should automatically start and be placed on line to supply emergency load centers

Question: What is the purpose of the device labeled 'Man-Auto Sw.' in the illustrated switchboard? See illustration EL-0003.
Response 1: shift from the automatic voltage regulator to manual voltage control or vice versa
Response 2: shift the governor control from manual to automatic/zero droop or vice versa
Response 3: enable the operator to read the field voltage on device 'Volt.Reg.Adj.Pot.' or device 'Man.Volt.Adj.Rheo'
Response 4: supply regulated control power to the switchboard

Question: In the illustrated switchboard what is the function of the device labeled "Gen.Bkr.Sw."? See illustration EL-0003.

Question: In the illustration of the one line distribution system diagram if the ship's service generator on line fails what statement is true concerning the operation of the emergency diesel generator? See illustration EL-0014.

Question: Referring to the containership one -line distribution diagram shown in the illustration what is the purpose of the transformers providing power to the refrigerated container feeder bus? See illustration EL-0014.

Question: Referring to the containership one-line distribution diagram shown in the illustration what is the purpose of the feedback circuit breaker as used to bypass the automatic bus transfer device? See illustration EL-0014.

Question: In using a portable growler for the purpose of locating a shorted stator coil in an AC motor as shown in the illustration what statement is true as the feeler is moved from slot to slot around the stator? See illustration EL-0200.
Response 1: The feeler will vibrate in synchronism with the 60 Hz AC power source and produce a growling noise when the feeler is moved over a slot containing a shorted coil.
Response 2: The feeler will vibrate in synchronism with the 60 Hz AC power source and produce a growling noise when the feeler is moved over a slot which does NOT contain a shorted coil.
Response 3: The feeler will remain motionless with NO vibration or noise when the feeler is moved over a slot containing a shorted coil.
Response 4: The feeler will vibrate in synchronism with the 60 Hz AC power source and produce a growling noise when the feeler is moved over a slot containing an open coil.

Question: In the illustrated motor controller the motor fails to start. A voltmeter reading between 1 and 5 reads line voltage while the voltmeter reading between 2 and 5 reads 0 VAC. What is most likely the problem? See illustration EL-0007.
Response 2: an open stop switch contact (when not pushed in)
Response 3: an open start switch contact (when pushed in)

Question: With power available at the fuses and the motor disconnected from line the following voltage readings are taken:
With power available at the fuses and the motor disconnected from line the following voltage readings are taken:
With power available at the fuses and the motor disconnected from line the following voltage readings are taken:
With power available at the fuses and the motor disconnected from line the following voltage readings are taken:
If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the fuse being tested is blown? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the fuse being tested is not blown and has proper continuity? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the single pole single throw switch being tested is in the "on" position and the internal switch contacts are closed and have proper continuity? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the single pole single throw switch being tested is in the "on" position but the internal switch contacts are corroded and have partial continuity? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the single pole single throw switch being tested is in the "on" position but the internal switch contacts are deteriorated and have no continuity? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the single pole single throw switch being tested is in the "off" position but the internal switch contacts are welded together? See illustration EL-0210.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration what would be displayed on the screen if the single pole single throw switch being tested is in the "off" position and the internal switch contacts have no continuity? See illustration EL-0210.
An open primary coil in a simple potential transformer will be indicated by which of the listed conditions?
Response 1: No voltage on the output of the secondary coil.
Response 2: An infinite resistance value on the secondary coil.
Response 3: Low resistance value on the primary coil.

Question: The FIRST requirement for logical troubleshooting of any system requires the troubleshooter to do what?
Response 1: collect all available data on a casualty
Response 3: identify the probable cause of a symptom

Question: If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration to test an AC contactor coil what would the display read if the coil is open-circuited? See illustration EL-0214.
If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration to test an AC contactor coil what would the display read if the coil is functioning properly? See illustration EL-0214.
If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration to test an AC solenoid valve coil what would the display read if the coil is short-circuited? See illustration EL-0214.
If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration to test an AC solenoid valve coil what would the display read if the coil is open-circuited? See illustration EL-0214.

If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration to test an AC solenoid valve coil what would the display read if the coil is functioning properly? See illustration EL-0214.
If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration to test a capacitor what would the display read if the capacitor is functioning properly? See illustration EL-0213.
Response 1: the ohmic value would initially read very low but over time the ohmic value would gradually rise to an extremely high value (OL ohms)
Response 2: the ohmic value would initially read very high (OL ohms) but over time the ohmic value would gradually drop to an extremely low value
Response 3: the ohmic value would read very low and remain at that value
Response 4: the ohmic value would read very high (OL ohms) and remain at that value

Question: If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration to test a capacitor what would the display read if the capacitor is shorted? See illustration EL-0213.
Response 1: the ohmic value would initially read very low but over time the ohmic value would gradually rise to an extremely high value (OL ohms)
Response 2: the ohmic value would initially read very high (OL ohms) but over time the ohmic value would gradually drop to an extremely low value
Response 3: the ohmic value would read very low and remain at that value
Response 4: the ohmic value would read very high (OL ohms) and remain at that value

Question: If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "A" of the illustration to test a capacitor what would the display read if the capacitor is open circuited? See illustration EL-0213.
Response 1: the ohmic value would initially read very low but over time the ohmic value would gradually rise to an extremely high value (OL ohms)
Response 2: the ohmic value would initially read very high (OL ohms) but over time the ohmic value would gradually drop to an extremely low value
Response 3: the ohmic value would read very low and remain at that value
Response 4: the ohmic value would read very high (OL ohms) and remain at that value

Question: If a digital multimeter is set up as shown in figure "B" of the illustration to test a capacitor what would the display read if the capacitor was functioning properly? See illustration EL-0213.
Response 1: the charging voltage would be displayed which will initially be low and gradually rise to the internal battery voltage
Response 2: the actual capacitance value of the capacitor will be displayed which should be within the tolerance range of the capacitor
Response 3: initially a very low ohmic value will be displayed followed by a gradual rise in resistance until a very high value is displayed (OL ohms)
Response 4: initially a very high ohmic value will be displayed (OL ohms) followed by a gradual drop in resistance until a very low value is displayed

Question: When troubleshooting an electronic circuit an unreliable high resistance "cold" solder joint can be located with the aid of an ohmmeter. Once the problem has been located what should be done?
Response 1: reheat the circuit in an oven to an even temperature and recheck with an ohmmeter
Response 2: reheat the connection with a match and recheck with an ohmmeter
Response 3: reheat connection with a soldering tool and recheck with an ohmmeter
Response 4: do nothing as this is the normal condition

Question: Normally what is the FIRST step in troubleshooting a transistor mounted on a circuit card?
Response 1: carefully remove the transistors from the card
Response 2: give the circuit an initial test with a signal generator
Response 3: test for continuity with a low voltage DC supply

Question: What is an effective method of troubleshooting digital circuits in a console?
Response 1: supply alternate logic levels at the input(s) and test for change of state conditions at the output
Response 2: ground all inputs and test for a logic "1" at the output
Response 3: open all inputs and test for a logic '0' at the output
Response 4: vary each input smoothly from 0-10 volts and test for similar variance at the output

Question: When troubleshooting a console circuit card suspected of being faulty you should first check for proper operating voltages followed by cleaning the card. Then what should be done?
Response 1: make sure wired connections and push-on connectors are tight
Response 2: test each resistor and capacitor on the card with an ohmmeter
Response 3: check the continuity of all printed circuit traces with an ohmmeter
Response 4: measure the gain of each transistor or integrated circuit

Question: When troubleshooting a console circuit card suspected of being faulty what would be the last thing to do if all else fails to reveal the problem?
Response 1: check the fuses and voltage levels of all power supplies in the console
Response 2: clean dust and debris from the card and burnish the sliding connections
Response 3: make sure all connections are tight including wire wrappings and push-on types
Response 4: substitute a new or repaired spare card and check the operation of the circuit

Question: If a solid-state circuit is inoperative; what should be the FIRST action taken?
Response 1: wiggle all the components to check for loose connections

Question: When troubleshooting electronic equipment what should be the FIRST step taken before testing any circuit voltages?
Response 1: set the meter to the lowest range
Response 2: check the voltage supply from the power source
Response 4: check the current flow through the circuit

Question: While on watch at sea with only one ship's service turbo-generator on line the entire plant suddenly blacks out without warning. After restoring power which of the following faults would most likely have attributed to this casualty?
Response 1: The turbo-generator throttle valve position "micro switch" vibrated open allowing the main breaker to trip open according to its protection circuitry.
Response 2: Someone pushed the trip button to the 'shore power' breaker.
Response 3: The main air compressor suddenly stopped.
Response 4: The standby generator started automatically and became motorized.

Question: What is the name of the device shown in figure "2" of the illustration? See illustration EL-0068.

A lightly loaded three-phase squirrel-cage induction motor while running begins to vibrate excessively but continues to run. After shutting down the motor the motor will not restart but makes growling noises overheats and smokes. What caused this?
Response 1: The motor tripped-out on under load.
Response 2: The branch circuit breaker tripped open.
Response 3: The source voltage or frequency was too low.
Response 4: One of the lines feeding the motor has an open phase resulting in single-phasing.

Question: Which of the following statements concerning electrical cables is correct?
Response 1: Where they pass through watertight bulkheads they should be fitted with watertight stuffing boxes.
Response 2: Electric cable coverings should never be grounded.
Response 3: Electrical cables must be rigidly held in place by welding of armored cable.
Response 4: Electrical cables must be glued in place where nonmetallic insulation is used.

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the spaces listed is defined as a 'location requiring an exceptional degree of protection' when considering the installation of shipboard electrical equipment?
According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what is another term for a motor enclosure which is considered to be waterproof?

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the following IEEE publications would be the best reference for general guidance on recommended practice for electrical installations aboard ship?

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). who must be notified before alterations or modifications can be performed to electrical installations that deviate from approved plans or that may effect the safety of the vessel?
Response 4: The Officer in Charge of Marine Inspection

Question: In interpreting 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what would be considered a 'corrosive location'?
Response 1: a location exposed to the weather on a vessel operating only in fresh water
Response 2: a location exposed to the weather on a vessel that may operate in salt water
Response 3: a location within a machinery space subjected to the presence of steam
Response 4: a location within a machinery space subjected to heavy condensation

Question: In interpreting 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) under what conditions must particular attention be paid when performing periodic inspections of electrical equipment?
Response 1: When circuits have been added or modified since the original issuance of the Certificate of Inspection
Response 2: When circuits have been removed since the original issuance of the Certificate of Inspection
Response 3: When circuits have been added or modified prior to the original issuance of the Certificate of Inspection
Response 4: When circuits have been removed prior to the original issuance of the Certificate of Inspection

Question: In interpreting 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what are the acceptable variations of steady state voltage and frequency for electrical equipment rated for values of 460 VAC and 60 Hz?
Response 1: voltage between 414.0 and 487.6 VAC frequency between 57 and 63 Hz
Response 2: voltage between 432.4 and 506.0 VAC frequency between 57 and 63 Hz
Response 3: voltage between 437.0 and 483.0 VAC frequency between 54 and 63.6 Hz
Response 4: voltage between 437.0 and 483.0 VAC frequency between 56.4 and 66 Hz

Question: In interpreting 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what should the ambient temperature rating be on a replacement electric motor to be installed in the engine room of a vessel assuming that it cannot be proven that the temperature will not exceed 45C in these spaces?

In accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) a motor fitted with a heater to prevent condensation within the motor when the motor is idle must have a separate source of power and means of disconnect from the motor itself. Additionally a sign is required to warn the operator to open both devices before servicing. Where would you expect to find the heater disconnect device?
Response 2: adjacent to the motor disconnect device

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the following motor applications would be required to be continuous in terms of duty cycle?
Response 2: Main engine lube oil pump drive motor

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) for the purposes of the installation of a new electric motor and its controller which of the following applications would allow low voltage release to be used?
Response 1: a controller for a motor of less than 2 HP
Response 2: a controller for a motor where automatic restart would be hazardous
Response 3: a controller for a non-vital motor of 2 HP or more
Response 4: a controller for a non-vital motor of 5 HP or more

Question: According to the 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) for motor controller replacement purposes which motor application would require low voltage release?
Response 1: a motor controller for a vital propulsion auxiliary with restart capability at a central control station
Response 2: a motor controller for a vital propulsion auxiliary without restart capability at a central control station and where automatic restart would not be hazardous
Response 3: a motor controller for a vital propulsion auxiliary where automatic restart would be hazardous
Response 4: a motor controller for a non-vital auxiliary

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) electric motors operating in an engine room machinery space must be designed for an ambient temperature of what value?

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the listed protection or release control logic schemes would require a motor controller to be manually re-started upon restoration of voltage following a power failure?

Where automatic restart does not present a hazard after a power failure according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) it is required that motor controllers for auxiliaries vital to the propulsion equipment to be provided with what type of protection?

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) the type of control circuit logic associated with auxiliaries vital to the operation of propulsion equipment where automatic restart after a voltage failure would not create a hazard is termed what?

According to the 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) requires which of the listed features to open the power circuit to a motor due to low voltage and re-close automatically when the voltage is restored to normal?
According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which statement is true concerning a circuit breaker located in the machinery space and installed in a 440V AC distribution system?
Response 1: It can be dependent upon mechanical cooling to operate within its rating.
Response 2: It can have a long-time delay trip element set above the continuous current rating of the trip element or the circuit breaker frame.
Response 3: It must have an interrupting rating sufficient to interrupt the maximum asymmetrical short-circuit current available at the point of application.
Response 4: It must have an ambient temperature rating of 40 degrees C.

Question: It is desired to replace the deck matting in front of a switchboard. According to the 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what would be a suitable replacement?
Response 1: any non-conductive mat similar in appearance to the one being replaced
Response 2: a non-conductive mat or grating rated for the specific switchboard voltage
Response 3: a non-conductive grating must be used as non-conductive mats are no longer approved
Response 4: the mat need not be replaced if the decking in front of the switchboard is adequately painted

Question: You are in the process of replacing an ammeter in a generator control panel of an AC switchboard and you notice that the current transformer secondary circuit is not fused. In accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what should be your action?
Response 1: install a suitable fuse (for one line only) since this must have been missed during initial inspection
Response 2: install two suitable fuses (one for each line) since this must have been missed during initial inspection
Response 3: install a two pole circuit breaker in the secondary circuit
Response 4: do nothing as the secondary circuit of a current transformer must never be fused

Question: You are in the planning stages of replacing a section of control wiring in an AC switchboard with one end attached to a component on a hinged panel. In addition to using extra flexible wire in accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what criteria must be met in terms of the replacement wire?
Response 1: be suitable for installation in a switchboard and be rated at least 60 degrees C or higher
Response 2: be stranded copper and flame retardant
Response 3: be solid copper and oil resistant
Response 4: be No. 18 AWG or larger or be ribbon cable or similar conductor size cable

Question: In accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) panel boards are required to be numbered and have a circuit directory. What information is required for each circuit in the directory?
Response 1: circuit designation and load description only
Response 2: load description and over current device rating or setting only
Response 3: circuit designation and over current device rating or setting only
Response 4: circuit designation load description and over current device rating or setting

Question: You are in the planning stages of adding a circuit to an available spare in a distribution panel board. Assume that the circuit shall be protected with a 20 amp circuit breaker. In accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what would be the maximum load permitted if the load will be energized continuously for 3 hours or more and the branch circuit breaker to be used is NOT rated for continuous duty at 100% of its rating?

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what statement is true concerning a 3 phase ungrounded electrical distribution system's ground detection system as illustrated in figure "B" of the illustration? See illustration EL-0008.
Response 1: The system provides continuous indication of circuit status to ground with a provision to remove the indicating device from the reference ground.
Response 2: The system does NOT provide a continuous indication of circuit status to ground but has a provision to connect the indicating device to reference ground for ground detection.
Response 3: The system provides continuous indication of circuit status to ground with an added provision to connect the indicating device to the reference ground for ground detection.
Response 4: The system does NOT provide a continuous indication of circuit status to ground but has a provision to remove the indicating device to reference ground.

Question: As required by 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) the illustrated ground detection system shown in figure "B" is appropriate for which type of electrical distribution system? See illustration EL-0008.
Response 4: high impedance grounded neutral 3 phase AC system

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) when considering replacement instrument and control wiring in a switchboard is to be of what minimum size?
According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what is the minimum conductor size allowed for use in making up a flexible electrical cord?
According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical engineering) regulations prohibit the use of portable electric cord or fixture wire aboard ship if that wire or cord is smaller than what size?
According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what statement is true concerning the use of twist-on connectors?
Response 1: Twist-on connectors may be used for making joints in cables.
Response 2: Twist-on connectors may be used to facilitate a conductor splice.
Response 3: Twist-on connectors may be used to extend the length of a circuit.
Response 4: Twist-on connectors may be used in enclosures as long as the insulating cap can be secured to prevent loosening due to vibration.

Question: According to CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the following statements is true concerning flexible electric cord and cable used aboard ship?
Response 1: No. 12 AWG cable or cord may be spliced for repairs if made in compliance with CFR 111.60-19.
Response 2: No. 14 AWG cable or cord may be spliced for repairs if made in compliance with CFR 111.60-19.
Response 3: No. 16 AWG cable or cord may be spliced for repairs if made in compliance with CFR 111.60-19.
Response 4: No. 18 AWG cable or cord may be spliced for repairs if made in compliance with CFR 111.60-19.

Question: When portable cords are connected to devices such as portable tools you must eliminate direct tension on the joints or terminals. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) how may this be provided for?
Response 1: knotting or taping of the cords only
Response 2: installation of a strain relief fitting only
Response 3: knotting or taping of cords or installation of strain relief fittings
Response 4: joints and terminals are required to handle the tension

Question: You are in the planning stages of making up a portable cable to be used for transmitting power from a battery charger on a ship to a charging receptacle on a lifeboat. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the following statements is true regarding the transmitting of power between receptacles?
Response 1: The plug on the end of the cord that may be energized when unplugged from the receptacle must be male.
Response 2: The plug on the end of the cord that may be energized when unplugged from the receptacle must be female.
Response 3: The plugs on both ends of the cord must be male.
Response 4: Regulations do not allow transmitting power between receptacles under any circumstances.

Question: You are in the planning stages of installing an electrical receptacle on a lifeboat. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what statement is true concerning receptacle connections?
Response 1: Outlets connecting a lifeboat and the vessel's electrical system must allow the plug to pull free when the lifeboat is lowered.
Response 2: Outlets connecting a lifeboat and the vessel's electrical system must have threaded plugs to prevent nuisance unplugging.
Response 3: Outlets connecting a lifeboat and the vessel's electrical system must use knotted cords to prevent nuisance unplugging.
Response 4: There are no special provisions concerning outlets connecting a lifeboat and the vessel's electrical system.

Question: You are in the planning stages of installing an electrical receptacle in a receptacle branch circuit. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) under what conditions do the regulations require that the electrical receptacle is to have a grounding pole?
Response 1: if it operates at 100 volts or more
Response 2: if it is in a location exposed to the weather
Response 3: if it is in a location accessible to other than qualified personnel
Response 4: if it is connected to a DC source

Question: You are in the planning stages of making up a portable cord for use on a ship with 110 VAC 220 VAC and 110 VDC outlets. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what statement is true concerning receptacle outlets?
Response 1: Each receptacle type may use the same plug configuration but care must be exercised in plugging in cords.
Response 2: The 110 VAC and 220 VAC outlets may have the same plug configuration whereas the 110 VDC outlets must be different to preclude plugging a cord into an outlet of incompatible power type.
Response 3: The 110 VAC and 110 VDC outlets may have the same plug configuration whereas the 220 VAC outlets must be different to preclude plugging a cord into an outlet of incompatible voltage.
Response 4: Each receptacle type must have a different plug configuration to preclude plugging a cord into an outlet of incompatible voltage or type of power.

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) regulations require that lighting fixture globes must be protected by guards if the fixtures are located in certain spaces. Which of the listed spaces would be an example?
Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR Part 111) permit which of the listed types of fuses to be used in an interior lighting circuit?

It is desired to add additional 120 VAC 100 watt lighting fixtures in the accommodations port side fed from circuit #1 (1L110) as illustrated in the lighting panel L110 of the illustration. According to 46 CFR 111.75-5 would be the maximum allowable additional lighting fixtures that could be installed? See illustration EL-0013.

It is desired to add additional 120 VAC 100 watt lighting fixtures in the accommodations port side fed from circuit #3 (3L110) as illustrated in the lighting panel L110 of the illustration. According to 46 CFR 111.75-5 would be the maximum allowable additional lighting fixtures that could be installed? See illustration EL-0013.
According to CFR 111.75-5 what would be the maximum amperage load on circuit #2 (2L110) of the illustrated lighting panel board L110 of the illustration? See illustration EL-0013.

You are in the planning stages of replacing a battery charger where an exact duplicate of the charger to be replaced is not available. Obviously the charger must be suitable for the battery to be charged. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which of the following is a true statement concerning battery chargers?
Response 1: Battery chargers incorporating grounded autotransformers must be used and if the charging voltage exceeds 20% of the battery line voltage automatic protection against reversal current must be provided.
Response 2: Battery chargers incorporating grounded autotransformers must NOT be used and if the charging voltage exceeds 20% of the battery line voltage automatic protection against reversal current must be provided.
Response 3: Battery chargers incorporating grounded autotransformers must NOT be used and if the charging voltage is less than the battery line voltage automatic protection against reversal current must be provided.
Response 4: Battery chargers incorporating grounded autotransformers must be used and if the charging voltage is less than 20% of the battery line voltage automatic protection against reversal current must be provided.

Question: You are in the planning stages of replacing a battery room ventilation fan drive motor located outside of but within 5 feet of the end of the exhaust duct. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what type of motor in terms of enclosure type must be used as a replacement?

In accordance with 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) each diesel engine driven generator prime mover must have an over speed device independent of the normal operating governor. If in testing the over speed device what should be the trip point setting in terms of rated speed?
Response 1: not to exceed 10% above rated speed
Response 2: not to exceed 15% above rated speed
Response 3: not to exceed 20% above rated speed
Response 4: not to exceed 25% above rated speed

Question: You are in the planning stages of setting the instantaneous trip of a ship's service generator circuit breaker. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what statement is true regarding the criteria for the instantaneous trip set point assuming the generator is capable of being paralleled?
Response 1: The trip point should be set below but as close as practical to the maximum asymmetrical short circuit current available.
Response 2: The trip point should be set above but as close as practical to the maximum asymmetrical short circuit current available.
Response 3: The trip point should be set considerably above the maximum asymmetrical short circuit current available.
Response 4: The trip point should be set exactly equal to the maximum asymmetrical short circuit current available.

Question: There are very specific rules that govern the testing of generators found in the appropriate publication incorporated by reference. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) which agency publishes the rules for the construction and testing of generators?

According to its nameplate a power transformer has Class F insulation and is rated for 40C ambient temperature. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) what would be the maximum winding temperature allowable as taken by the resistance method?

Belt drives used in hazardous locations may potentially present an explosion hazard due to the build up of static electricity. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) how are belt drives used in hazardous locations required to be equipped?
Response 2: Use of ungrounded pulleys and shafts
Response 4: Use of conductive belts and grounded pulleys and shafts

Question: According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) with respect to acceptable voltage variations for electrical equipment which statement is true if the equipment rated voltage is 450 VAC?
Response 1: Actual applied voltage should be between 405 and 477 VAC.
Response 2: Actual applied voltage should be between 423 and 495 VAC.
Response 3: Actual applied voltage should be between 423 and 477 VAC.
Response 4: Actual applied voltage should be between 405 and 495 VAC.

Question: Suppose a cargo vessel of 1600 gross tons or more is fitted with emergency storage batteries for the purpose of supplying emergency lighting and power. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) the capacity of the storage batteries is such that they should be able to successfully power the emergency loads for a period of 18 hours. Beginning with fully charged batteries what is the minimum allowable voltage of the batteries after the 18 hour discharge period assuming a nominal voltage rating of 24 VDC and operating at rated capacity.

Relay-controlled emergency lanterns have an internal storage battery that is maintained in a charged state when normal power is available. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) upon a loss of normal power what is the minimum time the internal battery should be capable of providing light?

Suppose a cargo vessel of 1600 gross tons or more is fitted with emergency storage batteries for the purpose of supplying emergency lighting and power. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) the capacity of the storage batteries is such that they should be able to successfully power the emergency loads for a period of 18 hours. What is the maximum initial voltage of the batteries allowable at the beginning of the 18 hour discharge period assuming a nominal voltage rating of 24 VDC.

According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) when supplying emergency lighting loads the storage battery initial voltage must not exceed the standard system voltage by more than what percentage?

Suppose a cargo vessel of 1600 gross tons or more is fitted with emergency storage batteries for the purpose of supplying emergency lighting and power. According to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering) the capacity of the storage batteries is such that they should be able to successfully power the emergency loads for a period of 18 hours. Beginning with fully charged batteries what is the minimum allowable percentage of the voltage rating of the batteries after the 18 hour discharge period assuming a nominal voltage rating of 24 VDC and operating at rated capacity.

Emergency generators are required to automatically start upon a loss of normal supply voltage according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). In conducting a test of the emergency generator automatic start function if the normal system supply voltage is 450 VAC to what value would the normal supply voltage have to drop to trigger the automatic starting of the emergency generator?
Response 1: The voltage must drop to 247.5 VAC.
Response 2: The voltage must drop to 270.0 VAC.
Response 3: The voltage must drop to 382.5 VAC.
Response 4: The voltage must drop to within a range from as low as 270 VAC to as high as 382.5 VAC.

Question: Emergency generators are required to automatically start upon a loss of normal supply voltage according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). In conducting a test of the emergency generator automatic transfer of load function if the normal system supply voltage is 450 VAC to what value would the emergency generator output voltage have to rise to trigger the automatic transfer of emergency loads to the emergency generator?
Response 1: The voltage would have to rise to 382.5 VAC.
Response 2: The voltage would have to rise to 427.5 VAC.
Response 3: The voltage would have to rise to a value between from 382.5 VAC to 427.5 VAC.
Response 4: The voltage would have to rise to a value ranging from between 405 VAC to 450 VAC.

Question: Emergency generators are required to automatically start upon a loss of normal supply voltage according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). In conducting a test of the emergency generator automatic transfer of load function what is the maximum amount of time allowed for the automatic transfer of load to the emergency generator?

Emergency generators are required to automatically start upon a loss of normal supply voltage according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). In conducting a test of the emergency generator capacity function the emergency generator fuel tank on an ocean going cargo vessel of 1600 GT or more must be capable of supplying fuel to a fully loaded engine for a time period of at least how many hours?

Emergency generators are required to automatically start upon a loss of normal supply voltage according to 46 CFR Subchapter J (Electrical Engineering). In conducting a test of the emergency generator automatic transfer of load function if the normal system supply voltage is 480 VAC to what value would the normal source output voltage have to rise to trigger the automatic transfer of emergency loads back to the normal power source?
Response 1: It would have to rise to 408 VAC.
Response 2: It would have to rise to 456 VAC.
Response 3: It would have to rise to a value between from 408 VAC to 456 VAC.

Question: Given the circuit and input and output waveforms shown in figure "E" of the illustration what function does the coupling transformer perform? See illustration EL-0075.

Question: If it is desired to determine the average temperature across a large duct what thermocouple wiring technique can be used to generate an emf proportional to the average temperature?

Response 1: The monitor works on the fluorescence principle where the greater the oil content the less the amount of ultra-violet light detected by the sampling photo-electric cell as compared to the reference photo-electric cell.
Response 2: The monitor works on the absorption/scattering principle where the greater the oil content the less the amount of visible light detected by the sampling photo-electric cell as compared to the reference photo-electric cell.

Response 4: The bob has a pointed end and floats on the surface of the liquid when lowered by the tape.

Question: What statement best represents the characteristics of an ullage tape and bob for the purposes of taking a vented tank sounding?
Response 1: The bob has a pointed end and sinks in the liquid when lowered by the tape.
Response 2: The bob has a cupped end and sinks in the liquid when lowered by the tape.

Question: What statement best represents the characteristics of innage and ullage tank soundings?

Question: What statement is true concerning the operating principle of a liquid level sensing and transmitting system of the capacitance type?

Response 4: The capacitance method is generally used with non-conductive liquids and works on the principle of the substantial difference between the specific gravity of air and that of the liquid in the tank.

Question: According to the illustration shown which of the following statements is/are true? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: If port "C" became obstructed or plugged the outlet pressure would tend to decrease.
Response 2: If port "J" became obstructed or plugged the outlet pressure would tend to decrease.
Response 3: If auxiliary valve "D" developed a considerable leak the outlet pressure would tend to decrease.

Question: If the high pressure port became plugged in the spring-loaded internal pilot self-operated steam pressure reducing valve illustrated which of the following problems would probably occur? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: The main valve would open wide and deliver high pressure steam.
Response 2: The opening of the auxiliary valve "D" would have no effect on the positioning of the piston 'H.'
Response 3: Main valve "B" would be opened by spring 'A.'
Response 4: Spring "F" would open valve "D" causing spring "A" to compress.

Question: Which of the problems listed will occur if diaphragm "E" in the illustration shown develops a significantly large hole? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: The auxiliary valve will open wider due to the action of spring 'F'.
Response 2: The main valve "B" will open wider compressing the main valve spring 'A'.
Response 3: Downstream pressure will be greater than the desired setting.

Question: The probable cause of erratic operation of a pneumatically controlled steam pressure reducing valve is __________.
Response 1: the range spring has become weakened
Response 2: an incorrect loading pressure supplied to the power unit

Question: How would the pressure setting of the illustrated self-contained internal-pilot piston-operated steam pressure-reducer be reduced to a lower set point? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: The adjusting spring would need to have its compression load reduced by rotating the adjusting screw clockwise further into the adjusting spring chamber.
Response 2: The adjusting spring would need to have its compression load reduced by rotating the adjusting screw counter-clockwise further out of the adjusting spring chamber.
Response 3: The adjusting spring would need to have its compression load increased by rotating the adjusting screw counter-clockwise further out of the adjusting spring chamber.
Response 4: The adjusting spring would need to have its compression load increased by rotating the adjusting screw clockwise further into the adjusting spring chamber.

Question: Suppose the illustrated self-contained internal-pilot piston-operated steam pressure-reducing valve is part of a 600-to150 psig reducing station. If there was an increase in demand for steam downstream what statement correctly represents how the valve would initially respond? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: The downstream pressure would drop causing the control diaphragm to flex upward and further close the pilot valve.
Response 2: The downstream pressure would drop causing the control diaphragm to flex downward and further open the pilot valve.
Response 3: The downstream pressure would rise causing the control diaphragm to flex upward and further close the pilot valve.
Response 4: The downstream pressure would rise causing the control diaphragm to flex downward and further open the pilot valve.

Question: In the illustrated self-contained internal-pilot piston-operated steam pressure-reducing valve what statement is true concerning the opening and closing forces acting upon the control diaphragm? See illustration GS-0044.
Response 1: The spring (F) force acting on the control diaphragm is a pilot valve opening force and the downstream pressure (J) acting on the control diaphragm is a pilot valve closing force.
Response 2: The spring (F) force acting on the control diaphragm is a pilot valve opening force and the upstream pressure
Response 3: acting on the control diaphragm is a pilot valve closing force.

Question: In the illustrated self-contained internal-pilot piston-operated temperature control valve what statement is true concerning the pilot and main valves? See illustration GS-0045.
Response 1: The pilot valve is downward seating and the main valve is upward seating.
Response 2: The pilot valve is upward seating and the main valve is upward seating.
Response 3: The pilot valve is downward seating and the main valve is downward seating.
Response 4: The pilot valve is upward seating and the main valve is downward seating.

Question: Suppose the illustrated self-contained internal-pilot piston-operated temperature control valve is part of the temperature control system for a steam-heated heavy fuel oil service heater for a steam boiler. If there was an increase in demand for fuel by the boiler what statement correctly represents how the valve would initially respond? See illustration GS-0045.
Response 1: The fuel oil heater fuel outlet temperature would increase causing the remote bulb pressure to increase and the control diaphragm to flex downward and through lever action further close the pilot valve.
Response 2: The fuel oil heater fuel outlet temperature would decrease causing the remote bulb pressure to decrease and the control diaphragm to flex upward and through lever action further open the pilot valve.
Response 3: The fuel oil heater fuel outlet temperature would decrease causing the remote bulb pressure to decrease and the control diaphragm to flex downward and through lever action further close the pilot valve.
Response 4: The fuel oil heater fuel outlet temperature would increase causing the remote bulb pressure to increase and the control diaphragm to flex upward and through lever action further open the pilot valve.

Question: Which of the listed devices would be installed at a control system air pressure reducing station?
Which of the listed components would normally be installed with a Control Air System pressure regulator?

Response 3: Exchange part "L" for one that is upward seated.

Question: With regards to the device shown in the illustration the parts labeled "D" and "I" function together to __________. See illustration GS-0043.

Question: An automatic temperature controller with a net output pressure of 15 psi and a full scale range of 15F would have a sensitivity ratio of __________.

Question: As shown in the illustration the pneumatic force balance unit could be used for a __________. See illustration GS-0145.

Question: The two most common gases used in pneumatic systems are __________.

Response 3: flow rates as a square root extractor

Question: The power necessary to close the diaphragm control valve as used in a pneumatic control system is supplied by the __________. See illustration GS-0051.

Question: If a leak occurs between the areas labeled "B" and "J" of the control valve shown in the illustration which of the following problems is most likely to occur? See illustration GS-0043.
Response 1: The valve will open with a decrease in temperature below the set point of the liquid being heated.

Response 3: The valve will open with an increase in temperature above the set point of the liquid being heated.

Question: Over tightening of the valve stem packing to a pneumatically controlled final control element shown in the illustration will cause __________. See illustration GS-0051.

Response 1: practically no limit to the power available for a given system

Question: In a pneumatic automation system a unit producing a signal to govern the position of the controller of the measured variable relative to the value of the measured variable is said to have __________.
In an automation system increasing or decreasing the loading pressure by a set amount is known as __________.
Biasing in a pneumatic automated combustion control system refers to a set amount of increase or decrease in the __________.
The difference between the setpoint and the measured parameter in an automatic flow controller is called:
The range of values around a setpoint of a measured variable where "no action" occurs in an automatic flow controller is called:
In an automatic flow controller the factor by which the magnitude of the flow error signal has been increased to drive the final valve controller is referred to as _________.
In a proportional controller the term "offset" refers to the difference between the________________.
The return signal from a valve as sensed by an automatic flow controller that is proportional to the actual valve position is referred to as:
The difference between the set point in an automatic controller and the steady-state value of the measured parameter is called ___________.
A two-position single-point action controller has been adjusted to minimize cycling and would only be suitable for __________.
In an automated control system which of the following statements would apply to any type of closed loop system?
Response 1: The manipulated variables are adjusted only from the input demand signals without monitoring the outlet conditions or variables.
Response 2: Another term commonly used in conjunction with this type of system is 'feed forward'.
Response 3: The controlled variable must always deviate from its set point before any corrective action is initiated by the controller.
Response 4: In order for a system to fall under the category of closed loop control there should be no adjustments required to be made manually by the operator.

Question: A controller with floating action has a controlled variable where the range of values produces no motion of the final control element. This range of values is called the __________.
The range of values through which the input can be varied without initiating an output response is known as __________.

Response 1: desired value of the proportionally controlled variable
Response 2: floating rate of the proportional-speed floating component
Response 3: value representing the readjusted controlled variable
Response 4: desired prepositioned value of the controlled medium

Question: Which of the following control actions when combined with proportional-position action will eliminate manual repositioning of the set point for each load change to produce an automatic reset action?

Response 3: repeats the proportional action more frequently

Question: Which of the following statements expresses the function of proportional-plus-reset action?
Response 1: The action measures the rate of time of the final control element.
Response 2: The action gives control without offset under all load conditions.
Response 3: The action combines proportional-position action and rate action.
Response 4: The action is very unstable for anything but constant load conditions.

Question: In the operation of a proportional-plus-reset controller the proportional action __________.
In the operation of a proportional-plus-reset controller the proportional action __________.

Response 1: The period of time in which the set point and the control point coincide.
Response 2: The periodic change between the set point and the control point.
Response 3: The variable difference between the set point and the control point.
Response 4: The constant difference between the set point and the control point.

Question: 'Offset' is an inherent characteristic of which of the following types of control modes?

Response 1: corrective action is only proportional to offset
Response 2: exact correction can be made only when there is no change in load
Response 4: the corrective action is only proportional to the deviation

Question: The characteristic of 'offset' is inherent with which mode of control?

Response 3: proportional band adjustment of the controller

Question: A mandatory characteristic of a pure amplifier is that __________.
Response 1: the form of the input and output energies must be the same
Response 2: the ratio of the output to the input must always be greater than the numerical value of 'one'
Response 3: the form of the input and output energies must be different
Response 4: the action must be either integral or derivative

Question: Which of the following proportional band values most closely approaches 'ON-OFF' control?
