Response 1: leaky discharge valves on the LP cylinder
Response 2: leaky discharge valves on the HP cylinder

Question: Which of the following problems could cause air to blow out through the inlet air filter of a running compressor?
Air blowing from the intake air filter of an operating air compressor indicates __________.
Response 3: pulsations in the air distribution system
Response 4: overloading of the air distribution system

Question: One cause of leaky valves in a low pressure air compressor may be attributed to __________.
Response 1: running with an air filter element different from that required by the original manufacturer's specifications
Response 2: excessive operating hours without carrying out preventive maintenance

Question: Leaking valves in a low pressure reciprocating air compressor can result from __________.
Response 2: operating the compressor at excessive speed
Response 3: uneven piston stroke in the compressor

Question: Leaking valves in an air compressor can be a result of __________.
A leaking suction valve in the second stage of a two stage high pressure air compressor can cause excessively high __________.
If the intercooler relief valve lifts while an air compressor is operating under load you should check for __________.
Response 1: a defective pressure switch or pilot valve
Response 2: a leak in the intercooler piping
Response 3: leakage through the low pressure unloader control diaphragm

Question: Which of the following problems would be the probable cause for the faulty operation of a reciprocating air compressor suction valve?
Response 1: Carbon build up in the piston ring belt.
Response 2: Faulty operation of a cylinder unloader.
Response 3: Compressor operation in an area of high relative humidity.

Question: A reciprocating air compressor is running roughly and vibrating excessively indicating that the __________.
If there is a sudden drop in the capacity of a reciprocating air compressor you should check for __________.
Response 2: worn piston rings or cylinder liners

Question: If a ship service air compressor failed to unload the __________.
Response 2: air receiver pressure would be excessively low

Question: Slipping drive belts on a ship service air compressor is a probable symptom of __________.
If a ship service air compressor operating in intermittent service were failing to unload the __________.
Response 1: compressor would stop abruptly when power was secured
Response 3: air receiver indicated pressure would be excessively low
Response 4: compressor would require more than the normal amount of lubrication

Question: Which of the following problems can result in below normal pressure in the intercooler of an operating low pressure air compressor?
Response 3: Leaking intake valves on the high pressure cylinder
Response 4: Leaking discharge valves on the low pressure cylinder

Question: Broken valve strips in an operating low pressure air compressor will cause __________.
Response 2: oil contamination in the compressed air
Response 4: no immediate loss of the compressed air capacity

Question: Cylinder inlet valve failure in a low pressure air compressor can be caused by __________.
Response 1: flywheel misalignment with the driving motor
Response 4: excessive moisture buildup in the receiver

Question: A compressor operating with an accumulation of dust and grease on the surfaces of an intercooler would result in __________.
The transfer of heat within a solid caused by the application of thermal energy is called ___________.
Sacrificial zinc anodes are used on the saltwater side of heat exchangers to __________.
Response 1: keep heat transfer surfaces shiny and clean
Response 2: prevent rapid accumulation of marine growth
Response 3: provide a protective coating on heat exchanger surfaces
Response 4: reduce electrolytic action on heat exchanger metals

Question: Zinc anodes are installed in a marine sea water heat exchanger cooling system to ________.
Which non-ferrous alloy is most commonly used for heat exchanger tubes and possesses a high resistance to corrosion?
Which of the listed figures represents the configuration and alignment of the inlet/outlet head as viewed from the tube side? See illustration GS-0122.
The general purpose of a heat exchanger is to __________.
Response 1: eliminate hot air from the condenser
Response 2: maintain steady pressure in a system
Response 3: heat or cool one fluid by means of another fluid
Response 4: reduce the engine room temperature in tropical climates

Question: The temperature differential occurring between the inlet temperature of the fluid to be cooled and the outlet temperature of the cooling medium in a shell-and-tube heat exchanger is greatest in which of the flow designs listed?
The rate of heat transfer between the hot and cold fluids passing through a shell-and-tube type heat exchanger will __________.
Response 1: remain constant along the tube's length
Response 2: be greatest in a single pass counter flow heat exchanger
Response 3: remain constant throughout the heat exchanger
Response 4: vary from section to section throughout the heat exchanger

Question: The rate of heat transfer between the hot and cold fluids passing through a shell-and-tube type heat exchanger will __________.
Response 1: remain constant along the tube's length
Response 2: vary according to the fluid pressures
Response 3: remain constant throughout the heat exchanger
Response 4: vary from section to section throughout the heat exchanger

Question: Heat exchanger tubes can be protected against erosion and abrasion by the use of __________.
Response 1: metallic packing on the inlet end

Question: Assuming oil and water flow rates remain the same what would be the effect of scale formation occurring on the inside of the cooling water tubes of a lube oil heat exchanger?
Response 1: Water temperature outlet temperature will decrease and the lube oil temperature will decrease.
Response 2: Water temperature outlet temperature will decrease and the lube oil temperature will increase.
Response 3: Water temperature outlet temperature will increase and the lube oil temperature will decrease.
Response 4: Water temperature outlet temperature will increase and the lube oil temperature will increase.

Question: Tube scaling in heat exchangers causes the heat transfer rate to decrease because the ________.
Response 1: surface area of the tube decreases
Response 3: thermal conductivity of the scale is very low
Response 4: flow through the heat exchanger becomes more turbulent

Question: In a heat exchanger excessive fluid velocity should be avoided to prevent __________.
When a heat exchanger is used as a cooler excessive cooling water flow should be avoided to prevent __________.
Erosive tube failure in a heat exchanger can result from __________.
In heat exchangers seawater pressure should be maintained lower than freshwater pressure to __________.
Response 1: eliminate scaling problems on the saltwater side
Response 2: reduce erosion of heat exchanger surfaces
Response 3: ease the load on the saltwater service pump

Question: Which of the following statements is true concerning a radiator type heat exchanger?
Response 1: Raw water is the cooling medium.
Response 2: Water cooled exhaust elbows remove the heat.
Response 3: The surge tank must be located a minimum of 4 feet above the highest finned tube.
Response 4: Air flow provided by a fan is used as the cooling medium.

Question: In a shell-and-tube type heat exchanger the most common cause of decreased performance is __________.
In a shell-and-tube type hydraulic fluid cooler the amount of heat transferred from the hydraulic fluid to the cooling water depends upon __________.
Response 1: the temperature of the hydraulic fluid
Response 2: the flow rate of both the cooling water and the hydraulic fluid
Response 3: the temperature of the cooling water

Question: A steam supplied heat exchanger will fail to maintain the designed quantity of heated liquid output if the __________.
A steam supplied heat exchanger will fail to maintain the designed quantity of heated liquid output if the __________.
What type of lube oil cooler is shown in the illustration? See illustration GS-0122.
Which of the following statements is true concerning lube oil coolers?
Response 1: The temperature of the oil is less than that of the cooling water.
Response 2: The pressure of the oil is less than that of the cooling water.
Response 3: The pressure of the oil is greater than that of the cooling water.
Response 4: Magnets are installed in the tube sheets to remove metal particles.

Question: The interior of some diesel engine saltwater heat exchangers are protected from electrolytic corrosion by the use of __________.
If both the shell-and-tube lube oil cooler and shell-and-tube jacket water cooler of a diesel engine are seawater cooled what statement is true?
Response 1: Seawater flows through the shells of both the lube-oil and jacket-water coolers.
Response 2: Seawater flows through the tubes of the lube-oil cooler and through the shell of the jacket- water cooler.
Response 3: Seawater flows through the tubes of the jacket-water cooler and through the shell of the lube- oil cooler.
Response 4: Seawater flows through the tubes of both the lube-oil and jacket-water coolers.

Question: If a heat exchanger is designed to condense refrigerant vapor using central cooling fresh water as a condensing medium what statement is true?
Response 1: The refrigerant vapor loses latent heat the central cooling fresh water loses latent heat.
Response 2: The refrigerant vapor loses sensible heat the central cooling fresh water gains latent heat.
Response 3: The refrigerant vapor loses latent heat the central cooling fresh water gains sensible heat.
Response 4: The refrigerant vapor gains latent heat the central cooling fresh water loses sensible heat.

Question: What type of flow pattern would be associated with a forced-convection finned-coil heat exchanger such as an air-cooled hydraulic oil cooler?
If a seawater-cooled shell-and-tube lubricating oil cooler has the seawater inlet and outlet connections on the opposite end water boxes in terms of the number of passes what statement is true?
Response 1: The number of fluid passes cannot be determined.
Response 2: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is four-pass.
Response 3: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is single-pass.
Response 4: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is two-pass.

Question: The general purpose of a heat exchanger is to ______.
Response 1: maintain steady pressure in a system
Response 2: eliminate hot air from the condenser
Response 3: heat or cool one fluid by means of another fluid
Response 4: reduce the engine room temperature in tropical climates

Question: With regard to the relative flow patterns through the tubes and the shell of shell-and-tube heat exchangers what statement is true?
Response 1: In a counter-flow heat exchanger the flow through the tubes and the flow through the shell are in opposite directions.
Response 2: In a counter-flow heat exchanger the flow through the tubes and the flow through the shell are in the same direction.
Response 3: In a parallel-flow heat exchanger the flow through the tubes and the flow through the shell are in opposite directions.
Response 4: In a cross-flow heat exchanger the flow through the tubes and the flow through the shell are in opposite directions.

Question: With regard to the number of passes through the tubes of shell-and-tube heat exchangers what statement is true?
Response 1: In two-pass and four-pass heat exchangers the inlet and outlet tube-side fluid connections are at opposite ends.
Response 2: In single-pass and two-pass heat exchangers the inlet and outlet tube-side fluid connections are at opposite ends.
Response 3: In single-pass and two-pass heat exchangers the inlet and outlet tube-side fluid connections are at the same end.
Response 4: In two-pass and four-pass heat exchangers the inlet and outlet tube-side fluid connections are at the same end.

Question: If a heat exchanger is designed to cool lubricating oil using sea water as a cooling medium what statement is true?
Response 1: The lubricating oil loses sensible heat and the sea water loses sensible heat.
Response 2: The lubricating oil loses sensible heat and the sea water gains sensible heat.
Response 3: The lubricating oil loses latent heat and the sea water gains latent heat.
Response 4: The lubricating oil gains sensible heat and the sea water loses sensible heat.

Question: If a heat exchanger is designed to heat heavy fuel oil using steam as a heating medium what statement is true?
Response 1: The heavy fuel oil gains sensible heat and the steam loses latent heat.
Response 2: The heavy fuel oil loses sensible heat and the steam gains latent heat.
Response 3: The heavy fuel oil gains latent heat and the steam loses sensible heat.
Response 4: The heavy fuel oil gains sensible heat and the steam loses sensible heat.

Question: If a heat exchanger is designed to evaporate sea water using diesel engine jacket water as an evaporating medium what statement is true?
Response 1: The sea water gains latent heat and the diesel engine jacket water loses latent heat.
Response 2: The sea water loses latent heat and the diesel engine jacket water gains sensible heat.
Response 3: The sea water gains sensible heat and the diesel engine jacket water loses latent heat.
Response 4: The sea water gains latent heat and the diesel engine jacket water loses sensible heat.

Question: If a seawater-cooled shell-and- tube lubricating oil cooler has the seawater inlet and outlet connections on the opposite end water boxes in terms of the number of passes what statement is true?
Response 1: The number of fluid passes cannot be determined.
Response 2: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is single-pass.
Response 3: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is four-pass.
Response 4: The tube-side fluid flow pattern is two-pass.

Question: Which of the following provisions for thermal expansion for shell-and-tube heat exchangers only requires a single tube sheet located at one end?
Response 1: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring a floating tube sheet.
Response 2: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring U-tube type tubes.
Response 3: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring a packed tube sheet.
Response 4: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring bayonet type tubes.

Question: Which of the following provisions for thermal expansion for shell-and-tube heat exchangers has a tube arrangement featuring a "tube-within-a-tube"?
Response 1: A shell-and tube heat exchanger featuring a packed tube sheet.
Response 2: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring a floating tube sheet.
Response 3: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring bayonet type tubes.
Response 4: A shell-and-tube heat exchanger featuring U-tube type tubes.

Question: In a shell- and-tube heat exchanger which of the following tube types would be LEAST susceptible to tube-side fouling?
For a given shell diameter and tube sizes for a shell-and-tube heat exchanger which tube pitch pattern would be the most compact design allowing for the most tubes?
For a shell-and-tube heat exchanger which tube pitch pattern would feature "see-through" lanes and would most easily allow external mechanical cleaning of the tubes?
Concerning the baffles of a shell-and-tube heat exchanger what statement is true?
Response 1: The baffles are used to support the tubes guide flow and decrease the velocity of the fluid flowing through the shell.
Response 2: The baffles are used to support the tubes guide flow and increase the velocity of the fluid flowing through the tubes.
Response 3: The baffles are used to support the tubes guide flow and increase the velocity of the fluid flowing through the shell.
Response 4: The baffles are used to support the tubes guide flow and decrease the velocity of the fluid flowing through the tubes.

Question: For marine-type shell-and-tube heat exchangers what is the most common arrangement for baffles?
What prevents the two fluids in a plate type heat exchanger from coming into direct contact with each other and mixing?
Response 1: The chevrons and corrugations between the individual heat transfer plates.
Response 2: The metal-to-metal seal between the individual heat transfer plates.
Response 3: The metal-to-metal seal between the covers (pressure plates).
Response 4: The pipe to groove seals between the individual heat transfer plates.

Question: With regard to the flow patterns associated with plate type heat exchangers which flow pattern is able to achieve counter-flow on opposite sides of each heat exchange plate?
Response 1: The flow pattern where one fluid makes a single pass and the other makes multiple passes through the heat exchanger.
Response 2: The flow pattern where each fluid makes multiple passes through the heat exchanger.
Response 3: The flow pattern where each fluid makes a single pass through the heat exchanger.
Response 4: It is not possible for each heat exchanger plate to achieve counter flow on opposite sides.

Question: What is the most common arrangement for a compact heat exchanger such as that used on an air conditioning cooling coil located in a ventilation supply duct?
Response 1: Plate-fin set up as a serpentine plate.
Response 2: Finned-tube set up as a serpentine coil.
Response 3: Finned-tube set up as a spiral coil.
Response 4: Finned-tube set up as a helical coil.

Question: When placing a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with a removable tube bundle such as a bayonet- tube heavy fuel oil service heater into service to avoid thermal shock what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Introduce the heavy fuel oil and steam simultaneously establishing full flow of both fluids immediately to avoid thermal shock.
Response 2: Introduce both the heavy fuel oil and steam simultaneously and gradually to avoid thermal shock.
Response 3: Introduce the steam first then gradually introduce the heavy fuel oil until full flow is established to avoid thermal shock.
Response 4: Introduce the heavy fuel oil first then gradually introduce the steam until full flow is established to avoid thermal shock.

Question: When placing a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with a removable tube bundle such as a bayonet- tube heavy fuel oil service heater into service to prevent water hammer what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Crack open the condensate drains first. Gradually introduce the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer draining condensate and issuing dry steam. Finally introduce the heavy fuel oil.
Response 2: Introduce the heavy fuel oil first then crack open the condensate drains. Gradually introduce the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer issuing dry steam and draining condensate.
Response 3: Crack open the condensate drains first. Gradually introduce the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer issuing dry steam and draining condensate. Finally introduce the heavy fuel oil.
Response 4: Introduce the heavy fuel oil first then crack open the condensate drains. Gradually introduce the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer draining condensate and issuing dry steam.

Question: When taking a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with a removable tube bundle such as a bayonet-tube type heavy fuel oil service heater out of service to avoid thermal shock what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Secure both the steam and heavy fuel oil simultaneously and immediately to avoid thermal shock.
Response 2: Secure the heavy fuel oil first then gradually secure the steam to avoid thermal shock.
Response 3: Secure the steam and heavy fuel oil simultaneously and gradually to avoid thermal shock.
Response 4: Gradually secure the steam first then secure the heavy fuel oil to avoid thermal shock.

Question: When taking a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with a removable tube bundle such as a bayonet-tube heavy fuel oil service heater out of service to prevent water hammer what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Open wide the condensate drains first. Gradually close down and secure the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer issuing dry steam. Finally secure the heavy fuel oil.
Response 2: Secure the heavy fuel oil first then crack open the condensate drains. Gradually close down and secure the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer issuing dry steam.
Response 3: Crack open the condensate drains first. Gradually close down and secure the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer draining condensate. Finally secure the heavy fuel oil.
Response 4: Secure the heavy fuel oil first then crack open the condensate drains. Gradually close down and secure the steam then close the condensate drains when no longer draining condensate.

Question: When placing a shell-and-tube heat exchanger with a non-removable tube bundle such as a lube oil cooler with fixed tube sheets into service to avoid thermal shock what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Introduce the cooling water first then gradually introduce the lube oil until full flow is established to avoid thermal shock.
Response 2: Introduce the lubricating oil first then gradually introduce the cooling water until full flow is established to avoid thermal shock.
Response 3: Introduce both the cooling water and the lubricating oil simultaneously and gradually to avoid thermal shock.
Response 4: Introduce both the cooling water and the lubricating oil simultaneously establishing full flow of both fluids immediately to avoid thermal shock.

Question: When placing a shell-and-tube heat exchanger such as a jacket water cooler into service to insure optimal heat transfer what statement represents the correct operating procedure?
Response 1: Both the water box and shell vent valves should be opened to expel any entrapped air and then reclosed.
Response 2: Both the water box and shell drain valves should be opened to expel any entrapped air and then reclosed.
Response 3: Both the water box and shell vent valves should be opened to expel any entrapped sediment and then reclosed.
Response 4: Both the water box and shell drain valves should be opened to expel any entrapped sediment and then reclosed.

Question: When securing a seawater- cooled shell-and-tube heat exchanger for an extended period of time what statement represents the recommended operating procedure?
Response 1: The seawater side of the heat exchanger should be drained then flushed with freshwater and left completely filled with freshwater.
Response 2: The seawater side of the heat exchanger should be drained by opening the drain valves while insuring that the vent valves remain closed while draining.
Response 3: The seawater side of the heat exchanger should be left completely filled with seawater.
Response 4: The seawater side of the heat exchanger should be drained by opening the drain valves while insuring that the vent valves remain open while draining.

Question: When shifting heat exchangers such as main engine lube- oil coolers what statement represents the recommended operating procedure if the shift is to occur during engine operation?
Response 1: First secure cooling water to the off-going cooler then secure lube oil to the off-going cooler. Next introduce lube oil to the on-coming cooler then introduce cooling water to the on-coming cooler.
Response 2: First introduce lube oil to the on-coming cooler then introduce cooling water to the on-coming cooler. Next secure cooling water to the off-going cooler then secure lube oil to the off-going cooler.
Response 3: First introduce cooling water to the on-coming cooler then introduce lube oil to the on-coming cooler. Next secure lube oil to the off-going cooler then secure cooling water to the off-going cooler.
Response 4: First secure lube oil to the off-going cooler then secure cooling water to the off-going cooler. Next introduce cooling water to the on-coming cooler then introduce lube oil to the on-coming cooler.

Question: Suppose a diesel engine is fitted with seawater-cooled lube oil and jacket water coolers. What statement is true concerning the system operating pressures?
Response 1: The jacket water pressure is maintained lower than the sea water pressure in the jacket water cooler and the lube oil pressure is maintained higher than the sea water pressure in the lube oil cooler.
Response 2: The jacket water pressure is maintained lower than the sea water pressure in the jacket water cooler and the lube oil pressure is maintained lower than the sea water pressure in the lube oil cooler.
Response 3: The jacket water pressure is maintained higher than the sea water pressure in the jacket water cooler and the lube oil pressure is maintained lower than the sea water pressure in the lube oil cooler.
Response 4: The jacket water pressure is maintained higher than the sea water pressure in the jacket water cooler and the lube oil pressure is maintained higher than the sea water pressure in the lube oil cooler.

Question: What is the primary indication of fouling of a heat exchanger?
Response 1: A decreased pressure drop associated with the side where the fouling exists and a decreased temperature differential between the two fluids exchanging heat.
Response 2: A decreased pressure drop associated with the side where the fouling exists and an increased temperature differential between the two fluids exchanging heat.
Response 3: An increased pressure drop associated with the side where the fouling exists and a decreased temperature differential between the two fluids exchanging heat.
Response 4: An increased pressure drop associated with the side where the fouling exists and an increased temperature differential between the two fluids exchanging heat.

Question: For soft scale deposits on the inside of the tubes of a seawater-cooled shell-and-tube heat exchanger what is typically the preferred method of cleaning?
Response 1: Blowing out with compressed air or a steam lance.
Response 2: Mechanical cleaning with specially designed brushes and/or flushing with hot freshwater.
Response 4: Mechanical cleaning with specially designed reamers or cutting tools.

Question: For stubborn hard scale deposits on the inside of the tubes of a seawater-cooled shell-and-tube heat exchanger what is typically the preferred method of cleaning?
Response 1: Mechanical cleaning with specially designed brushes.
Response 3: Mechanical cleaning with specially designed reamers.

Question: For removal of sludge from in the inside of the shell of a fuel oil heater or lube oil cooler what is typically the preferred method of cleaning?
Response 2: Blowing out with compressed air or a steam lance.
Response 4: Mechanical cleaning with specially designed brushes.

Question: What would be the most likely indication that a plate type jacket water cooler had an internal leak permitting mixing of the two fluids?
Response 1: Rising level and overflowing of the jacket water expansion tank.
Response 2: Drop in concentration of corrosion inhibitor package of jacket water.
Response 3: Excessive scale build-up on the various cylinder jacket surfaces.
Response 4: Dropping level and frequent need to top off jacket water expansion tank.

Question: Which saltwater -cooled heat exchanger arrangement and location would be MOST problematic in terms of keeping the seawater side filled?
Response 1: Vertically arranged cooler located below the water line.
Response 2: Horizontally arranged cooler located above the water line.
Response 3: Horizontally arranged cooler located below the water line.
Response 4: Vertically arranged cooler located above the water line.

Question: Which saltwater-cooled heat exchanger arrangement and location would be the LEAST likely to become air-bound on the seawater side?
Response 1: Vertically arranged cooler located below the water line.
Response 2: Horizontally arranged cooler located above the water line.
Response 3: Vertically arranged cooler located above the water line.
Response 4: Horizontally arranged cooler located below the water line.

Question: How may a suspected tube leak on a shell-and-tube jacket water cooler most easily be located?
Response 1: Isolate drain and dry the salt water side of the heat exchanger. Remove the water box inspection plates. Visually inspect the tube sheets for signs of seepage at each of the tube ends.
Response 2: Isolate drain and dry the salt water side of the heat exchanger. Pressurize the seawater side with compressed air. Visually inspect the jacket water expansion tank for bubbles.
Response 3: Isolate drain and dry both the salt water and jacket water sides of the heat exchanger. Remove the water box inspection plates. Visually inspect the tube sheets for signs of seepage at each of the tube ends.
Response 4: Isolate drain and dry the jacket water side of the heat exchanger. Remove the shell inspection plates. Visually inspect the tubes along the tube lengths for seepage.

Question: What would be the most likely indication that a shell-and-tube lube oil cooler had in internal leak permitting mixing of the two fluids?
Response 1: Dropping level and frequent need to add make-up oil to engine sump.
Response 2: Corrosion of engine internal parts in contact with lube oil.
Response 3: Rising level in engine lube oil sump.
Response 4: Drop in viscosity of engine lube oil.

Question: Besides a visual inspection upon disassembly what method can be used to check for suspected leakage through a heat transfer plate of a plate type heat exchanger?
Response 1: One side of the plate is cleaned and coated with a water-seeking paste and the other side is sprayed with water.
Response 2: One side of the plate is cleaned and sprayed with a fluorescent dye penetrant and the other side is viewed with an infra-red heat source.
Response 3: One side of the plate is cleaned and sprayed with a fluorescent dye penetrant and the other side is viewed with an ultra-violet light.
Response 4: One side of the plate is cleaned and sprayed with a fluorescent dye penetrant and the other side is viewed with an ordinary flashlight.

Question: If a fluorescent dye penetrant and ultra-violet light are used for leak detection on a heat exchanger what would be the indication of a confirmed leak?
Response 1: A bright green glow at the site of leakage.
Response 2: A bright orange glow at the site of leakage.
Response 3: A bright purple glow at the site of leakage.
Response 4: A bright red glow at the site of leakage.

Question: What statement is true concerning the heat transfer rates through a heat exchanger boundary wall by conduction?
Response 1: Heat transfer rates are inversely proportional to the temperature gradient across the wall and directly proportional to the area of the wall and the wall thickness.
Response 2: Heat transfer rates are inversely proportional to the temperature gradient across the wall and the area of the wall and directly proportional to the wall thickness.
Response 3: Heat transfer rates are directly proportional to the temperature gradient across the wall and inversely proportional to the area of the wall and the wall thickness.
Response 4: Heat transfer rates are directly proportional to the temperature gradient across the wall and the area of the wall and inversely proportional to the wall thickness.

Question: The floating end of a shell-and-tube type cooler utilizes a packing ring to ______.
Response 1: prevent leakage past the floating end tube sheet
Response 2: modify to a mixer type cooler
Response 4: baffle cooling water so it can be directed on a multiple pass

Question: What is the main reason that live auxiliary steam is normally attemporated before entering the feed heater of a flash evaporator?
Response 1: To reduce the rate of scale formation on heating surfaces.
Response 2: To increase the brine overboard density.
Response 3: To increase the pressure in the heat exchanger.
Response 4: To increase the pressure in the first stage flash chamber.

Question: As a watchstander you should know that some auxiliaries are not designed to handle steam at boiler pressure. Which of the devices listed is usually fitted in the branch line to deliver steam at the correct pressure?
At a given pressure erosion of steam piping and machinery will be minimized by utilizing __________.
The auxiliary exhaust system shown in the illustration can be supplied by steam from the __________. See illustration SG-0024.
Which of the following systems can normally be supplied by auxiliary exhaust steam?
Identify the system shown in the illustration. See illustration SG-0005.
Which of the following systems is designed to use auxiliary exhaust steam?
Auxiliary exhaust steam can generally be used as a supply for the __________.
Which of the following systems can be supplied by the auxiliary exhaust system?
The primary objective of the auxiliary exhaust system is to supply steam to the __________.
In a steam propulsion plant the primary source of auxiliary exhaust steam is from the __________.
Identify the system shown in the illustration. See illustration SG-0024.
Which of the systems or components shown in the illustration are supplied by auxiliary exhaust steam? See illustration SG-0024.
The primary source of steam to the auxiliary exhaust system is typically supplied directly from __________.
Response 2: turbine driven and reciprocating steam pumps

Question: Which of the piping systems listed is shown in the illustration? See illustration SG-0005.
Which of the following statements is true concerning the piping system shown in the illustration? See illustration SG-0005.
Response 1: The boiler soot blowers operate with desuperheated steam.
Response 2: Air ejectors operate on 143 psi steam.
Response 3: The steam whistle operates on 140 psi steam.

Question: Auxiliary steam at full operating pressure is supplied from the boiler directly to the __________.
The Butterworth heater shown in the illustration receives steam at approximately __________. See illustration SG-0005.
The Butterworth heater (tank cleaning heater) shown in the illustration is designed to operate at a nominal steam pressure of approximately ________. See illustration SG-0005.
The turbo generator steam stop is located between the superheater outlet and the main steam stop valve to __________.
Response 2: provide higher quality steam for the turbo generators
Response 3: provide a flow of cooling steam through the control desuperheater
Response 4: allow the use of superheated steam in the turbo generator without pressurizing the larger main steam line

Question: The main steam stop valve on a "D" type marine boiler is located at the __________.
The main steam stop bypass valve is used to __________.
Response 1: isolate the main steam stop for repairs while steaming
Response 2: gradually increase the pressure and temperature of the main steam piping when warming up
Response 4: supply auxiliary steam when the main steam stop is closed

Question: When two or more boilers provide steam flow to a common main steam line each boiler main steam line shall be fitted with a main steam stop valve and a/an __________.
Which of the symbols shown in the illustration is used to identify a stop-check valve? See illustration SG-0014.
In the system illustrated the valves at point "A" are __________. See illustration SG-0005.

Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require that main steam piping must be hydrostatically tested at specified intervals. If the pipe insulation cannot be removed during this test the piping shall be tested at __________.
Response 1: 1 1/4 times the maximum allowable working pressure and the pressure maintained for 10 minutes
Response 2: 1 1/2 times the maximum allowable working pressure and the pressure maintained for 20 minutes
Response 3: operating pressure and temperature and the pressure maintained for 1 hour
Response 4: a pressure and temperature specified by a Coast Guard marine inspector

Question: The intermediate pressure bleed steam system shown in the illustration is used to supply steam at approximately __________. See illustration SG-0024.
In the system illustrated the valves at point "A" are ______. See illustration SG-0005.
High pressure and low pressure drain systems are part of the __________.
High pressure steam drains from systems operating at above 150 psi are normally collected in the __________.
Clean low pressure steam drains are collected in the __________.
From which of the areas listed are condensate drains normally collected and returned to the low pressure drain system?
Response 2: Each main feed pump steam supply line
Response 3: Steam systems operating in excess of 150 psi
Response 4: Main and auxiliary air ejector after condensers

Question: From which of the areas listed are condensate drains normally collected and returned to the atmospheric pressure drain system?
Response 2: Each main feed pump steam supply line
Response 3: Steam systems operating in excess of 150 psi
Response 4: Main and auxiliary air ejector after condensers

Question: The level in the atmospheric drain tank is normally maintained by the use of a/an __________.
Response 3: vacuum drag to the air ejector condenser

Question: The atmospheric drain tank (ADT) normally drains to the _______.
Response 3: main and/or auxiliary air ejector condenser

Question: The level in the atmospheric drain tank when underway at sea is normally maintained by the use of a/an __________.
Response 1: overflow to the bilge drain tank
Response 2: float-type regulator draining to the main condenser
Response 3: vacuum drag to the air ejector condenser

Question: High pressure steam drains are normally discharged to the __________.
Which of the drains listed could be led directly to a DC heater operating at 35 psig (343 kPa)?
Response 2: Contaminated evaporator relief valve drain only.
Response 4: Only those steam drains which operate at 35 psig (343 kPa) or less.

Question: Excessively hot water returning to an atmospheric drain tank indicates __________.
Response 1: the condensate recirculating valve is open
Response 2: there is a loss of circulating water
Response 3: a steam trap is hung open

Question: Excessively hot water returning to an atmospheric drain tank indicates __________.
Response 2: a steam trap is hung open
Response 3: there is a loss of circulating water
Response 4: the condensate recirculating valve is open

Question: Which of the listed systems would be a potential source for the high pressure drain system?
Response 4: Steam systems operating in excess of 150 psi

Question: Steam drains from the potable water system hot water heater would be collected in the __________.
The contaminated drain system normally receives drains that may be exposed to __________.
Response 4: water contamination due to boiler treatment

Question: Condensate return lines from tank heating coils are led to the __________.
Condensate from fuel oil heating coils return to the __________.
Steam drains from fuel oil heating coils can be returned to the condensate and feed water system __________.
Response 1: through a direct connection to the heating drain header
Response 2: through a vacuum drag line connection to the fuel heater
Response 3: after being collected in the drain inspection tank
Response 4: after first passing through the DC heater

Question: Which statement is true concerning drain inspection tanks?
Response 1: Inspection tanks collect all HP drains.
Response 2: Inspection tanks provide for a visual examination of condensate which could be oil contaminated.
Response 3: They are discharged to the condensate system just forward of the feed pump.
Response 4: They collect condensate from the cargo tank heating coils only.

Question: If live steam is supplied directly to the tank heating coils the collected drains in the 'clean' section of the contaminated drain inspection tank are removed directly to the __________.
If oil is observed in the steam drains from a fuel oil heater you should __________.
Response 1: increase the fuel oil pressure to the heater
Response 2: shift the drains to the atmospheric drain tank
Response 3: transfer operation to another heater and secure the original heater
Response 4: increase the steam pressure to that heater

Question: Why are the condensate drains from the fuel oil heaters and fuel oil tank heating coils returned to the drain inspection tank?
Response 1: To allow any oil to be separated from the steam.
Response 2: To detect and prevent oil from getting in the boiler water.
Response 3: As a safety precaution to prevent oil leaks from these coils.
Response 4: As a safety precaution to prevent oil leaks into the bilges.

Question: The primary function of the contaminated drain inspection tank is to __________.
Response 1: provide a source of make-up feed
Response 2: provide a means to preheat auxiliary condensate
Response 3: provide a means to cool down contaminated drains
Response 4: serve as a means for visually examining steam condensate drains which may contain oil

Question: Contaminated steam generators in a contaminated drain system are usually __________.
A contaminated steam generator is used to produce saturated vapor from collected __________.
The purpose of a contaminated steam system is to __________.
Response 2: ensure fouled heating coil returns from fuel tanks do not contaminate boiler feed water
Response 3: distill makeup feed for use as potable water
Response 4: ensure an uncontaminated source of feed for the makeup evaporator

Question: The contaminated steam system is secured for repairs. Live steam is supplied to the fuel oil heating system and its returns are directed to the drain tank. Considering these circumstances an undetected leak in an idle fuel oil heater could eventually lead to __________.
Response 4: sputtering burners and possible loss of fires

Question: Oil in the contaminated drain inspection tank results from __________.
Response 1: a defective relief valve on the fuel oil heater
Response 2: improper drainage of the fuel oil heater coils
Response 3: a leaking heating coil in a fuel oil settling tank
Response 4: operating the fuel oil heater at excessive temperatures

Question: Fuel oil may be discovered in the contaminated drain inspection tank when the __________.
Response 4: steam operated fuel oil pump leaks

Question: A leak in a heating coil in a fuel oil storage tank should be detected quickly by __________.
Response 1: an increase in fuel oil temperature
Response 2: observing oil on the contaminated evaporator steam coils
Response 3: the presence of fuel oil in the inspection tank
Response 4: the sputtering of burners in the boilers

Question: A leak in the heating coils of a fuel oil heater will first show up as __________.
Response 1: water in the fuel oil supply
Response 2: oil in the drain inspection tank

Question: A suspected leak in an operating fuel oil heating coil is normally confirmed by __________.
Response 1: checking the pH of heating coil returns

Question: The motor operated valve shown in the illustration is represented by item number __________. See illustration GS-0125.
In the diagram illustrated item "4" represents a __________. See illustration GS-0125.
Accidental flooding of the engine room bilges through the bilge system is prevented by __________.
Response 1: stop-check valves installed in the bilge suction manifolds
Response 2: using a positive displacement reciprocating bilge pump
Response 3: installing eductors in all bilge rose boxes
Response 4: installing a swing check before each bilge valve

Question: The shaded portion of the diagram shown in the illustration represents a __________. See illustration GS-0125.
In the diagram illustrated the direction of flow through the check valve is __________. See illustration GS-0125.
In the diagram shown in the illustration item "3" represents a __________. See illustration GS-0125.
The emergency bilge suction valve is typically used __________.
Response 1: to inject cleaning additives when the bilges are extremely dirty
Response 2: when the main condenser becomes fouled in order to provide additional cooling water circulation
Response 3: to connect the rose box to the independent bilge suction
Response 4: if the bilges become flooded and they can not be emptied by any other means

Question: The general service pump is to be used to remove clean water from the No. 4 port aft cargo hold and discharged through the ballast overboard. What are the minimum number of valves that must be opened on both the suction and discharge to accomplish this task? See illustration GS-0042.
What equipment is required when processing bilge slops for overboard discharge?
Response 2: A lube oil purifier operating as a separator.
Response 3: A 15 PPM oily water separator and discharge monitor.
Response 4: A 30 PPM oily water separator and discharge monitor.

Question: As routine maintenance the bilge manifold valves are periodically removed and examined. Prior to reassembling the valve bonnets the valve __________.
Response 1: disks and seats should be checked and lapped if necessary
Response 2: bonnet flange gaskets should be renewed if they were cut or torn
Response 3: stem packing should be renewed if the packing has hardened

Question: During routine maintenance the bilge manifold valves are removed. Prior to resecuring the valve bonnets the valve __________.
Response 1: disks and seats should be checked and lapped if necessary
Response 2: bonnet flange gaskets should be renewed if they were cut or torn
Response 3: stem packing should be renewed if the packing has hardened the glands have bottomed out or the glands cannot be tightened

Question: The aft starboard bilge well is clogged and back flushing has not been successful. The next practical solution would be to __________.
Response 1: change the trim of the ship to port in order to pump out the bilges for the remainder of the voyage
Response 2: place 20 gallons ( 75.7 L) of fuel oil tank wash into the affected bilge well to clear the blockage
Response 3: properly and safely empty the well with a portable pump then manually muck it out

Question: The aft starboard bilge-well can not be pumped out and back flushing has not been successful. The next practical solution will be to carry out which of the following actions?
Response 1: List the ship to port in order to pump out the bilges for the remainder of the voyage.
Response 2: Place 20 gals. (75.7 L) of fuel oil tank-wash into the affected bilge well for one hour to dissolve the stoppage.
Response 3: Take all necessary steps to properly and safely pump out the affected bilge well then manually 'muck' it out.
Response 4: Change over and use one of the two remaining bilge pumps to dewater the starboard bilge well.

Question: The bilge system is unable to pump out the aft starboard engine room bilge-well due to the bilge-well suction being fouled. With two feet of water over the top of the bilge-well which of the following actions should be carried out?
Response 1: Send the wiper into the bilge-well with a scoop and pail.
Response 2: Remove the effected bilge manifold valve and attempt to back flush the line.
Response 3: Simultaneously operate all available bilge pumps.
Response 4: Transfer half the contents of a drum of degreaser into the bilge well and pump out the bilge well with the system.

Question: If one of the bilge system manifold valves does not properly seat the __________.
Response 1: bilge well connected to that valve plus the second bilge well being pumped will be completely emptied
Response 2: bilge system will lose vacuum and prevent the other bilges from being pumped out
Response 3: bilge well aft connected to that valve will siphon its contents to the forward bilge wells

Question: If one of the bilge manifold valves is prevented from seating the __________.
Response 1: bilge-well connected to that valve plus the second bilge-well being pumped will be completely emptied
Response 2: bilge system will lose vacuum preventing other bilges from being pumped out
Response 3: aftermost bilge-wells connected to that valve will siphon their contents to the forward bilge-wells

Question: If a bilge pump is able to develop vacuum but is unable to sufficiently pump out the bilges you would check for all of the following EXCEPT __________.
Response 2: for leaks in the suction piping
Response 3: relief valve is not properly seated

Question: If a bilge pump is able to develop some vacuum but is unable to sufficiently pump out the bilges you would check for __________.
Response 3: a relief valve not properly seated

Question: Which of the following actions should be taken FIRST if a bilge well of a multiple suction bilge system is unable to be pumped out?
Response 1: Open the bilge pump for inspection.
Response 2: Remove each of the suction manifold valves.
Response 3: Remove only the suction manifold valve to the affected bilge well.
Response 4: Attempt to pump out another bilge well to determine if the entire system is affected.

Question: Referring to Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) what statement is true concerning an emergency bilge suction for a cargo vessel over 180 feet in length?
Response 1: It is required to use the main circulating water pump or if not suitable the largest available pump in the machinery space.
Response 2: It can use any pump in the machinery space other than that required for the bilge system but the pump capacity must exceed that of the required main bilge pump.
Response 3: It is required to use the largest available pump in the machinery space other than that required for the bilge system.
Response 4: No emergency bilge suction is required for cargo vessels over 180 feet in length.

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require the emergency bilge system to __________.
Response 1: be independent of the main bilge system
Response 2: be a part of the independent bilge system
Response 4: have a cross connection to the ballast system

Question: Bilge suction lines led through tanks without using a pipe tunnel must be __________.
Response 2: fitted with gate valves at the bilge manifolds
Response 3: coated with coal tar epoxy or similar corrosion resistant substance
Response 4: fitted so as to not allow for expansion

Question: An emergency bilge suction is required for __________.
Which of the following is the minimum internal diameter of the main bilge suction piping permitted by Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR Part 56) on a vessel over 150 gross tons?
Which of the following statements indicates compliance with Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR Part 56) concerning a vessel's bilge system?
Response 1: All bilge manifold suctions shall be capable of being locally controlled from above the floor plates.
Response 2: The system must be capable of operation under all practicable conditions after a casualty whether the vessel is upright or listed.
Response 3: Peak tanks chain lockers and decks over peak tanks may be drained by eductors ejectors or hand pumps.

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR Part 56) for bilge and ballast piping require that __________.
Response 1: all oil and water tanks be connected to the bilge system
Response 2: the bilge pumping system be operable under all practicable conditions
Response 3: peak tanks and chain lockers have separate electric pumps

Question: In the diagram items '2A and 2B' represent the overboard discharge valves of the ballast system illustrated. According to 46 CFR Part 56 which of the following statements is correct if the length between perpendiculars of a vessel is 500 feet and the through hull opening is eleven feet above the summer load line? See illustration GS-0125.
Response 1: Valve 2A must be positive closing in addition to the indicated automatic non-return valve feature.
Response 2: Valve 2B must be positive closing in addition to the indicated automatic non-return valve feature.
Response 3: Only one automatic non-return valve feature is required.
Response 4: Both valves are correct as required and indicated in the illustration.

Question: Which of the following statements is correct if the length of the vessel between perpendiculars is 500 feet and the through hull opening is five feet above the summer load line for the overboard discharge of the system illustrated? See illustration GS-0125.
Response 1: The inboard valve only need be positive closing in addition to being of the automatic non-return valve type.
Response 2: The outboard valve only need be positive closing in addition to being of the automatic non-return valve type.
Response 3: Only one shutoff valve is required.
Response 4: Two valves are required and each must be of the automatic non-return type.

Question: In the diagram items '2A and 2B' represent the overboard discharge valves of the ballast system illustrated. According to 46 CFR Part 56 which of the following statements is correct if the vessels length between perpendiculars is 500 feet and the through hull opening is four feet above the summer load line? See illustration GS-0125.
Response 1: Valve 2A must be positive closing in addition to the indicated automatic non-return valve feature.
Response 2: Valve 2B must be positive closing in addition to the indicated automatic non-return valve feature.
Response 3: Both valves must be positive closing in addition to the ability to provide the automatic non-return feature.
Response 4: Only one valve is required but must be positive closing and include the automatic non-return feature.

Question: To thoroughly pump out the bilges using a horizontally mounted centrifugal pump the __________.
Response 2: volute must impart a radial and rotary motion of the water
Response 3: suction side connection must guide the liquid to the lantern rings
Response 4: stuffing box should not be allowed any water leakage

Question: Which of the following statements describes one of the functions of the ballasting system?
Response 1: To permit flooding of any fuel oil storage tank on any class of ship.
Response 2: To use it as a secondary service system.
Response 3: To store reserve feed or potable water for extended cruises.
Response 4: To stabilize the ship by flooding certain designed tanks with seawater.

Question: A vessel over 100 gross tons in coastwise service is to deballast its fuel tanks to a facility while in port. This vessel must have a/an __________.
Response 1: deballasting pump which is independent of the ballasting pump
Response 2: stop-check valve located at the pump discharge
Response 3: oil and water separator to retain oily waste in a holding tank
Response 4: adapter or shore connection made in accordance with 33 CFR Part 155

Question: According to the Coast Guard Pollution Prevention Regulations (33 CFR) a 299 gross ton uninspected motor towing vessel not equipped with an oily water separator is required to have how many outlets accessible from the weather deck to discharge oily bilge slops?
An acceptable method of dealing with accumulated oil found in the pump room bilges is to __________.
Response 1: transfer the oil to the sea chest
Response 2: pump the oil into the slop tanks
Response 3: discharge the oil over the side on an outgoing tide
Response 4: pump the oil into a clean ballast tank

Question: A segregated ballast system is a system where __________.
Response 1: all ballast is processed through the oily water separator
Response 2: ballast is taken on and discharged through a separate main deck riser
Response 3: ballast and cargo tanks are separated by cofferdams
Response 4: all ballast lines tanks and pumps are independent of those used for oil

Question: The term "segregated ballast" is defined in the Pollution Prevention Regulations (33 CFR) as ballast water introduced into a/an __________.
Response 1: tank that is completely separated from the cargo oil and fuel oil systems
Response 2: fuel settling tank for segregation from lighter fluids
Response 4: isolated tank for analysis because of its noxious properties

Question: When two ballast pumps used for deballasting a single tank start cavitating you should __________.
Response 1: open all valves on the discharge side to permit improved flow
Response 2: close the valve on the discharge side of the pump to re-acquire suction
Response 3: close the valve on the suction side of the ballast pump to re-prime the pump

Question: Under what conditions is it permissible to pump machinery space bilges directly overboard without processing by an oily water separator?
Response 1: When the bilge water holding tank is full.
Response 2: When presented with a flooding emergency.
Response 3: When operating in international waters beyond the 200 mile limit.
Response 4: When by visual inspection the bilges appear to be free of oil.

Question: What is meant by the term independent bilge suction?
Response 1: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump not normally used as a bilge pump but using either bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 2: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump normally used as a bilge pump but independent of any bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 3: The means by which a cargo hold bilge is pumped out by a pump normally used as a bilge pump but independent of any bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 4: The means by which a cargo hold bilge is pumped out by a pump not normally used as a bilge pump but using either bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.

Question: What is meant by the term emergency bilge suction?
Response 1: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump not normally used as a bilge pump and drawing a suction on the bilge through either bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 2: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump not normally used as a bilge pump and drawing a suction directly on the bilge independent of any bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 3: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump normally used as a bilge pump and drawing a suction directly on the bilge independent of any bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.
Response 4: The means by which the machinery space bilge is pumped out by a pump normally used as a bilge pump and drawing a suction on the bilge through either bilge manifolds or automatic bilge suction valves.

Question: Which of the following ballasting operations performed in conjunction with off-loading cargo could be accomplished without the use of a ballast pump?
Response 1: Filling a salt water ballast tank located above the waterline.
Response 2: Draining a salt water ballast tank located above the waterline.
Response 3: Draining a salt water ballast tank located below the waterline.
Response 4: Filling a salt water ballast tank located below the waterline.

Question: Which of the following deballasting operations performed in conjunction with loading cargo could be accomplished without the use of a ballast pump?
Response 1: Draining a salt water ballast tank located above the waterline.
Response 2: Filling a salt water ballast tank located below the waterline.
Response 3: Filling a salt water ballast tank located above the waterline.
Response 4: Draining a salt water ballast tank located below the waterline.

Question: With regard to a ballast system associated with a dry cargo ship what is the primary purpose of the forepeak and aft peak tanks?
Response 1: Adjusting the overall draft of the vessel.
Response 2: Adjusting the trim of the vessel.
Response 3: Correcting a list condition on the vessel.
Response 4: Correcting a condition of hogging or sagging of the vessel.

Question: With regard to a ballast system associated with a dry cargo ship what is the primary purpose of the double-bottom ballast tanks?
Response 1: Adjusting the overall draft of the vessel or correcting a condition of list.
Response 2: Adjusting the trim of the vessel.
Response 3: Correcting a condition of sagging of the vessel.
Response 4: Correcting a condition of hogging of the vessel.

Question: With regard to ballast system operations associated with a dry cargo ship what is meant by the term "ballasting"?
Response 1: Ballasting is the operation associated with draining ballast tanks to compensate for loading cargo.
Response 2: Ballasting is the operation associated with re-distributing ballast water to correct for a condition of list.
Response 3: Ballasting is the operation associated with filling ballast tanks to compensate for off-loading cargo.
Response 4: Ballasting is the operation associated with re-distributing ballast water to correct for a condition of hogging or sagging.

Question: With regard to ballast system operations associated with a dry cargo ship what is meant by the term "deballasting"?
Response 1: Ballasting is the operation associated with re-distributing ballast water to correct for a condition of hogging or sagging.
Response 2: Ballasting is the operation associated with draining ballast tanks to compensate for loading cargo.
Response 3: Ballasting is the operation associated with filling ballast tanks to compensate for off-loading cargo.
Response 4: Ballasting is the operation associated with re-distributing ballast water to correct for a condition of list.

Question: With regards to a ballast system associated with an oil tanker what is meant by the term "segregated" ballast?
Response 1: Segregated ballast is dedicated clean ballast water introduced into tanks that are completely separate from engine room bilge systems.
Response 2: Segregated ballast is dedicated clean ballast water introduced into tanks that are completely separate from cargo or fuel oil systems.
Response 3: Segregated ballast is dedicated clean ballast water introduced into tanks that are completely separate from sea water circulating or fire main systems.
Response 4: Segregated ballast is dedicated clean ballast water introduced into tanks that are completely separate from clean bilge systems.

Question: Besides retention of ballast water onboard or use of approved onboard ballast water treatment equipment what is another acceptable means for a vessel to be in compliance with the ballast water management regulations?
Response 1: Perform a complete ballast water exchange in an area no less than 3 nautical miles from any shore prior to discharging ballast in U.S. waters.
Response 2: Perform a complete ballast water exchange in an area no less than 12 nautical miles from any shore prior to discharging ballast in U.S. waters.
Response 3: Perform a complete ballast water exchange in an area no less than 25 nautical miles from any shore prior to discharging ballast in U.S. waters.
Response 4: Perform a complete ballast water exchange in an area no less than 200 nautical miles from any shore prior to discharging ballast in U.S. waters.

Question: What is the primary reason why the ballast water management regulations exist as applicable to vessels equipped with ballast tanks operating in U.S. waters?
Response 1: Prevent invasion of non-indigenous foreign marine species into U.S. waters.
Response 2: Prevent oil pollution of environmentally sensitive areas within U.S. waters.
Response 3: Prevent changes in salinity or salt content of coastal U.S. waters.
Response 4: Prevent sedimentary deposits in ports and harbor areas of U.S. waters.

Question: A centrifugal bilge pump requires priming ______.
Response 1: primarily to lubricate the shaft seals
Response 2: due to the inability of this type of pump to lift water to cover the suction (eye) of the impeller
Response 3: in order to overcome the potential energy of water in the discharge line
Response 4: to initially unload the pump by having its head pressure equal to discharge pressure

Question: You are unable to pump out the aft starboard engine room bilge well that is fouled with one foot of water over the top of the bilge well what action should be carried out?
Response 1: Simultaneously operate all available bilge pumps.
Response 2: It is only necessary to transfer half the contents of a drum of degreaser into the bilge well.
Response 3: Send the wiper into the well with only a scoop and pail.
Response 4: Remove the bilge manifold valve and attempt to back flush the line.

Question: Referring to the illustrated steam plant seawater cooling system drawing which pump can be used to pump out the main machinery space bilge in a flooding emergency? (SP-SW-01)
Response 1: The two-speed main sea water circulating pump can be used for this purpose.
Response 2: The single-speed main sea water circulating pump can be used for this purpose.
Response 3: Any of the sea water service pumps can be used for this purpose.
Response 4: The auxiliary sea water circulating pump can be used for this purpose.

Question: What is the general arrangement for bilge wells in the machinery spaces?
Response 1: Generally a single bilge well is provided on the centerline forward since a vessel is typically trimmed by the bow.
Response 2: Generally a single bilge well is provided on the centerline aft since a vessel is typically trimmed by the stern.
Response 3: Generally a bilge wells are provided in the port and starboard aft corners since a vessel is typically trimmed by the stern and to facilitate pump when the ship has a list.
Response 4: Generally a bilge wells are provided in the port and starboard forward corners since a vessel is typically trimmed by the bow and to facilitate pump when the ship has a list.

Question: The bilge system has been performing well; however the aft starboard engine room bilge-well suddenly fails to be pumped out. Which of the following should be done first to determine the cause?
Response 1: Open the bilge pump for inspection.
Response 2: Attempt to pump out another bilge well to determine if the entire system is affected.
Response 3: Remove each of the manifold valves.
Response 4: Remove only the manifold valve to the affected bilge-well.

Question: If one of the bilge system manifold valves does not properly seat the ______.
Response 1: bilge well connected to that valve plus the second bilge well being pumped will be completely emptied
Response 2: bilge well aft connected to that valve will siphon its contents to the forward bilge wells
Response 3: bilge system will lose vacuum and prevent the other bilges from being pumped out

Question: In accordance with international MARPOL Annex I regulations and federal regulations under 33CFR Subchapter O for oceangoing ships of 400 gross tons and above but less than 10000 gross tons what is the required means for preventing pollution by oil as it pertains to handling bilge slops?
Response 1: The oceangoing ship of 400 gross tons and above but less than 10000 gross tons is required to be equipped with an approved 15 parts per million oily-water separator but it is NOT required to have a high oil-content bilge alarm or a means to automatically stop the oily-water discharge when the oil content exceeds 15 ppm.
Response 2: The oceangoing ship of 400 gross tons and above but less than 10000 gross tons is required to retain onboard all oily mixtures in a slops tank and it is required to be equipped to discharge these mixtures to a reception facility.
Response 3: The oceangoing ship of 400 gross tons and above but less than 10000 gross tons is EITHER required to retain onboard all oily mixtures either in the bilges or in a slops tank and required to be equipped to discharge these mixtures to a reception facility OR the ship is required to be equipped with an approved oily-water separator.
Response 4: The oceangoing ship of 400 gross tons and above but less than 10000 gross tons is required to be equipped with an approved 15 parts per million oily-water separator AND it is required to have a high oil-content bilge alarm and a means to automatically stop the oily-water discharge when the oil content exceeds 15 ppm.

Question: Bilges may be pumped ______.
Response 3: overboard through an oily water separator
Response 4: anytime in an emergency i.e. main engine lube oil failure

Question: The term "arrival ballast" refers to ______.
Response 3: any form of sea water ballast

Question: In order to prevent the unnecessary release of hydrocarbons to atmosphere when taking on departure ballast one method used is to ______.
Response 1: use blowers to purge the inert gas from tanks
Response 2: completely open the mast riser valve
Response 3: allow entering ballast to displace the inert gas to a tank where cargo is currently being discharged

Question: The components indicated as "7" and "8" as shown in the illustration are known as the __________. See illustration GS-0153.
Response 3: first stage oil separator and drip pan
Response 4: second stage oil separator and drip pan

Question: What device shown in the illustration is used to prevent excessive internal pressures within the unit during its operation? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: An automatic valve item #14 opens to prevent excessive pressure.
Response 2: A rupture disc item #16 ruptures causing the pressure to drop.
Response 3: Internal tank pressure overcomes the spring force in item #2 causing it to open.
Response 4: This device is never exposed to excessive internal pressures.

Question: Which of the items listed is used to prevent over pressurization in the device shown in the illustration? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 4: This device is never exposed to excessive internal pressures.

Question: Which of the valves listed is connected to the suction side of the pump used in conjunction with the device shown in the illustration? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 4: A valve is not required as the pump is directly attached to the bottom of the tank.

Question: Which of the listed conditions will occur if valve "14" of the unit shown in the illustration is secured while the unit is operating in the processing mode? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: The water in the bilges will continue to be discharged.
Response 2: The water in the bilges will rise until probe "6" activates the separator.
Response 3: The water in the bilges will rise until probe "6" causes the automatically operated valve "5" to open.
Response 4: The water in the bilges will continue to rise if no other pump is operated because the pump suction valve has been secured.

Question: The valve labeled "4" for the device shown in the illustration is the __________. See illustration GS-0153.
The valve labeled "5" in the device shown in the illustration is the __________. See illustration GS-0153.
The valve labeled 'V-4' for the illustrated device is the __________. See illustration GS-0113.
When the oily water separator shown in the illustration is in operation and processing clear bilge water what should be the internal water level? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: The water level should be located in the upper section of the tank.
Response 2: The water level should be located in the lower section of the tank as controlled by flow control valve "14".
Response 3: The water level in the tank should be slightly above the upper coalescer bed "9".
Response 4: No water level is maintained in the tank.

Question: When operating the oily-water separator shown in the illustration why is it necessary to avoid detergents mixing with the bilge water? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: The detergent will agitate within the separator and cause it to explode.
Response 2: The detergent will damage the special protective coating in the inside of the unit.
Response 3: The detergents may cause the oil and water to become an emulsion which this unit is not capable of separating.
Response 4: The detergent will foam causing the main bilge pump to become air bound.

Question: You are observing the operation of the oily-water separator shown in the illustration. Item "1" initially indicates a vacuum and a moment later indicates a positive pressure. Which of the following statements describes what has occurred? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: The unit has just begun the oily-water mixture processing mode.
Response 2: The unit has just begun the oil discharge mode.
Response 3: The unit is obviously flooded and needs to be drained to the proper operating level.
Response 4: The unit is operating incorrectly and must be secured immediately.

Question: Regarding the oily water separator shown in the illustration what mode of operation is occurring if item "1" indicates a positive pressure? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: The unit is operating in the processing mode and is currently separating emulsified bilge water.
Response 2: The unit is operating in the bilge water removal mode separating the oil from the water as it flows through the unit.
Response 3: The unit is operating in the purge mode and is only removing air from the upper level of the tank.
Response 4: The unit is operating in the back flush mode causing any oil or air to be discharged to the oil slop tank.

Question: The function of item "7" shown in the illustration is to __________. See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: direct the flow of the oily-water mixture against the coalescer bed
Response 3: allow the oil accumulated to exit the device while remaining separated from the liquid
Response 4: prevent separated oil from mixing with the incoming bilge water

Question: The unit shown in the illustration is known as a/an __________. See illustration GS-0153.
The illustrated system is used as a/an __________. See illustration GS-0113.
The illustrated system is used to __________. See illustration GS-0113.
Response 1: process sludge found on motor vessels
Response 2: process sludge found on steam vessels

Question: What is the normal direction of flow through the device shown in the illustration while operating in the processing mode? See illustration GS-0153.

Question: Which of the valves listed for the device shown in illustration will be open while the unit is operating in the back flush mode? See illustration GS-0153.

In the illustration shown which of the listed components would be removed or disconnected last during cleaning and inspection of the tank internals? See illustration GS-0153.

Question: Regarding the device shown in the illustration what would be the most probable cause if item "1" indicated an unusually high vacuum while the oily water separator was operating in the processing mode? See illustration GS-0153.

Question: While the illustrated oily-water separator is operating in the processing mode if item "1" indicates higher than normal absolute pressure what is the probable cause? See illustration GS-0153.

Question: What will cause the throughput of the oily-water separator shown in the illustration to decrease when operating in the processing mode? See illustration GS-0153.

Response 4: The throughput of the separator varies while in the processing mode as determined by the quantity of oil in the emulsion.

Question: What will cause the throughput of the oily-water separator shown in the illustration to decrease when operating in the processing mode? See illustration GS-0113.

Question: Under what conditions would the oily-water separator shown in the illustration fail to effectively process a mixture of oily-water? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: When the oily-water mixture is an emulsion the effectiveness of the separator is greatly reduced.
Response 2: Without detergents the effectiveness of the separator is greatly reduced.
Response 3: When there are small air leaks in the discharge piping the effectiveness of the separator will greatly reduced.
Response 4: When the oily-water separator is in the process mode it will effectively handle emulsions.

Question: Under what conditions would the oily-water separator system illustrated fail to effectively process a mixture of oily-water? See illustration GS-0113.
Response 1: When the oily-water mixture is an emulsion the effectiveness of the separator is greatly reduced.
Response 2: Without detergents the effectiveness of the separator is greatly reduced.
Response 3: When there are small air leaks in the discharge piping the effectiveness of the separator will greatly reduced.
Response 4: When the oily-water separator is in the process mode it will effectively handle emulsions.

Question: If valve 'V2A' in the illustration does not open when the oily-water separator shifts into the oil discharge mode which of the following statements describes what would occur? See illustration GS-0113.
Response 1: Back flush water would cause the oil accumulated in the upper section of the tank to be forced back into the bilge spaces.
Response 2: The separator operation would stall as a result of oil remaining on the longer probe of item "S".

Question: On U.S. inspected ships oily water separating equipment bilge alarms and bilge monitors must be approved under __________.
