Response 1: slowly operating the bilge pump at half capacity so that it never completely dewaters the bilges
Response 2: circulating them through the lube oil purifier to remove water and debris
Response 3: holding its slops onboard until they can be discharged to a shore side reception facility
Response 4: pumping them into a settling tank for separation before pumping the oily water residue overboard

Question: An oceangoing ship of 350 gross tons constructed in January 1976 and not equipped with an oily water separator may retain all bilge slops __________.
In controlling pollution which action should be taken after all dirty ballast has been transferred to the slop tank and prior to discharge through the oily water separator?
Response 1: The clean tanks should be ballasted.
Response 2: The slops should be allowed time to settle.
Response 3: Chemicals should be added to emulsify the oil.
Response 4: The dirty ballast tank is crude oil washed.

Question: The function of item "7" shown in the illustration is to ______. See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: direct the flow of the oily-water mixture against the coalescer bed
Response 3: prevent separated oil from mixing with the incoming bilge water
Response 4: allow the oil accumulated to exit the device while remaining separated from the liquid

Question: The line labeled "C" as shown in the illustration would be identified as the ______. See illustration GS-0175.
The line labeled "G" as shown in the illustration would be identified as the ______. See illustration GS-0175.
What is an engine room bilge oily-water separator designed to do?
Response 1: Remove small amounts of oil from large amounts of water.
Response 2: Remove small amounts of oil from small amounts of water.
Response 3: Remove small amounts of water from large amounts of oil.
Response 4: Remove small amounts of oil from small amounts of water.

Question: What type of fuel oil as part of an oily-water mixture is most likely to have a density approaching that of water?
What statement is true concerning the effect of elevating the temperature of the oily-water mixture associated with an oily-water separator?
Response 1: Heating the oily-water mixture decreases the viscosity of the oil and decreases the specific gravity differential between the oil and water.
Response 2: Heating the oily-water mixture increases the viscosity of the oil and decreases the specific gravity differential between the oil and water.
Response 3: Heating the oily-water mixture decreases the viscosity of the oil and increases the specific gravity differential between the oil and water.
Response 4: Heating the oily-water mixture increases the viscosity of the oil and increases the specific gravity differential between the oil and water.

Question: What statement is true concerning the polishing coalescer filter of an oily-water separator?
Response 1: The coalescing filter is typically a hydrophilic filter meaning that small droplets of entrained water of the oily-water mixture coalesce on the filter and form large globules of water that sink to the bottom of the filter housing.
Response 2: The coalescing filter is typically an oleophilic filter meaning that small droplets of entrained oil of the oily-water mixture coalesce on the filter and form large globules of oil that sink to the bottom of the filter housing.
Response 3: The coalescing filter is typically a hydrophilic filter meaning that small droplets of entrained water of the oily-water mixture coalesce on the filter and form large globules of water that rise to the top of the filter housing.
Response 4: The coalescing filter is typically an oleophilic filter meaning that small droplets of entrained oil of the oily-water mixture coalesce on the filter and form large globules of oil that rise to the top of the filter housing.

Question: Referring to the illustration note that the solenoid in line "C" is closed. The check valve in line "E" is open. The separator service pump is running. The check valve in line "G" is closed. Valve "B" is closed. Valve "D" is open. What is the operational status of the oily-water separator unit? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The oily-water separator is in the bilge water separation processing mode with water discharging back to the bilge water holding tank with an oil content less than 15 ppm.
Response 2: The oily-water separator is in the bilge water separation processing mode with water discharging overboard with an oil content less than 15 ppm.
Response 3: The oily-water separator is in the bilge water separation processing mode with water discharging back to the bilge water holding tank with an oil content greater than 15 ppm.
Response 4: The oily-water separator is in the bilge water separation processing mode with water discharging overboard with an oil content greater than 15 ppm.

Question: Referring to the illustration suppose after initiating the oil discharge mode the oily - water separator fails to come out of the oil discharge mode in a timely fashion. Cracking open the upper sampling valve reveals the presence of water exiting under a positive pressure. What is most likely the cause? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The lower oil/water interface detection probe fails to initiate the oil discharge mode.
Response 2: The clean water supply solenoid fails to open and as a result provides no discharge pressure.
Response 3: The oil discharge check valve fails to open and as a result no oil actually discharges.
Response 4: The upper oil/water interface detection probe fails to end the oil discharge mode.

Question: Referring to the illustration what would be the result if the lower oil/water interface detection probe became faulty? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The unit would not be able to transition from ending the oil discharge mode to initiating the separation processing mode.
Response 2: The unit would not be able to transition from the overboard discharge mode to the re-circulation mode while in the separation processing mode.
Response 3: The unit would not be able to transition from ending the separation processing mode to initiating the oil discharge mode.
Response 4: The unit would not be able to come out of the oily-water separator idle mode and begin processing bilge water.

Question: If item "1" in the illustrated oily water separator indicates an abnormally deep vacuum which of the following conditions is the most probable cause? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 1: Process water inlet valve item "5" is open.
Response 2: Suction line inlet strainer is obstructed.
Response 3: No problem exists as a high vacuum should be maintained in the chamber whose vacuum is to be measured.

Question: In order to facilitate separation of oil from an oily -water mixture in an oily-water separator what statement is true concerning the flow pattern of the oily-water?
Response 1: Ideally the flow of the oily-water should be low in flow rate and high in turbulence.
Response 2: Ideally the flow of the oily-water should be high in flow rate and high in turbulence.
Response 3: Ideally the flow of the oily-water should be low in flow rate and low in turbulence.
Response 4: Ideally the flow of the oily-water should be high in flow rate and low in turbulence.

Question: What type of oil as part of an oily-water mixture is most likely to require heating to facilitate separation in an oily-water separator?
What statement is true with regard to the basic operating principle of gravity associated with an oily-water separator?
Response 1: The density of oil is less than that of water and as a result the oil droplets in an oily-water mixture will tend to rise.
Response 2: The density of oil is greater than that of water and as a result the oil droplets in an oily-water mixture will tend to sink.
Response 3: The density of oil is greater than that of water and as a result the oil droplets in an oily-water mixture will tend to rise.
Response 4: The density of oil is less than that of water and as a result the oil droplets in an oily-water mixture will tend to sink.

Question: If an oily-water separator uses an inclined plate pack to facilitate separation what statement concerning the plate pack is true?
Response 1: The oil droplets collect on the underside of the plates and rise when they have reached the outer edge of the plate pack. Solid particles collect on the upper side of the plates and sink when they have reached the inner edge of the plate pack.
Response 2: The oil droplets collect on the upper side of the plates and sink when they have reached the outer edge of the plate pack. Solid particles collect on the underside of the plates and rise when they have reached the inner edge of the plate pack.
Response 3: The oil droplets collect on the upper side of the plates and rise when they have reached the outer edge of the plate pack. Solid particles collect on the underside of the plates and sink when they have reached the inner edge of the plate pack.
Response 4: The oil droplets collect on the underside of the plates and sink when they have reached the outer edge of the plate pack. Solid particles collect on the upper side of the plates and rise when they have reached the inner edge of the plate pack.

Question: Referring to the illustration note that the solenoid in line "C" is closed. The check valve in line "E" is open. The separator service pump is running. The check valve in line "G" is closed. Valve "B" is open. Valve "D" is closed. What is the operational status of the oily-water separator unit? See illustration GS-0175.

Response 4: The oily-water separator is in the bilge water separation processing mode with water discharging back to the bilge water holding tank with an oil content less than 15 ppm.

Question: Referring to the illustration an oil-water separator is in the re-circulation mode due to high oil content of the processed water outlet. What action may be required before the unit is capable of discharging overboard once again? See illustration GS-0175.

Question: Referring to the illustration what would be the result if the upper oil/water interface detection probe became faulty? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The unit would not be able to transition from ending the separation processing mode to initiating the oil discharge mode.
Response 2: The unit would not be able to transition from the overboard discharge mode to the re-circulation mode while in the separation processing mode.
Response 3: The unit would not be able to transition from ending the oil discharge mode to initiating the separation processing mode.
Response 4: The unit would not be able to come out of the oily-water separator idle mode and begin processing bilge water.

Question: If item "1" in the illustrated oily water separator indicates an abnormally deep vacuum which of the following conditions is the most probable cause? See illustration GS-0153.
Response 2: Suction line inlet strainer is obstructed.
Response 3: Process water inlet valve item "5" is open.
Response 4: No problem exists as a high vacuum should be maintained in the chamber whose vacuum is to be measured.

Question: Referring to the illustration suppose the oily-water separator vessel compound gauge is showing an unusually deep vacuum for operating in the separation processing mode with the separator service pump running. The oil content is 8.3 ppm. What is most likely the cause? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The oily-water separator bilge suction strainer is clogged.
Response 2: The oily-water separator vessel relief valve is leaking.
Response 3: The oily-water separator service pump is worn.
Response 4: The bilge water holding tank level is unusually high resulting in a high level alarm.

Question: Referring to the illustration suppose after initiating the oil discharge mode the oily - water separator fails to come out of the oil discharge mode in a timely fashion. Cracking open the upper sampling valve reveals the presence of oil exiting under positive pressure. What is most likely the cause? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The clean water supply solenoid fails to open and as a result provides no discharge pressure.
Response 2: The oil discharge check valve fails to open and as a result no oil actually discharges.
Response 3: The lower oil/water interface detection probe fails to initiate the oil discharge mode.
Response 4: The upper oil/water interface detection probe fails to end the oil discharge mode.

Question: Referring to the illustration suppose while in the oil separation processing mode the oil content detector display screen shows 17.9 ppm and the oily-water separator is discharging back to the bilge water holding tank for re-circulation. What is most likely the cause? See illustration GS-0175.
Response 1: The bilge water holding tank contents is excessively contaminated with oil.
Response 2: The oily-water separator bilge suction strainer is excessively clogged.
Response 3: The oily-water separator service pump is excessively worn.
Response 4: The bilge water holding tank level is excessively high resulting in a high level alarm.

Question: A pneumatic pressure tank is installed in a sanitary system to __________.
Response 1: reduce excessive cycling of the sanitary pump
Response 2: prevent the sanitary pump from losing suction
Response 3: provide a higher pressure in the system then the pump can deliver
Response 4: increase water flow through the system

Question: The process of grinding shredding or reducing the size of sewage particles is known as __________.
In sewage treatment the term 'maceration' refers to the process of __________.
Response 1: breaking up solid matter into fine particles
Response 2: precipitating non-decomposed waste in a collection tank
Response 3: chemically adjusting the sewage pH to 7.0
Response 4: eliminating bacterium coli from the sewage

Question: The process of grinding or shredding sewage into smaller particles is known as __________.
Coast Guard regulations concerning marine sanitation devices may be found in __________.
A vessel is in compliance with federal regulations regarding the discharge of sewage by __________.
Response 2: treating sewage in an approved system
Response 3: pumping the sewage ashore to an approved container

Question: Marine sanitation devices installed on vessels must be certified by the __________.
Response 3: Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers

Question: Sewage treatment systems aboard U.S. inspected vessels must be approved by the __________.
Which type of Marine Sanitation Device (MSD) is used solely for the storage of sewage and flush water at ambient air pressure and temperature?

According to Coast Guard Regulations (33 CFR Part 159) which of the listed types of Marine Sanitation Devices (MSD) is designed to hold sewage on board in special tanks to be pumped out at shore side facilities when available.
Prior to entering a shipboard compartment containing spilled sewage you should test the atmosphere in the compartment for __________.
Which of the following sewage handling technologies would be associated with maintaining a culture of aerobic bacteria?
By what means is biological sewage treatment plant effluent disinfected before discharge overboard?
Response 1: Disinfection is not required on biological sewage treatment plants.
Response 2: Ultraviolet light irradiation is the only approved means of disinfection.
Response 3: Hypochlorite tablets or liquid solution and ultraviolet irradiation are both approved means of disinfection.
Response 4: Hypochlorite tablets or liquid solution is the only approved means of disinfection.

Question: Besides promoting mixing of the bacterial population with the fecal waste material what is the purpose of aeration system as used in a biological sewage treatment plant?
Response 1: The air provides an oxygen source for the aerobic bacteria required for metabolism and it helps promote settling in the aeration chamber.
Response 2: The air provides an oxygen source for the anaerobic bacteria required for metabolism and it helps promote settling in the aeration chamber.
Response 3: The air provides an oxygen source for the anaerobic bacteria required for metabolism and it helps prevent settling in the aeration chamber.
Response 4: The air provides an oxygen source for the aerobic bacteria required for metabolism and it helps prevent settling in the aeration chamber.

Question: The flame screens installed on sewage system tank vents prevent explosions by ______.
Response 1: allowing the escape of flammable vapors
Response 2: dissipating the heat of a flame
Response 3: absorbing any flammable vapors in the vicinity
Response 4: preventing flammable vapors from entering the tank

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O what is the definition of the term "sewage"?
Response 1: Victual or food wastes collected from galley sinks.
Response 2: Various deck drains situated within the vessel's superstructure.
Response 3: Human body wastes and the wastes from toilets and other receptacles intended to receive or retain body waste.
Response 4: Drains collected from sinks and showers from the various heads onboard ship.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O what is the definition of a "Type I Marine Sanitation Device"?
Response 1: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and suspended solids not greater than 150 milligrams per liter.
Response 2: A device that is designed to prevent the overboard discharge of treated or untreated sewage or any waste derived from sewage.
Response 3: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 1000 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 4: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O what is the definition of a "Type II Marine Sanitation Device"?
Response 1: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 1000 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 2: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 3: A device that is designed to prevent the overboard discharge of treated or untreated sewage or any waste derived from sewage.
Response 4: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and suspended solids not greater than 150 milligrams per liter.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O what is the definition of a "Type III Marine Sanitation Device"?
Response 1: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 2: A device that is designed to prevent the overboard discharge of treated or untreated sewage or any waste derived from sewage.
Response 3: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and suspended solids not greater than 150 milligrams per liter.
Response 4: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 1000 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O if a vessel equipped with a Type III Marine Sanitation Device enters a body of water where the discharge of untreated sewage is prohibited which of the following methods of securing the device to prevent the discharge of sewage is UNACCEPTABLE?
Response 1: Using a non-releasable wire-tire to hold each valve leading to an overboard discharge in the closed position.
Response 2: Closing each valve leading to an overboard discharge and removing the handle.
Response 3: Closing and tagging each valve leading to an overboard discharge.
Response 4: Padlocking each valve leading to an overboard discharge in the closed position.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O if a vessel equipped with a Type II Marine Sanitation Device enters a body of water where the discharge of treated or untreated sewage is prohibited which of the following methods of securing the device to prevent the discharge of sewage is ACCEPTABLE if it is impractical to close the seacock and prevent its opening?
Response 1: Making an announcement over the public address system advising all concerned that the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".
Response 2: Placing a warning sign on the door to the space enclosing the toilets advising all concerned that the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".
Response 3: Locking the door to the space enclosing the toilets with a padlock or door handle key lock to prevent entry when the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".
Response 4: Placing of tape forming an "X" over toilet and urinal bowls to convey to all concerned that the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".

Question: Under the international MARPOL regulations under Annex IV if the ship is less than 3 nautical miles from the nearest land what statement is true?
Response 1: The discharge of comminuted sewage is prohibited but the discharge of disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 2: The discharge of comminuted and disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 3: The discharge of disinfected sewage is prohibited but the discharge of comminuted sewage is permitted.
Response 4: The discharge of any sewage treated or untreated is prohibited.

Question: Under the international MARPOL regulations under Annex IV if the ship is more than 3 but less than 12 nautical miles from the nearest land what statement is true?
Response 1: The discharge of comminuted and disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 2: The discharge of disinfected sewage is prohibited but the discharge of comminuted sewage is permitted.
Response 3: The discharge of comminuted sewage is prohibited but the discharge of disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 4: The discharge of any sewage treated or untreated is prohibited.

Question: Under the international MARPOL regulations under Annex IV if the ship is more than 12 nautical miles from the nearest land what statement is true?
Response 1: The discharge of comminuted and disinfected sewage is prohibited.
Response 2: The discharge of any sewage treated or untreated is permitted.
Response 3: The discharge of comminuted sewage is prohibited but the discharge of disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 4: The discharge of disinfected sewage is prohibited but the discharge of comminuted sewage is permitted.

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O if a vessel equipped with a Type II Marine Sanitation Device enters a body of water where the discharge of treated or untreated sewage is prohibited which of the following methods of securing the device to prevent the discharge of sewage is ACCEPTABLE if it is impractical to close the seacock and prevent its opening?
Response 1: Placing a warning sign on the door to the space enclosing the toilets advising all concerned that the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".

Response 4: Locking the door to the space enclosing the toilets with a padlock or door handle key lock to prevent entry when the vessel is entering a "no discharge zone".

Question: Under the federal regulations of 33CFR Subchapter O what is the definition of a "Type III Marine Sanitation Device"?
Response 1: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 1000 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 2: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and no visible floating solids.
Response 3: A device that is designed to prevent the overboard discharge of treated or untreated sewage or any waste derived from sewage.
Response 4: A device that produces a fecal coliform bacteria count not greater than 200 per 100 milliliters and suspended solids not greater than 150 milligrams per liter.

Question: Under the international MARPOL regulations under Annex IV if the ship is more than 3 but less than 12 nautical miles from the nearest land what statement is true?
Response 1: The discharge of comminuted sewage is prohibited but the discharge of disinfected sewage is permitted.
Response 2: The discharge of any sewage treated or untreated is prohibited.
Response 3: The discharge of comminuted and disinfected sewage is permitted.

Question: Short cycling of the potable water system's pump is prevented by using __________.
Short cycling of the potable water pump is avoided by the proper use of a __________.
Response 1: hydro-pneumatic tank completely filled with compressed air at system operating pressure
Response 3: charge of air at 20 psi (137.9 kPa) above system pressure with the hydro-pneumatic tank one quarter full of water
Response 4: charge of air at system pressure when the hydro-pneumatic tank is half full of water

Question: A constant pressure range is maintained in the potable water system of many vessels by using __________.
Response 3: an air cushion in a hydro-pneumatic surge tank
Response 4: a pressure regulator in the pump suction piping

Question: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause water hammer in the potable water system shown in the illustration? See illustration GS-0173.
Response 1: The hydro-pneumatic tank being half full of water
Response 2: Loss of air in the hydro-pneumatic tank.
Response 3: A low water level in the potable water storage tank.

Question: According to the illustration which of the following conditions would most likely cause Pump "A" to short cycle? See illustration GS-0173.
Response 1: The hydro-pneumatic expansion tank is operating with an insufficient air charge.
Response 2: The hydro-pneumatic tank is operating with a low water level.
Response 3: A low water level exists in the potable water storage tank.
Response 4: Pump "A" wearing rings have excessive clearance.

Question: A recirculating line is provided in the potable hot water system to __________.
Response 1: maintain uniform inlet conditions for the pressure tanks
Response 2: maintain flow rates which will eliminate fluid film formation in the piping
Response 3: return overflow from the pressure tanks back to the potable water tanks
Response 4: maintain the desired temperature range throughout the system

Question: Which of the listed chemicals can be routinely used to maintain the hygienic quality of potable water?
Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause water hammer in the potable water system?
Response 1: The hydro-pneumatic tank being half full of water
Response 2: The starting of the potable water pump.
Response 3: A low water level in the potable water storage tank.
Response 4: Rapid closing of a spring closed basin faucet.

Question: Potable water piping systems installed aboard ships must be __________.
Response 1: disinfected monthly with a chlorine compound
Response 2: independent of all other piping systems
Response 3: cadmium lined to prevent internal corrosion
Response 4: flushed each time potable water is taken onboard

Question: Potable and non-potable water systems aboard ship __________.
Response 1: may be temporarily connected with a removable spool
Response 2: are permanently connected through a double stop valve
Response 3: may never be cross-connected by any means
Response 4: may be connected if they are used only for wash water

Question: Potable and non-potable water systems aboard vessels __________.
Response 1: may be temporarily interconnected with a removable spool
Response 2: are permanently interconnected through a double stop valve
Response 3: may never be interconnected by any means
Response 4: may be connected if they are used only for wash water

Question: According to Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) fresh water tank vents the may terminate below the deep load water line in the machinery space under what condition?
Response 1: vents are fitted with suitable mechanical closures
Response 2: tanks have no boundaries in common with the hull
Response 3: vents are fitted with ball float check valves or an equivalent automatic closure device
Response 4: tanks are fitted with suitable pressure-vacuum relief valves

Question: In addition to one safety pressure relief valve Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require that a small electrically heated hot water supply boiler must be fitted with what other protective device?
Response 1: a temperature relief valve set for not more than 125 Fahrenheit
Response 2: a temperature relief valve or a combined pressure-temperature relief valve set for not more than 125 Fahrenheit
Response 3: a temperature relief valve or a combined pressure-temperature relief valve set for not more than 210 Fahrenheit
Response 4: an audible high water temperature alarm set for not more than 210 Fahrenheit

Question: According to Coast Guard regulations (46 CFR) for electric storage tank-type hot water heaters what statement is true concerning independent temperature limiting devices?
Response 1: they must prevent the water in the upper 25% of the tank from attaining a temperature higher than 99C (210F)
Response 2: they are automatically reset when the temperature drops below 90C (194F)
Response 3: they open a secondary power supply to the heater elements only
Response 4: they prevent the water from attaining a temperature of more than 90 (194F)

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require small electric storage tank-type hot water boilers rated at no more than 600 volts must be fitted with a temperature limiting device to prevent the water in the upper 25% of the tank from attaining a temperature higher than __________.
Distilled water from an evaporator is normally discharged into a potable water tank __________.
Response 2: after first passing through an activated charcoal filter
Response 3: after chemical analysis shows it is fit for consumption
Response 4: after passing through a solenoid operated dump valve energized by an alarm monitor

Question: In a shipboard potable water system which of the following symptoms would indicate that the hot water circulating pump had failed?
Response 1: The hot water return manifold would be warmer than normal.
Response 2: The average temperature of the hot water heater would be above normal.
Response 3: The water faucets would operate at a lower pressure.
Response 4: Below normal water temperature would be discharged for a long period before hot water would appear at the hot water faucets.

Question: A standard procedure for the emergency disinfection of water in a potable water tank is to add a small amount of standard laundry liquid chlorine bleach to the water tank. Approximately how much bleach would be considered appropriate to add to a tank containing 1000 gallons of water?
What is used to prevent contamination of a potable water system supplying a plumbing fixture such as a galley sink from a backup of sewage sanitary drains?
Response 1: Location of the potable water spigots below the rim of the galley sink.
Response 2: Location of the potable water spigots above the rim of the galley sink.
Response 3: A "P" trap in the drain line draining sewage waste from the galley sink.
Response 4: Check valves in the potable water supply lines delivering water to the galley sink.

Question: Suppose the pressure switch used to control the "lead" potable water pump is set at 45 psig cut-in for pump start and 55 psig cut-out for pump stop. What would be an appropriate setting for the "lag" potable water pump?
Response 1: 40 psig cut-in for pump start and 55 psig cut-out for pump stop.
Response 2: 45 psig cut-in for pump start and 50 psig cut-out for pump stop.
Response 3: 45 psig cut-in for pump start and 60 psig cut-out for pump stop.
Response 4: 50 psig cut-in for pump start and 60 psig cut-out for pump stop.

Question: What type of disinfection system has the disadvantage that it would fail to provide residual disinfectant in the potable water?
Response 1: A chlorinator located at the potable water storage tank recirculation line.
Response 2: A brominator located at the desalinator discharge piping to the potable water storage tank.
Response 3: An ultraviolet irradiator at the desalinator discharge to the potable water storage tank.
Response 4: A chlorinator located at the desalinator discharge piping to the potable water storage tank.

Question: Which of the following desalination plants will always require a sterilizer when providing water to a potable water system?
Which of the following statements concerning the arrangements of a potable water system is true?
Response 1: Potable water pumps of the positive displacement type require a vacuum-priming system if located above the potable water storage tanks.
Response 2: Potable water pumps of the non-positive displacement type require a vacuum-priming system if located below the potable water storage tanks.
Response 3: Potable water pumps of the non-positive displacement type require a vacuum-priming system if located above the potable water storage tanks.
Response 4: Potable water pumps of the positive displacement type require a vacuum-priming system if located below the potable water storage tanks.

Question: Most type(s) of microbiological growths in fuel are ______.
On most commercial cargo vessels with a relatively small crew size and few users of the potable water system how is the potable water system pressure maintained?
Response 1: Cycling the potable water pump on and off by the action of potable water storage tank level switches in response to system demand changes.
Response 2: Allowing the potable water pump to run continuously while recirculating during periods of zero demand for potable water.
Response 3: Allowing the potable water pump to run continuously against a shut-off head during periods of zero demand for potable water.
Response 4: Cycling the potable water pump on and off by the action of the potable water hydro pneumatic tank pressure switch in response to system demand changes.

Question: What is the primary purpose of the lead-lag arrangement of the two potable water pumps supporting a typical potable water system?
Response 1: Enabling the lead pump to cycle on and off during periods of relatively low demand and the lag pump to assist the lead pump only when the demand is high.
Response 2: Enabling the lead pump to pump against a shut-off head during periods of relatively low demand and the lag pump to recirculate when the demand is high.
Response 3: Enabling the lag pump to cycle on and off during periods of relatively low demand and the lead pump to assist the lag pump only when the demand is high.
Response 4: Enabling both potable water pumps to cycle on and off together in response to system demand changes.

Question: What design feature is used to minimize potable water wastage associated with hot water distribution piping for a potable water system?
Response 1: Use of hot water recirculation loops.
Response 2: Use of instantaneous type hot water heaters only.
Response 3: Use of storage type hot water heaters only.
Response 4: Use of hot water heaters with multiple heat sources.

Question: Hot water heaters used in potable water systems may have multiple heat sources such as an electric heating element and a jacket water heated tube bundle. What is the primary purpose of such an arrangement?
Response 1: Allow the designated backup heat source to be used in the event of failure of the designated primary heat source whether in port or underway.
Response 2: Allow jacket water to be used in port and electricity to be used while underway.
Response 3: Allow both the heat sources to be used when the demand for hot water is high whether in port or underway.
Response 4: Allow electricity to be used in port and jacket water to be used while underway.

Question: What are the operating characteristics of a "waterlogged" potable water system hydro pneumatic header tank that needs to be recharged with compressed air?
Response 1: Failure of the potable water pump to start with demand on the system.
Response 2: Extremely long running and idle periods for the potable water pump.
Response 3: Very short and frequent running and idle periods for the potable water pump.
Response 4: Failure of the potable water pump to stop with zero demand on the system.

Question: Distilled water from an evaporator may be discharged into a potable water tank ______.
Response 1: after chemical analysis shows it is fit for consumption
Response 2: after passing through an activated charcoal filter
Response 4: through a solenoid operated three-way valve

Question: On deep-draft ships what statement is true concerning high and low sea suctions for machinery space sea water cooling systems?
Response 1: A high sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water and a low sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily while underway.
Response 2: A low sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water and a high sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily while underway.
Response 3: A high sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily while underway and a low sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water.
Response 4: A low sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily while underway and a high sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water.

Question: What operating condition (or conditions) would necessitate shifting from a high sea suction to a low sea suction for a machinery space sea water cooling system?
Response 1: Underway operations or encountering rough seas.
Response 2: Increasing the number of sea water cooled heat exchangers on service.
Response 3: Reducing the total number of sea water cooled heat exchangers on service.

Question: What operating condition (or conditions) would necessitate shifting from a low sea suction to a high sea suction for a machinery space sea water cooling system?
Response 1: Reducing the total number of sea water cooled heat exchangers on service.
Response 2: Increasing the number of sea water cooled heat exchangers on service.
Response 3: Underway operations or encountering rough seas.

Question: What provision is made for sea chests for removal of solid debris restricting the entry grating into the sea chest of a machinery space sea water cooling system?
Response 1: The debris is continuously removed by blowing the sea chest clear with either compressed air or steam by cracking open the blow valve as appropriate.
Response 2: The debris may be removed by blowing the sea chest clear with either compressed air or steam as appropriate.
Response 3: The debris may be removed by draining the sea chest clear by opening a drain valve located at the bottom of the sea chest.
Response 4: The debris is continuously removed by draining the sea chest clear by cracking open a drain valve located at the bottom of the sea chest.

Question: What provision is made for sea chests for removal of air ingested into the sea chest of a machinery space sea water cooling system?
Response 1: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the vent line originating from the top of the sea chest and terminating in the bilges.
Response 2: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the vent line originating from the top of the sea chest and terminating above the deep-draft load line.
Response 3: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the drain line originating from the bottom of the sea chest and terminating in the bilges.
Response 4: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the drain line originating from the bottom of the sea chest and terminating above the deep-draft load line.

Question: What provision is made for sea chests for removal of ice from within the sea chest of a machinery space sea water cooling system during operation in icy waters?
Response 1: The ice may be removed by using the chemical de-icing anti-freeze connection if provided.
Response 2: The ice may be removed by using the fire main flushing connection if provided.
Response 3: The ice may be removed by using the steaming out sea chest blow connection if provided.
Response 4: The ice may be removed by using the compressed air sea chest blow connection if provided.

Question: Referring to the illustrated steam plant seawater cooling system drawing which pump is considered a high-head pump operating with the highest discharge pressure? See illustration GS-SW-01.
Response 1: The auxiliary sea water circulating pump is considered a high-head pump.
Response 2: The two-speed main sea water circulating pump is considered a high-head pump.
Response 3: The single-speed main sea water circulating pump is considered a high-head pump.
Response 4: Any of the sea water service pumps are considered high-head pumps.

Question: Referring to illustrated steam plant seawater cooling system drawing what statement is true concerning seawater service system to auxiliary circulating seawater system cross-connect capability? See illustration GS-SW-01.
Response 1: In the event of auxiliary circulating pump failure multiple seawater service pumps may be used to supply both the seawater service system and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 2: In the event of auxiliary circulating pump failure multiple seawater service pumps may be used to supply the seawater service main circulating seawater and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 3: In the event of multiple seawater service system pump failures the auxiliary circulating pump may be used to supply both the seawater service system and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 4: In the event of multiple seawater service system pump failures multiple main circulating pumps may be used to supply the seawater service main circulating sea water and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.

Question: Referring to illustrated steam plant seawater cooling system drawing what statement is true concerning main circulating to auxiliary circulating seawater system cross-connect capability? See illustration GS-SW-01.
Response 1: It is possible to use the auxiliary circulating pump to supplement the main circulating pump(s) and it is possible to use the main circulating pump(s) to supplement the auxiliary circulating pump.
Response 2: In the event of multiple seawater service system pump failures multiple main circulating pumps may be used to supply the seawater service main circulating sea water and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 3: While it may be possible to use the main circulating pump(s) to supplement the auxiliary circulating pump it is not possible to use the auxiliary circulating pump to supplement the main circulating pump(s).
Response 4: While it may be possible to use the auxiliary circulating pump to supplement the main circulating pump(s) it is not possible to use the main circulating pump(s) to supplement the auxiliary circulating pump.

Question: On deep-draft ships what statement is true concerning high and low sea suctions for machinery space sea water cooling systems?
Response 1: A low sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water and a high sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily while underway.
Response 2: A high sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water and a low sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily while underway.
Response 3: A high sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily while underway and a low sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water.
Response 4: A low sea suction is located near the turn of the bilge and is used primarily while underway and a high sea suction is located near the bottom of the ship and is used primarily in port or when operating in shallow water.

Question: What provision is made for sea chests for removal of air ingested into the sea chest of a machinery space sea water cooling system?
Response 1: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the drain line originating from the bottom of the sea chest and terminating above the deep-draft load line.
Response 2: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the vent line originating from the top of the sea chest and terminating in the bilges.
Response 3: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the drain line originating from the bottom of the sea chest and terminating in the bilges.
Response 4: The air may be continuously removed by an open valve located in the vent line originating from the top of the sea chest and terminating above the deep-draft load line.

Question: Referring to illustrated steam plant seawater cooling system drawing what statement is true concerning seawater service system to auxiliary circulating seawater system cross-connect capability? See illustration GS-SW-01.
Response 1: In the event of multiple seawater service system pump failures multiple main circulating pumps may be used to supply the seawater service main circulating sea water and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 2: In the event of auxiliary circulating pump failure multiple seawater service pumps may be used to supply both the seawater service system and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 3: In the event of auxiliary circulating pump failure multiple seawater service pumps may be used to supply the seawater service main circulating seawater and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.
Response 4: In the event of multiple seawater service system pump failures the auxiliary circulating pump may be used to supply both the seawater service system and auxiliary circulating sea water system heat exchangers.

Question: When preparing/writing shipyard items for your vessel's upcoming dry docking period what would you consider as an item regarding CuNi salt water cooling systems/piping?
Response 1: Identify in your item all steel waster piece pipe spools in the CuNi systems and require them to be removed and replaced.
Response 2: This item should be of no concern since you have not experienced system piping degradation/leaks.
Response 3: Remove certain designated CuNi piping sections for inspection.
Response 4: Replace all bonding pieces/wires between all CuNi system flanges.

Question: Which of the copper alloys listed is commonly used in heat exchangers and possesses a high resistance to corrosion?

A basic comparison can be made between a low pressure evaporator operation and a main condenser with regards to the removal of non-condensable gases. The vacuum drag line for the main condenser is specifically connected in which area?
The vacuum drag line for the main condenser is specifically connected in which area?
Response 2: the steams first point of entry
Response 3: the end of the steam lane
Response 4: lower portion of the hot well

Question: When condenser tube ends are rolled into both tube sheets the different rates of material expansion are compensated for by utilizing __________.
Response 1: belled joints at both tube ends
Response 2: threaded brass ferrules on the tube ends
Response 3: expansion joints in the condenser shell
Response 4: metallic packing pressed around the tube ends

Question: When main condenser tubes are rolled into both tube sheets the effects due to differential expansion rates are minimized by the use of __________.
A vent line is provided on each water box of the main condenser in order to prevent __________.
A vent line is provided on each water box of the main condenser in order to prevent __________.
Response 1: insufficient head pressure being developed on the circulating pump discharge
Response 2: inadequate heat transfer from developing during normal operation

Question: Which of the pumps listed operates at constant speed and delivers water to the deaerating feed tank at a nearly constant pressure?
The main condensate pump in a steam propulsion plant discharges directly to the __________.
Condensate pumps have distinctly noticeable characteristics and can usually be recognized by their __________.
Response 2: large suction chambers and impeller eyes
Response 3: multiple impellers and pump shaft positions

Question: To combat galvanic corrosion condensers utilizing copper-nickel waterboxes are usually fitted with __________.
Zincs are installed in the main and auxiliary condenser waterboxes to __________.
Electrolytic corrosion in the condenser circulating water system can be reduced by __________.
Response 1: decreasing the velocity of the circulating water through the waterboxes
Response 2: using zinc plates in the waterboxes
Response 3: chemically treating the condensate formed in the hot well
Response 4: decreasing the volume of water in the system

Question: To combat galvanic corrosion condensers utilizing copper-nickel waterboxes are usually fitted with __________.
Which statement listed represents a vital function of the main condenser?
Response 1: The recovery of feed water for reuse.
Response 2: Cooling of the exhaust steam from the auxiliary exhaust system before it enters the deaerating feed tank.
Response 3: Storage of feed water for immediate use in the boilers.
Response 4: Condensing of the exhaust steam from the main feed turbine pumps.

Question: In a marine condenser designed with a reheating hot well the hot well is reheated by __________.
Response 3: a branch line from the air ejector steam supply
Response 4: submerged heating coils supplied with auxiliary exhaust steam

Question: Which of the condensers listed is cooled by sea water?
Heat introduced to the condenser by exhausting steam is removed by the circulation of __________.
In which of the following types of condensers would you find the cooling water passing through tubes with the turbo generator exhaust steam directed around the outside of the tubes?
Proper vacuum must be maintained in the main condenser to __________.
While underway vacuum in the main condenser is primarily caused by the __________.
Response 1: suction drawn by the condensate pump

Question: What unit or factor creates most of the vacuum within a tight and adequately cooled main condenser once the main engine is in operation?
Response 4: Counter flow of seawater over the surface of the tubes with the flow of exhaust steam in the tubes

Question: A main condenser utilizing a scoop for the circulation of seawater must be constructed as a __________.
One of the basic rules applying to the operation of a single-pass main condenser is that the __________.
Response 1: cooling water overboard should be about 10F higher than the inlet temperature
Response 2: vacuum must be maintained at 29.92" of Hg. under all operating conditions
Response 3: quantity of reheating steam flow through the condenser must be maintained at maximum under all operating conditions
Response 4: condensate temperature must never be allowed to drop below 104F

Question: If the pressure becomes excessive in the auxiliary exhaust system of a steam propulsion plant the excess steam will normally be dumped to the __________.
Water boxes on condensers are vented to __________.
Response 1: prevent excessive pressure on tube sheets
Response 2: liberate air pockets and reduce waterside oxidation
Response 3: assure positive flow to the lube oil coolers
Response 4: prevent vapor binding of the circulating pump

Question: Water boxes on main condensers are vented to __________.
Response 1: prevent excessive pressure on tube sheets
Response 2: liberate air pockets and reduce waterside oxidation
Response 3: provide a minimum condensate level in the hot well
Response 4: prevent vapor binding of the circulating pump

Question: If the main condenser were operating at a vacuum of 28.5"Hg a condensate discharge temperature of 86F a seawater inlet temperature of 72F and a seawater outlet temperature of 79F what would be the condensate depression? See illustration SG-0026.

If a main condenser were operating with a vacuum of 28.09 in. Hg a condensate discharge temperature of 95F a seawater inlet temperature of 64F and an overboard temperature of 72F which of the following would represent the condensate depression? See illustration SG-0026.

If the main condenser were operating at a vacuum of 28.7"Hg a condensate discharge temperature of 81F a seawater inlet temperature of 72F and a seawater outlet temperature of 79F what would be the condensate depression? See illustration SG-0026.

The difference between the temperature of the condensate discharge and the temperature corresponding to the vacuum being maintained at the exhaust inlet to the main condenser is defined as __________.
The differential temperature of the main condenser circulating water will be affected by __________.
The differential temperature of the main condenser circulating water during normal operation will be affected by __________.
The differential temperature of the main condenser cooling water will be significantly affected by a change in __________.
In a main propulsion steam turbine installation the condensate pump initially discharges to the __________.
A condensate recirculating line is provided to the main condenser in a closed feed water system to __________.
Response 1: prevent excessively cooled distillate from entering the DC heater
Response 2: provide adequate cooling water to the air ejector inter and after condensers
Response 3: assure a positive flow through the main feed pump
Response 4: prevent flashing in the main feed pump

Question: Air in the main condenser is harmful because it will __________.
Response 1: decrease the turbine exhaust steam pressure
Response 2: decrease the vacuum in the main condenser
Response 3: cause heat to be transferred too rapidly
Response 4: cause the turbine casing to warp and bow

Question: Air trapped within the main condenser shell is detrimental because it will __________.
Response 1: decrease the turbine exhaust steam temperature
Response 2: cause the turbine casing to warp and bow
Response 3: decrease the vacuum in the main condenser
Response 4: cause heat to be transferred too rapidly

Question: A steam plant is operating at 100% power when the atmospheric drain tank runs dry allowing a large air leakage into the main condenser. Which of the following will occur as a result of this air leakage?
Response 2: Decreased pressure in the main condenser
Response 3: Decreased suction pressure at the condensate pump
Response 4: Decreased condenser cooling water outlet temperature

Question: Why does air entry into the main condenser reduce the efficiency of the steam cycle?
Response 1: Steam flow rate through the main turbine increases
Response 2: Condensate sub cooling in the main condenser increases
Response 3: Low pressure turbine exhaust steam enthalpy value increases
Response 4: The air mixes with the steam and enters the condensate

Question: Which of the water supplies listed below is typically used as a cooling medium for the gland exhaust condenser intercondenser and after condenser of an air ejector unit?
The automatic recirculating valve in the main condensate recirculating line is controlled by a temperature sensor which is located at the __________.
Response 3: condensate inlet to the main air ejectors

Question: If a ship is to be laid up for an indefinite period the saltwater side of the main condenser should be __________.
Response 1: left filled with saltwater with the sea valves closed
Response 2: left filled with saltwater with the sea valves open
Response 3: drained and refilled with saltwater after closing the sea valves
Response 4: drained and dried out after closing the sea valves

Question: What affect will the emergency plugging of leaking condenser tubes have on the condenser pressure and hot well temperature when returning to normal steam plant sea speed operation?
Response 1: Absolute pressure and hot well temperature will increase
Response 2: Absolute pressure will decrease and hot well temperature will increase
Response 3: Absolute pressure will increase and hot well temperature will decrease
Response 4: Absolute pressure and hot well temperature will decrease

Question: After being required to plug an excessive number of leaking condenser tubes on the main condenser what changes would you expect to observe when returning to normal steam plant sea speed operation?
Response 1: Absolute pressure and hot well temperature will increase.
Response 2: Absolute pressure will decrease and hot well temperature will increase.
Response 3: Absolute pressure will increase and hot well temperature will decrease.
Response 4: Absolute pressure and hot well temperature will decrease.

Question: Vapor blowing from the air ejector condenser vent may be caused by __________.
Response 2: excess makeup feed being taken into the system

Question: In a closed feed and water cycle which of the conditions listed could prevent vacuum from reaching the desired level?
Response 1: Steam leaking from the turbine glands.
Response 2: Marine growth on the cooling water side of the main condenser.
Response 3: Condensate recirculating back to the condenser during maneuvering.
Response 4: Steam pressure to air ejectors maintained at 10 psig above designed supply pressure.

Question: Saltwater contamination of condensate could occur at which component?
Excessive condensate depression can result in __________.
Excessive condensate depression will result in __________.
Response 1: increased oxygen rejected in the condenser
Response 4: increased air absorption by the condensate

Question: Excessive recirculation of condensate should be avoided as it can cause __________.
Response 3: the condenser hot well to be completely drained at low speeds

Question: The vent line from the main condenser water boxes was not opened when the waterside was recharged. This would __________.
The vent line from the main condenser water boxes was not opened when the waterside was recharged. This would __________.

Operating a steam turbine propulsion unit at reduced speed in an area with extremely cold seawater with the main circulating pump providing full cooling water flow to the condenser will result in __________.
Response 1: decreased plant efficiency due to higher attainable vacuum
Response 2: decreased plant efficiency due to increased condensate depression
Response 3: a decreased requirement for gland sealing steam
Response 4: increased plant efficiency due to increased condensate depression

Question: The temperature at which a vapor mixture at a given pressure begins to condense is the __________.
In a closed feed and condensate system to where do the main air ejector after condenser drains directly drain?
Steam condensed in the air ejector intercondenser drains to the __________.
Response 4: main condenser through the loop seal

Question: Air accumulated in the after condenser of the air ejector unit is discharged directly to the __________.
Air removed from the main condenser is vented to the atmosphere through the __________.
Air accumulated in the intercondenser of the air ejector assembly is discharged directly to the __________.
Which of the following actions should be taken to reestablish a 'blown' air ejector loop seal?
Response 1: Increase the condensate flow through the air ejector.
Response 2: Momentarily close the valve in the loop seal line then reopen slowly.
Response 3: Shut off the steam to the second stage air ejector momentarily then open it again.
Response 4: Decrease the steam pressure to the air ejector nozzles.

Question: The cooling water flow from an air ejector intercondenser and after condenser is discharged directly into the __________.
The first and second stage air ejectors used with large sea water cooled steam surface type condensers are designed to __________.
A set of first and second stage air ejectors are used with a large sea water cooled steam condenser. If the first stage air ejector is not in operation __________.
The first and second stage air ejectors used with main steam condensers are designed to __________.
The loop seal connected to the main condenser returns the drains from the __________.
Which statement is true concerning two-stage air ejector assemblies?
Response 1: Air is removed from the condensate as it passes through the tubes.
Response 2: Steam to the after condenser is condensed and returned to the main condenser via the loop seal.
Response 3: The first stage air ejector takes suction on the second stage to increase vacuum.
Response 4: The steam/air mixture from the main condenser is discharged by the first stage air ejector to the inter condenser.

Question: In the condensate system the automatic recirculating valve can be actuated by the __________.
Main condensate recirculating systems are primarily intended to __________.
Response 1: prevent excessive overheating of the condensate pumps
Response 2: balance and control condensate temperatures at full load
Response 3: provide adequate cooling water for the air ejector condensers
Response 4: vent accumulated vapors from the condensate pump discharge

Question: Serious tube leaks in the air ejector condenser assembly will cause __________.
Serious tube leaks in the air ejector after condenser assembly may cause __________.
Response 3: an overflow of the contaminated drain inspection tank
Response 4: an overflow of the atmospheric drain tank

Question: Serious tube leaks in the air ejector condenser assembly may cause __________.
Response 3: an overflow of the contaminated drain inspection tank
Response 4: an overflow of the atmospheric drain tank

Question: While vacuum is being raised on the main unit and the turbine is being warmed condensate is recirculated to the main condenser to __________.
Response 1: ensure the condensation of air ejector steam
Response 2: cool the main condenser shell for better vacuum
Response 4: maintain a proper DC heater water level

Question: The automatic recirculating valve in the main condensate recirculating line is designed to be controlled by which method?
Response 2: Main condenser salt water pressure controller

Question: What type of sensor is normally used with the automatic recirculating valve in the main condensate line?
Scale in the air ejector first-stage nozzle could cause a decrease in the __________.
If the cooling water flow through the air ejector intercondensers and after condensers is inadequate which of the problems listed will occur?
Response 4: Main condenser absolute pressure will increase.

Question: Insufficient cooling water circulation through air ejector intercondensers and after condensers will cause __________.
Response 1: decreased vacuum in the main condenser
Response 2: overheating of the air ejector nozzles

Question: If the condensate level in the loop seal of the intercondenser is lost __________.
Response 1: no condensate will flow through the system
Response 2: some air will be drawn into the main condenser
Response 3: the air ejector will not operate
Response 4: the air ejector will become overheated

Question: If the condensate level in the loop seal of the air ejector intercondenser is lost __________.
Response 1: no condensate will flow through the system
Response 2: air will be drawn back into the main condenser
Response 3: the air ejector will not transfer heat to the condensate

Question: Feed water heaters are used aboard steam vessels to reduce thermal shock to the boiler and to __________.
Response 2: act as a heat sink for turbine bleed steam
Response 4: reduce back pressure in the auxiliary exhaust line

Question: Under normal conditions the rate of heat transfer in a feed water heater is most greatly affected by the __________.
Response 1: temperature differential between the steam and feed water
Response 4: speed of the main feed pump

Question: An increase in the pressure drop between the inlet and outlet of the feed water heater waterside not due to a waterside obstruction would indicate __________.
Response 1: insufficient water velocity through the heater
Response 2: a water flow rate higher than feed water heater design limits
Response 3: fouling of the heater steam side
Response 4: an accumulation of non-condensable gases in the steam circuit

Question: Excessive water flow beyond the design limits of a feed water heater will be indicated by a/an __________.
Response 1: increase in the pressure drop between the water inlet and outlet
Response 2: decrease in the pressure drop between the water inlet and outlet
Response 3: excessive gas liberation from the waterside vents
Response 4: high steam temperature at the heater outlet

Question: The unit shown in the illustration is used as the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 4: flash evaporator salt water feed heater

Question: The items labeled "A" in the illustration are the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
The connections labeled "D" in the illustration __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: maintain a vacuum in the shell of the feed water heater
Response 2: provide a point of admission of the steam air heater drains
Response 3: provide a point of admission of the L.P. bleed steam
Response 4: drain condensate from the feed water heater to the main condenser

Question: The items labeled "D" in the illustration are the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
The connection labeled "B" in the illustration is used to __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: maintain a vacuum in the shell of the feed water heater
Response 2: provide a point of admission for the steam air heater drains
Response 3: provide a point of admission for the L.P. bleed steam
Response 4: drain condensate from the feed water heater to the main condenser

Question: The connection labeled "C" in the illustration is used to __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: maintain a vacuum in the shell of the feed water heater
Response 2: provide a point of admission for the steam air heater drains
Response 3: provide a point of admission for the L.P. bleed steam
Response 4: drain condensate from the feed water heater to the main condenser

Question: The connections labeled "A" in the illustration are used to __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: maintain a vacuum in the shell of the feed water heater
Response 2: provide a point of admission for the steam air heater drains
Response 3: provide a point of admission for the L.P. bleed steam
Response 4: drain condensate from the feed water heater to the main condenser

Question: The item labeled "C" in the illustration is the __________. See illustration SG-0025.

The feed water heater shown in the illustration is actually comprised of three separately functioning heat exchangers. These heat exchangers are identified as the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: first stage heater gland exhaust condenser and drain cooler
Response 2: first stage heater inter condenser and after condenser
Response 3: inter condenser after condenser and gland exhaust condenser
Response 4: drain cooler distillate condenser and fresh water drain collector

Question: The upper section of the feed water heater indicated by "G" in the illustration is used as the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
The mid section of the feed heater indicated by "F" in the illustration is used as the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
The lower section of the feed heater labeled "E" in the illustration is used as the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
A slight vacuum is maintained in the shell of the first stage heater shown in the illustration. The primary reason for the vacuum is to __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: provide a low pressure area to guarantee feed water flow to the heater
Response 2: maintain a positive flow of steam as supplied by the main engine LP bleed system
Response 3: force the use of the main condenser as the drain cooler
Response 4: avoid the necessity of having to use the condensate pumps

Question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the operation of the level or drain regulator associated with the feed water heater shown in the illustration is correct? See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: The regulator maintains the flow of steam into the first stage heater of this unit.
Response 2: The regulator controls the level of condensate collected in the drain cooler section.
Response 3: The regulator controls the flow rate of condensate leaving the feed water outlet.
Response 4: The regulator controls the volume of condensate leaving the gland exhaust condenser.

Question: The feed water heater shown in the illustration was designed to maintain the required feed water outlet temperature with an approximate 10" (25.4 cm) Hg shell vacuum. If the shell vacuum is increased to approximately 16" (40.64 cm) Hg vacuum the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: overall plant operating efficiency will increase
Response 2: vacuum in the main condenser will drop as the feed heater shell vacuum increases
Response 3: feed water outlet temperature will decrease
Response 4: flow rate of condensate to the feed heater will increase

Question: The feed water heater shown in the illustration was designed to maintain the required feed water outlet temperature with an approximate 10" Hg shell vacuum. If the shell vacuum is decreased to approximately 8" Hg vacuum the __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 2: vacuum in the main condenser will increase as the feed heater shell vacuum increases
Response 3: flow rate of condensate to the feed heater will decrease
Response 4: feed water outlet temperature will increase

Question: If the drain regulator used in the operation of the combined L.P. feed water heater shown in the illustration is incorrectly set to maintain too high of a level (condensate level covers approximately the lower half of tubes in the first stage heater) the resulting operation will __________. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 2: cause the feed water outlet temperature to decrease
Response 3: cause the feed water temperature to increase above the designed outlet temperature
Response 4: cause the automatic make-up feed valve to cycle open

Question: The items labeled "D" in the illustration are the ______. See illustration SG-0025.
The connections labeled "A" in the illustration are used to ______. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: provide a point of admission for the steam air heater drains
Response 2: drain condensate from the feed water heater to the main condenser
Response 3: provide a point of admission for the L.P. bleed steam
Response 4: maintain a vacuum in the shell of the feed water heater

Question: The unit shown in the illustration is used as the ______. See illustration SG-0025.
Response 1: flash evaporator salt water feed heater

Question: Under normal conditions steam to the DC heater is supplied directly from which of the systems listed?
In a DC heater which source of steam is commonly used to heat and deaerate condensate?
The minimum design height of the DC heater is determined by the _______.
Response 1: dew point temperature of the stack gases
Response 2: minimum net positive suction head required by the main feed pump

Question: Why is it necessary to have a relief valve protect the deaerating feed tank from internal pressure?
Response 1: Because the tank receives auxiliary exhaust.
Response 2: Because the tank receives high pressure drains.
Response 3: Because the tank receives large amounts of water.
Response 4: Because the tank drains to the main condenser.

Question: Which of the components listed prevents water from flowing back into the auxiliary exhaust line if the deaerating feed tank becomes flooded?
The DC Heater functions to __________.
Response 1: store heat and deaerate feed water
Response 2: chemically treat feed water to remove carbonic gas
Response 3: ensure recirculation in the feed water system
Response 4: remove the major amount of non-condensable gases from the main condenser

Question: The DC heater functions to __________.
In a closed feed water system the greatest deaeration of condensate occurs in the __________.
Feed water is deaerated to prevent __________.
In a modern high pressure steam plant most feed water deaeration takes place in the __________.
A high water level in a deaerating feed heater will cause the automatic dump valve to drain condensate to the __________.
The DC heater automatic level dump valve is used to __________.
Response 1: divert the flow of condensate from the first stage heater to the vent condenser
Response 2: maintain a proper condensate level in the condenser hot well
Response 3: recirculate condensate to the atmospheric drain tank
Response 4: drain excess feed water to the distilled water tank

Question: Flooding of the DC heater due to the addition of excessive makeup feed is normally corrected by the use of __________.
Response 4: a manual or automatic dump valve to the reserve feed tank or distilled tank

Question: Cooling water to the vent condenser in a DC heater is supplied by the _______.
Vent condensers are usually an integral part of deaerating feed heaters and serve to condense __________.
Response 1: only steam vented from high pressure steam traps
Response 2: steam vented from high pressure steam glands
Response 3: the steam vapor entrained with the non-condensable gases
Response 4: the gases liberated by the deaeration process

Question: Condensate is pumped from the condenser to the DC heater instead of directly to the boiler because __________.
Response 1: boiler feed pumps must operate with a negative suction head
Response 2: suspended solids in the condensate must be eliminated
Response 3: condensate should be deaerated before entering the boiler
Response 4: condensate at condensing temperature is too hot and will cause thermal stress in the boiler

Question: Discharging an excessive amount of cold water into the DC heater during normal steaming conditions could cause __________.
Response 1: flashing at the feed pump suction
Response 2: excess oxygen in the feed water

Question: Rapidly discharging condensate into the DC heater during normal steaming conditions could cause __________.
Response 2: decrease in dissolved oxygen in the feed water

Question: To provide emergency feed water supply to a steaming boiler if it becomes necessary to secure the DC heater suction should be taken on the distilled water tank using the __________.
During cold ship start-up you should open the feed water outlet and condensate valves to a DC heater in order to __________.
Response 2: expel non-condensable vapors from the vent

Question: If the boiler water and condenser hot well levels are normal but the DC heater level is only 30% of full you should __________.
Response 1: increase the speed of the condensate pump
Response 2: open the feed pump recirculating valve wide
Response 4: bypass the vent condenser and third-stage feed heater

Question: If the boiler water level is normal the main condenser hot well level is normal and the DC heater level is 40% full you should __________.
Response 4: open the makeup feed vacuum drag line

Question: The purpose of the steam control valves installed in the auxiliary exhaust line is to __________.
Response 1: control steam admission and maintain the proper steam spray pattern in the DC heater
Response 2: regulate back pressure in the desuperheater line
Response 3: preheat the condensate before it enters the vent condenser
Response 4: seal the vent condenser to prevent the escape of condensate

Question: With the steam control valve wide open during normal operation the rate of steam flow from the auxiliary exhaust steam line to the DC heater is actually a function of __________.
Response 1: rate of condensation in the DC heater
Response 2: spring pressure of the spray valves
Response 3: water level in the DC heater reservoir
Response 4: rate of evaporation in the DC heater

Question: During normal operation the steam flow from the auxiliary exhaust line to the DC heater can be closely related to the _______.
Response 1: spring pressure of the spray valves
Response 2: water level in the DC heater reservoir
Response 3: the temperature and quantity of the condensate flow to the DC heater
Response 4: rate of evaporation in the DC heater

Question: Improper boiler feed water deaeration could be directly linked to __________.
Response 2: fluctuating deaerating feed tank level as a result of taking on makeup feed too rapidly
Response 3: fluctuating condensate pressure due to not maintaining proper hot well level

Question: Excess free oxygen in the boiler feed water can be the result of __________.
Response 1: improper operation of the DC heater
Response 2: steam leaks through the turbine glands
Response 3: improper operation of the gland exhauster
Response 4: vapor lock in the boiler feed pump

Question: Which of the DC heater operations listed will result in excessive dissolved oxygen in boiler water?
Response 1: Excessively high water level in the heater.
Response 3: Operating the heater with a closed air vent.

Question: In order to test the lifting pressure of the deaerating feed heater relief valve you would __________.
In order to test the lifting pressure of the deaerating feed heater relief valve you would __________.
If the DC heater relief valve lifts frequently the cause can be excessive __________.
Response 1: condensate supplied to the DC heater
Response 3: feed water recirculated from the feed pump
Response 4: makeup feed introduced to the system

Question: Which of the conditions listed may be indicated by the lifting of the DC heater relief valve?
Response 1: A malfunctioning auxiliary exhaust make-up steam regulating valve.
Response 2: Excessive deaeration of the feed water.
Response 3: Low back pressure in the auxiliary exhaust line.
Response 4: Low water level continually maintained in the DC heater.

Question: Which of the listed statements is true concerning the start-up of a main propulsion boiler centrifugal feed pump?
Response 1: The pump should always be started with the discharge valve closed.
Response 2: The pump should always be started with the suction valve closed.
Response 3: A priming pump is always required to flood the impeller suction.
Response 4: The pump should always be started with the sealing line valves closed.

Question: The main boiler feed pump discharge is controlled by the admission of steam to the auxiliary turbine. The admission of steam is normally regulated by a __________.
Which of the following statements is correct regarding the start-up operation of a non-condensing turbine-driven feed pump?
Response 1: Keep the steam exhaust valve closed until steam is applied to ensure that the auxiliary exhaust line pressure does not drop.
Response 2: Keep the pump casing vent valve closed until flow is established through the pump.
Response 3: Open the pump suction valve prior to admitting steam to the turbine.
