Question: Hydraulically servo-operated automatic change over valves utilized in a two ram hydraulic steering gear serve to __________.
Response 1: allow an alternate main pump to start in the fully loaded condition thus developing immediate full torque
Response 2: prevent either main pump from being hydraulically motored when idle by cross pressure flow
Response 3: prevent both units from operating simultaneously which could result in doubling the flow of oil and pressure leading to over pressurization of the system

Question: Hydraulically servo-operated automatic change over valves utilized in a two ram hydraulic steering gear serve to ________.
Response 1: allow an alternate main pump to start in the fully loaded condition thus developing immediate full torque.
Response 2: prevent the idle main pump from being hydraulically motored by cross pressure flow.
Response 3: prevent main pumps from operating simultaneously which could result in the over pressurization of the system.

Question: On an electro-hydraulic steering gear which of the listed devices will keep the rudder from over traveling the bridge signal?
Which of the devices listed when used on an electro-hydraulic steering gear keeps the movement of the rudder closely in step with the steering wheel?
Rudder motion is prevented from exceeding the movement of the steering wheel by the __________.
The follow-up gear on an electro-hydraulic steering gear __________.
Response 2: takes the pump off stroke when the desired rudder angle is attained.
Response 3: allows for rudder movement faster than the movement of the ship's wheel.
Response 4: returns the rudder to amidships when the wheel is released.

Question: The follow-up gear on an electro-hydraulic steering gear __________.
Response 2: takes the pump off stroke when the desired rudder angle is attained
Response 3: synchronizes wheel position with the rudder position
Response 4: returns the rudder to midposition when the wheel is released

Question: In an electro-hydraulic steering system rudder movement is maintained in close synchronization with the steering wheel position by means of the __________.
In a typical hydraulic steering gear system as the designated rudder angle is approaching the helm command angle what will be the reaction of the steering gear follow-up mechanism?
Response 1: The follow-up mechanism will be compensating with an increasing signal to the hydraulic pump tilt box controls.
Response 2: The follow-up mechanism will be inactive as long as rudder angle error exists.
Response 3: The follow-up mechanism will send a hydraulic signal back to the helm as the rudder angle is achieved
Response 4: The follow-up mechanism will be compensating with an decreasing signal to the hydraulic pump tilt box controls.

Question: The purpose of the six-way valve used in an electro-hydraulic steering system is to __________.
Response 1: parallel rudder motion to the steering wheel
Response 2: take the pump off stroke when desired rudder angle is attained
Response 3: redirect hydraulic fluid flow when changing over pumps
Response 4: ensure positive contact between the Rapson slide and the rudder post

Question: In the illustration component "C" is used to replace __________. See illustration GS-0123.
Response 1: the rudder position follow up gear
Response 2: the necessity for manual repositioning of the six-way valve
Response 4: the mechanical method for positioning of the variable stroke control of the main pump

Question: In the illustrated schematic the device used to replace the six-way valve as found on many older type steering gears is the component labeled as __________. See illustration GS-0123.
The necessity of the six-way valve as used on many older steering gears has been replaced by __________. See illustration GS-0123.
Response 2: check valves installed in the discharge/return lines of the steering gear pumps
Response 4: an automatic hydraulic method when changing over steering gear pumps

Question: In an electro-hydraulic steering gear any change in relative position between the synchronous receiver and the follow-up gear will result in __________.
Response 1: the pump going to full stroke
Response 3: driving the rams up against the stops
Response 4: a corresponding slowing or increasing of the pumped flow rate

Question: When the helm is turned on the navigation bridge which of the listed actions will be the FIRST response in the steering room on a ship equipped with an electro-hydraulic steering gear?
Response 1: The pumps go to full stroke.
Response 2: The six-way valve aligns itself with the running pump.
Response 3: Both port and starboard cables are energized.
Response 4: The synchronous receiver turns duplicating the helm motion.

Question: The function of the hydraulic telemotor transmitter used in an electro-hydraulic steering gear system is to __________.
Response 1: transmit the rudder angle to the bridge indicator
Response 2: prevent the control linkage from striking the stops when hard over
Response 3: automatically purge all entrained air from the system
Response 4: send hydraulic signals to the receiving unit

Question: When the steering gear receives a command signal for a 15 right rudder during the initial period of movement of the rudder __________. See illustration GS-0123.
Response 1: shaft "K" will rotate but its output to "M" will be nullified
Response 2: shaft "K" will rotate causing "M" to rotate reducing linkage length
Response 3: shaft "L" will cause shaft "K" to rotate via the planetary differential gear
Response 4: shaft "L" will rotate but its output to "M" will be nullified

Question: The output from shaft "K" shown in the illustration becomes an actual control factor when component(s) __________. See illustration GS-0123.
When there is no movement of the rams of an electro-hydraulic steering gear system the tilting box of the axial piston hydraulic pump is __________.
In an electro-hydraulic steering gear system when will the variable displacement pump be placed on stroke?
Response 1: When the helm is at any angle other than amidships.
Response 2: When the six-way valve is opened.
Response 3: When the ram relief valves lift.
Response 4: When the rudder angle is different from the position of the helm.

Question: The follow-up mechanism for the steering gear shown functions to assure the correct rudder position for each corresponding position of the helm. When operating properly the follow-up mechanism should __________. See illustration GS-0123.
Response 1: return the main pump stroke to neutral when rudder error angle is less than 10 degrees
Response 2: maintain a constant pump stroke for all rudder command angles
Response 3: gradually increase main pump stroke as rudder attains command angle
Response 4: gradually decrease pump stroke as rudder is achieving command angle

Question: What is the name of the mechanism used to transmit rudder angle information from the steering gear itself to the wheelhouse in the illustrated rudder angle indicator system? See illustration EL-0092.
As shown in the illustrated wiring diagram for an engine order telegraph system what statement concerning the current failure alarm buzzer is true? See illustration EL-0113.
Response 1: The current failure alarm buzzer is energized when there is a power loss from the battery or emergency switchboard as appropriate.
Response 2: The current failure alarm buzzer is energized when there is a power loss from the 115 VAC power supply to the system.
Response 3: The current failure alarm buzzer is energized when there is a open stator winding in any transmitter or indicator in the system.
Response 4: The current failure alarm buzzer is energized when there is an open rotor winding in any transmitter or indicator in the system.

Question: As shown in the illustrated wiring diagram for an engine order telegraph system what statement concerning the constant ringing and trouble alarm is true? See illustration EL-0113.
Response 1: The constant ringing and trouble alarm sounds when there is a power loss from the battery or emergency switchboard as appropriate.
Response 2: The constant ringing and trouble alarm sounds when there is a power loss from the 115 VAC power supply to the system.
Response 3: The constant ringing and trouble alarm sounds when the acknowledge handle and indicator arrow are not on the same order.
Response 4: The constant ringing and trouble alarm sounds when the transmitter rotor and corresponding indicator rotor are in correspondence.

Question: As shown in the illustrated wiring diagram for an engine order telegraph system what statement concerning the wrong direction alarm is true? See illustration EL-0113.
Response 1: The wrong direction alarm sounds when the engine room indicator rotates in the opposite direction from the wheelhouse transmitter.
Response 2: The wrong direction alarm sounds when the wheelhouse indicator rotates in the opposite direction from the engine room transmitter.
Response 3: The wrong direction alarm sounds when the transfer relay fails to transfer transmitting and indicating function to the proper station.
Response 4: The wrong direction alarm sounds when the engine is started in the opposite direction from the engine room indicator pointer position.

Question: What controls rudder movement when the Operation Selector Switch shown in figure "A" of the illustration is in the "Controller'' position? See illustration EL-0097.
As shown in figure "A" of the illustration feedback or rudder angle repeat back is used by the port or starboard amplifier in which operational modes? See illustration EL-0097.

As shown in figure "A" of the illustration fine adjustments such as "rate of turn signal" have no effect on steering stand operation when the 'operation selector switch' is in what position? See illustration EL-0097.
As shown in figure "A" of the illustration the actual rudder angle repeat back signal originates at what device and is delivered to what other device? See illustration EL-0097.
Response 1: originates at the power unit and delivered to the amplifier
Response 2: originates at the power unit and delivered to the control potentiometer
Response 3: originates at the amplifier and delivered to the power unit
Response 4: originates at the amplifier and delivered to the control potentiometer

Question: As shown in the illustrated steering hydraulic pump motor controller what would be the result if one of the 10 amp fuses blew while the steering hydraulic pump motor was running See illustration EL-0119.
Response 1: the steering hydraulic pump motor would stop running
Response 2: the gyro-pilot unit motor would stop running
Response 3: the steering hydraulic pump motor run indicator light would go out
Response 4: nothing except that the steering hydraulic pump motor overload indicator light would be unable to warn of an overload

Question: As shown in the illustration of an older electro-mechanical autopilot system by what means is the steering order conveyed from the helm to the steering gear? See illustration EL-0187.
As shown in the illustrated graph showing the operating principle of a phantom rudder what statement is true? See illustration EL-0189.
Response 1: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are equal in magnitude and have the same polarity.
Response 2: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are equal in magnitude and are opposite in polarity.
Response 3: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are unequal in magnitude and have the same polarity.
Response 4: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are unequal in magnitude and are opposite in polarity.

Question: As shown in the illustrated graph showing the practical application of a phantom rudder what statement is true? See illustration EL-0190.
Response 1: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are equal in magnitude and have the same polarity.
Response 2: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are equal in magnitude and are opposite in polarity.
Response 3: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are unequal in magnitude and have the same polarity.
Response 4: The rudder phantom and rudder translator voltages are unequal in magnitude and are opposite in polarity.

Question: As shown in the illustrated adaptive digital steering control system functional block diagram and listed system interface signals table what would the rudder order signal output voltage to the rudder servo amplifier be for a rudder order of 20 left rudder assuming left rudder signals are negative and right rudder signals are positive in polarity. See illustration EL-0191.

As shown in the illustrated adaptive digital steering control system functional block diagram and listed system interface signals table what would the rudder order signal output voltage to the rudder servo amplifier be for a rudder order of 15 right rudder assuming left rudder signals are negative and right rudder signals are positive in polarity. See illustration EL-0191.

As shown in the illustrated digital gyrocompass functional block diagram and the associated communication protocols table what would the rate of turn signal voltage be if the rate of turn is 30 per minute to port assuming that rate of turn to port is negative and rate of turn to starboard is positive in polarity? See illustration EL-0194.

Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustration if the gyrocompass was malfunctioning but no fault codes are present on the display unit what is most likely the problem if the DC/DC converter LED status indicator is functioning properly but the CPU LED status indicator is not blinking? See illustration EL-0195.
Response 2: The AC/DC power supply is malfunctioning.

Question: Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustrations if the adaptive digital steering system was malfunctioning but no fault codes are present on the display unit what is most likely the problem if the DC/DC converter LED status indicator is functioning properly and the CPU LED status indicator is blinking? Response 2: The AC/DC power supply is malfunctioning.

Question: Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustrations if the adaptive digital steering system was malfunctioning and the fault code 41 (SPEED LOG ERROR) is displayed what corrective action should be performed FIRST? See illustration EL-0197.See illustration EL-0198.

Question: Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustrations if the adaptive digital steering system was malfunctioning and the fault code 41 (SPEED LOG ERROR) is displayed what corrective action should be performed LAST? See illustration EL-0197.See illustration EL-0198.
Response 1: Check message string output by the source.

Question: Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustrations if the adaptive digital steering system was malfunctioning and the fault code 42 (SPEED LOG ERROR) is displayed what corrective action should be performed FIRST? See illustration EL-0197.See illustration EL-0198.

Question: Using the trouble analysis chart and faults table provided in the illustrations if the adaptive digital steering system was malfunctioning and the fault code 42 (SPEED LOG ERROR) is displayed what corrective action should be performed LAST? See illustration EL-0197.See illustration EL-0198.
Response 1: Check speed log source (log data strings from source).
Response 4: Replace the CPU assembly for pulse log.

Question: As shown in figure "A" of the illustration if the operation selector switch is allowed to remain in the 'Controller' mode after testing of the steering gear how will the rudder respond? See illustration EL-0097.
Response 1: It will not respond to commands from the helm
Response 2: It will move in one direction only regardless of the movement of the helm
Response 3: It will respond only to the output of the differential repeater
Response 4: It will stop moving only when the helm is counter-rotated to put the pump at neutral stroke

Question: When making welding repairs to a ship's structural member why is it important to avoid weld faults?
Response 1: The poor quality weld can lead to points of stress relief which in addition to a weak joint may form the starting points for cracks.
Response 2: The poor quality weld can lead to points of stress concentration which in addition to a weak joint may cause plate distortion.
Response 3: The poor quality weld can lead to points of stress concentration which in addition to a weak joint may form the starting points for cracks.
Response 4: The poor quality weld can lead to points of stress relief which in addition to a weak joint may cause plate distortion.

Question: When accomplishing welding repairs with an electric arc welding process what is generally the cause of slag inclusion when welding a single-V butt joint?
Response 1: The weld was performed with too high a current setting.
Response 2: The weld was performed with an improper rod angle.
Response 3: The weld was performed with inadequate cleaning between passes.
Response 4: The weld was performed with too low a current setting.

Question: When accomplishing welding repairs using the electric arc welding process what statement is true concerning the characteristics of a good quality weld when welding a single-V butt joint?
Response 1: There should be no overlap but there should be undercut at the toe of the weld.
Response 2: There should be both overlap and undercut at the toe of the weld.
Response 3: There should be no overlap and no undercut at the toe of the weld.
Response 4: There should be overlap but there should be no undercut at the toe of the weld.

Question: When accomplishing welding repairs using the electric arc welding process what statement is true concerning the characteristics of a good quality weld when welding a single-V butt joint?
Response 1: There should be no reinforcement or build-up of material on the top surface but there should be root penetration along the bottom surface.
Response 2: There should be a slight reinforcement or build-up of material on the top surface but there should be no root penetration along the bottom surface.
Response 3: There should be a no reinforcement or build-up of material on the top surface and there should be no root penetration along the bottom surface.
Response 4: There should be a slight reinforcement or build-up of material on the top surface and there should be root penetration along the bottom surface.

Question: When accomplishing welding repairs using the electric arc welding process what statement is true concerning the characteristics of a good quality weld when welding a single-V butt joint?
Response 1: There should be no penetration at the sides of the weld and there should be no penetration between passes.
Response 2: There should be no penetration at the sides of the weld but there should be penetration between passes.
Response 3: There should be penetration at the sides of the weld and there should be penetration between passes.
Response 4: There should be penetration at the sides of the weld but there should be no penetration between passes.

Question: Before welding repairs are performed to repair a crack what is the correct procedure for performing an emergency crack stopper?
Response 1: A 3/8-inch hole should be drilled at one end of the crack only making sure that none of the crack extends beyond the hole.
Response 2: A 3/8-inch hole should be drilled at each end of the crack making sure that none of the crack extends beyond the two holes.
Response 3: A 3/8-inch hole should be drilled at one end of the crack only making sure that approximately 1/2-inch of the crack extends beyond the hole.
Response 4: A 3/8-inch hole should be drilled at each end of the crack making sure that 1/2-inch of the crack extends beyond the two holes.

Question: Before welding repairs are performed to repair a crack after drilling a 3/8-inch hole at each end of the crack what is the correct procedure for welding overlays as an emergency crack stopper?
Response 1: A welded overlay of trapezoidal shape shall be deposited perpendicularly at each end of the crack no closer than 1/2-inch from each drilled hole.
Response 2: A welded overlay of trapezoidal shape shall be deposited perpendicularly at one end of the crack only no closer than 1/2-inch from the drilled hole.
Response 3: A welded overlay of trapezoidal shape shall be deposited perpendicularly at each end of the crack right up against each drilled hole.
Response 4: A welded overlay of trapezoidal shape shall be deposited perpendicularly at one end of the crack only right up against the drilled hole.

Question: In order to minimize distortion while performing the electric arc welding process while joining two plates with a butt weld besides using restraint procedures what statement is true?
Response 1: The greater the number of welding passes the less the distortion and welding on only one side of a joint with a single-V will minimize distortion.
Response 2: The greater the number the welding passes the less the distortion and symmetrical welding on either side of a joint with a double-V will minimize distortion.
Response 3: The fewer the number of welding passes the less the distortion and symmetrical welding on either side of a joint with a double-V will minimize distortion.
Response 4: The fewer the number of welding passes the less the distortion and welding on only one side of a joint with a single-V will minimize distortion.

Question: For long welding runs either the "back-step" or the "skip" welding technique is often used. For what purpose are these techniques utilized?
Response 1: These techniques are used to minimize internal stresses.
Response 2: These techniques are used to help minimize distortion.
Response 3: These techniques are used to increase weld strength.
Response 4: These techniques are used to maximize distortion.

Question: If a welding fabrication becomes unacceptably distorted what means of distortion correction should be avoided?
Response 1: Complete splitting of the joint followed by rewelding.
Response 2: Gouging or grooving of the joint followed by rewelding.
Response 4: Strategic application of spot heating with an acetylene torch.

Question: As shown in figure "A" of the illustration the actual rudder angle repeatback signal originates at what device and is delivered to what other device? See illustration EL-0097.
Response 1: originates at the amplifier and delivered to the control potentiometer
Response 2: originates at the power unit and delivered to the amplifier
Response 3: originates at the power unit and delivered to the control potentiometer
Response 4: originates at the amplifier and delivered to the power unit

Question: Air trapped in the hydraulic fluid of a steering system may be indicated by __________.
Response 3: a constantly occurring improper rudder response

Question: When the helm angle position is changed the series of corresponding events of the steering gear will include __________.
When the helm angle position is changed in the wheel house a series of corresponding events of the steering gear will occur and include the following:
If one hydraulic pump of an electro-hydraulic steering unit fails the vessel's steering can be maintained by using the __________.

If it were possible to simultaneously operate both main pumps shown in the steering gear illustration which of the following statements would be true if the starboard power unit were to be brought on line with the port unit already in operation? See illustration GS-0123.
Response 1: The indicated valve spool in "C" would shift to the left
Response 2: Pump "I" would supply replenishing oil to the system
Response 3: The starboard distributor valve "A" would allow recirculation of the starboard main pump

Question: Which of the following actions will occur with the steering system shown in the illustration when responding to a left rudder command from amidships? See illustration GS-0137.
Response 2: Only hose "J" will be placed under pressure during this maneuver.
Response 3: The starboard ram will extend aft.
Response 4: The six-way valve "N" will be opened.

Question: While responding to a right full rudder command from the amidships position which of the cylinders illustrated will be fully pressurized on the face of the pistons? See illustration GS-0104.
When responding to a 'right rudder' command from the amidships position which parts of the steering gear system illustrated will be subjected to the highest pressure? See illustration GS-0137.

The steering gear unit shown in the illustration which of the conditions listed will occur as 'left rudder' is being obtained and only the 'No. 1' steering gear pump is running? See illustration GS-0104.
The action necessary to use the steering gear room trick wheel when transferring the steering control from the wheelhouse to local control is to __________.
Response 1: align the trick wheel to the rudder angle position before engaging
Response 2: set the six-way control valve in the trick wheel position
Response 3: open the power transfer switch before engaging the trick wheel

Question: Dual electro-hydraulic steering units usually operate __________.

Question: In order to change over the main pumps shown in the illustrated steering gear which of the components listed must be manually actuated? See illustration GS-0123.
When the steering gear is in operation you should __________.
Response 1: check hydraulic oil levels every hour
Response 3: check for excessive oil leakage from rams
Response 4: drain water from telemotor cylinders each watch

Question: While inspecting the steering gear at sea you should check for __________.
Response 2: accuracy of the rudder angle indicator

Question: While inspecting the steering system at sea you should check for __________.
Response 1: air bubbles in the sight glass
Response 3: over travel in the rudder angle indicator

Question: While inspecting the steering system at sea you should check for __________.
Response 1: air bubbles in the sight glass
Response 3: over travel in the rudder angle indicator
Response 4: proper rotation of the hydraulic steering pump

Question: The purging of air from an electro-hydraulic steering gear unit is necessary when __________.
Response 1: changing over to hand pump operation

Question: While at normal sea speed the rudder movement stops but is restored after changing over power units. At the earliest opportunity the faulty power unit is restarted with the following results: the rudder can be remotely swung in only one direction however using the trick wheel equal movement of the variable stroke control device from neutral is available.The probable cause is __________. Response 2: either solenoid coil 'F1' or 'F3' has burned out

Response 4: that pump "G" can not develop adequate discharge

Question: If a severe leak develops in the electro-hydraulic steering gear which of the listed conditions could result?

Question: When air becomes trapped in the hydraulic fluid of a steering system the __________.
An electric power failure occurring in a electro-hydraulic steering gear would cause the rudder to __________.

Question: An electric motor failure in an electro-hydraulic steering gear system would cause the rudder to __________.

Question: Air trapped in the hydraulic fluid of a steering system would be indicated by __________.

Question: A power failure in the hydraulic system of a compact type steering gear would cause the rudder to __________.

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require hydraulic steering gear systems to be equipped with a means of steadying the rudder in an emergency. This may be accomplished with __________.
Response 1: a suitable arrangement of stop valves in the main piping
Response 2: a positive arrangement for stopping the rudder before the rudder stops are reached
Response 3: a suitable arrangement of block and tackle powered by winches
Response 4: buffer arrangements to relieve the gear from shocks to the rudder

Question: According to Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR Part 58) a power driven auxiliary steering gear for a vessel capable of a 12 knot service speed must be able to meet the rudder movement requirements at which of the minimum vessel speeds listed below?

An electric driven steering gear power unit is required by Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) to be capable of putting the rudder over from 15 on one side to 15 on the other side in not more than 60 seconds under emergency power with the vessel running ahead. For a 20 knot vessel this test must be carried out at __________.

According to Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) a power driven auxiliary steering gear for a vessel capable of a 20 knot service speed must be capable of producing a specific range of rudder movement at which of the minimum speeds listed below?
Your vessel is departing at 1800 hours on a voyage of more than 48 hours duration. Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require that the steering gear be examined and tested no earlier than __________.

Before setting out on a three day voyage Coast Guard Regulations require that the steering gear whistle and communications system between the bridge and engine room must be tested within how many hours prior to departure?

Response 1: by a required auxiliary steering system under emergency conditions when duplicated main steering power systems are provided
Response 2: by design at one-half astern speed without damage.
Response 3: from 35 degrees on one side to 30 degrees on the other side in no more than 28 seconds
Response 4: from 15 degrees on one side to 15 degrees to the other side in 30 seconds at 7 knots or one-half the maximum service speed

Question: Coast Guard Regulations require that vessels of 500 GT or less what equipment must be tested weekly?
Response 1: Storage batteries to provide all power for the vessel and operated under load for emergency lighting.
Response 2: All vessel internal control system alarms.
Response 3: Emergency astern operations regardless of vessel location
Response 4: Run emergency generator driven by an internal combustion engine under load for at least 2 hours.

Question: According to Title 33 CFR of the equipment listed below which equipment must be tested NOT more than 12 hours prior to getting underway from a U.S. port when the voyage is to be of 48 hours or greater duration?

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require that electric and electro-hydraulic steering gear motors shall be __________.

Response 2: provided with a running motor over current protection device

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) make certain requirements regarding over current protection. Steering gear feeder circuits shall be protected only by __________.

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require that an indicating light located at the propulsion control station be illuminated if there is an overload that would cause overheating of the __________.

Question: Coast Guard Regulations (46 CFR) require an audible and visible alarm to be actuated in the pilothouse when the actual position of the rudder differs from the position ordered by the follow-up control system by 5 or more for more than __________.
Response 1: 30 seconds for ordered rudder position changes of 70
Response 2: 16 seconds for ordered rudder position changes of 5

Question: According to 46 CFR Part 113 what would be the maximum time delay period allowed for a ships steering system to reach a 15 degree right rudder helm order from midships before an alarm condition will be indicated?

You are conducting an operational test of your main steering gear system. The main steering gear must be capable of moving the rudder from 35 degrees on either side to 35 degrees on the other with the vessel at its deepest loadline draft and running at maximum ahead service speed and from 35 degrees on either side to 30 degrees on the other in what minimum time frame?

Prior to entering the navigable waters of the United States after an international voyage your vessel must conduct drills according to 33 CFR regulations for ports and waterways safety that test steering system functionality and log that in the vessel logbook unless the drill is conducted and logged on a regular basis at least once every three months. Within how many hours of arrival must these drills be performed?

Prior to entering the navigable waters of the United States after an international voyage your vessel must conduct drills according to 33 CFR regulations for ports and waterways safety that test steering system functionality and log that in the vessel logbook unless the drill is conducted and logged on a regular basis at least once every three months. Which of the following functions must be tested for?
Response 1: Operation of the main steering gear from within the steering gear compartment utilizing the means of communication between the navigating bridge and the steering gear compartment.
Response 2: Operation of the main steering gear from each bridge wing if fitted utilizing the normal means of communication on the bridge wings.
Response 3: Operation of the auxiliary steering gear from the main navigating bridge utilizing the normal means of communication in the wheelhouse.

Question: Which of the following clearance readings should be taken and recorded in dry-dock?
Response 1: The clearances between the propeller blade tips and the hull.
Response 2: The clearances between the propeller hub and the fair water cone.
Response 4: The clearances between the stern tube packing gland and the retaining ring.

Question: Vessel propellers are classified as being right hand or left hand. A right hand propeller turns clockwise when viewed from __________.
When the propeller blades are integral with the hub the propeller is called a __________.
The conical steel or composition cone installed on a propeller known as a fairwater cone provides which of the following benefits?
The purpose of the propeller fairwater cone is to __________.
Response 1: lock the propeller nut in position

Question: The conical steel or composition cone installed on a propeller known as a fairwater cone provides which of the following benefits?
The propeller blade pitch angle change is caused by axial movement of what component in the hub body assembly? See illustration GS-0172.
The hub purge valve serves to relieve pressure in the forward chamber of the servomotor cylinder in a CPP system when what situation occurs? See illustration GS-0172.
Response 1: The propeller is stroked beyond its full ahead pitch limits.
Response 2: The propeller is stroked beyond its full astern limits.
Response 4: During periods of high-pressure oil surge.

Question: The function of the head tank on a CPP system is to _________.
Response 1: provide extra oil for maintaining the normal sump level
Response 2: prevent seawater from entering the hydraulic system when it is secured
Response 3: provide static head pressure for maintaining proper control oil pressure
Response 4: provide dynamic head pressure for maintaining proper high-pressure oil pressure

Question: The direction in which the control oil servo valve opens and directs control oil to the oil distribution (OD) box piston in a CPP system is determined by the command _________. See illustration GS-0170.
If your ship is experiencing slow erratic or no pitch response to normal CPP system commands you would suspect a fault in the _________. See illustration GS-0170.
If water were a semisolid the linear distance a propeller would advance in one revolution is the __________.
Excessive propeller vibration may occur as a result of __________.
Response 2: high water pressure under the hull

Question: A piece missing from one blade of a four-bladed propeller could result in __________.
Any unusual or new vibration in the hull or propeller shafting can be an indication of __________.
Unusual hull or propeller shaft vibrations can be caused by __________.
Response 1: excessive engine speed in shallow water
Response 3: slight overheating of the line shaft spring bearings
Response 4: high engine speed in deep water

Question: When a vessel is in dry-dock the vessel's engineers should __________.
Response 1: examine the condition of the propeller
Response 2: chip and paint all hull protection zincs
Response 3: install new docking plugs in all cofferdams
Response 4: inspect the hull for hogging or sagging

Question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning requirements for propellers?
Response 1: A propeller may not be changed with one of a different pitch unless stress evaluations are supplied and permission is granted by a Marine Surveyor.
Response 2: When steel propellers are used zinc anodes are to be fitted on the aftermost strut bearing housing and on the forward most section of the rudder assembly.
Response 3: The exposed steel of the shaft is to be protected from the action of the water by filling all spaces between the cap hub and shaft with a suitable material.
Response 4: Ultrasonic examinations of the propeller may be performed in lieu of required dry-docking periods provided certified copies are distributed to the proper regulatory bodies.

Question: Which of the following propulsor types represents the proper terminology for a screw propeller of the conventional design?
Which of the following propulsor types would be used with unidirectional propulsion shafting rotation?
What type of propeller consists of a flat disc set flush with the under surface of the vessel's hull with a number of vertical rudder like blades projecting from it?

If a main propulsion shafting arrangement is such that no strut or strut bearing is required what is an alternative name given to the propeller shaft which is the section of shafting that the propeller is attached to?
What statement is true with respect to the back of a propeller blade?
Response 1: The back of the propeller blade is the side of the blade which faces upstream during ahead motion and is the side of the blade known as the pressure side.
Response 2: The back of the propeller blade is the side of the blade which faces downstream during ahead motion and is the side of the blade known as the pressure side.
Response 3: The back of the propeller blade is the side of the blade which faces downstream during ahead motion and is the side of the blade known as the suction side.
Response 4: The back of the propeller blade is the side of the blade which faces upstream during ahead motion and is the side of the blade known as the suction side.

Question: What is meant by the term "left-handed" propeller?
Response 1: A "left-handed" propeller is a propeller located on the starboard side and which can rotate in either direction.
Response 2: A "left-handed" propeller is a propeller located on the port side and which can rotate in either direction.
Response 3: A "left-handed" propeller is a propeller which rotates in the counter-clockwise direction when viewed from ahead.
Response 4: A "left-handed" propeller is a propeller which rotates in the counter-clockwise direction when viewed from astern.

Question: What is meant by the term "right-handed" propeller?
Response 1: A "right-handed" propeller is a propeller located on the port side and which can rotate in either direction.
Response 2: A "right-handed" propeller is a propeller which rotates in the clockwise direction when viewed from astern.
Response 3: A "right-handed" propeller is a propeller located on the starboard side and which can rotate in either direction.
Response 4: A "right-handed" propeller is a propeller which rotates in the clockwise direction when viewed from ahead.

Question: During the Special Survey the propeller is removed and shaft pulled into the vessel. Which of the following tests must be performed on the propeller shaft prior to refitting?
Response 1: The tapered section must be checked for cracks using non destructive testing.
Response 2: The entire shaft must be checked for cracks using non destructive testing.
Response 3: The propeller flange must be checked for cracks using non destructive testing.
Response 4: The shaft weight must be checked prior to refitting.

Question: Compared to a constant pitch propeller a controllable pitch propeller __________.
Response 1: more efficiently uses available engine power
Response 2: operates at a lower efficiency at a fixed speed
Response 3: produces the same torque at lower engine power
Response 4: develops its rated power at a lower speed

Question: The control system for a controllable pitch propeller can be programmed __________.
Response 3: both I and II are correct
Response 4: neither I or II are correct

Question: Which of the following alarms and instrumentation is not required for a vessel incorporating a controllable pitch propeller in its main propulsion system?
Which of the statements listed accurately applies to controllable pitch propeller systems?
Response 1: A pitch indicator is to be fitted on the navigation bridge for vessels 400 gross tons and above.
Response 2: Independent remote control of pitch is to be provided at or near the oil distribution box. Tests of its operation are to be performed in the presence of the Surveyor.
Response 3: After installation in the vessel the complete piping system is to be subjected to a hydrostatic test equal to 1.25 times the design pressure.
Response 4: The arrangement of piping is to be such that a single failure in one part of the piping or pump unit will not impair the integrity of the remaining parts of the system.

Question: A controllable pitch propeller on a diesel driven vessel eliminates the need for __________.
Concerning the operating mechanism of a controllable-pitch propeller what statement is true?
Response 1: If the hydraulic actuator is outboard a mechanical pull-push rod is located within the propeller shaft. If the hydraulic actuator is inboard hydraulic oil pipes are located within the propeller shaft.
Response 2: If the hydraulic actuator is inboard or outboard the blade rotating mechanism is actuated by a mechanical pull-push rod located within the propeller shaft.
Response 3: If the hydraulic actuator is inboard or outboard hydraulic oil pipes are located within the propeller shaft in either case.
Response 4: If the hydraulic actuator is inboard a mechanical pull-push rod is located within the propeller shaft. If the hydraulic actuator is outboard hydraulic oil pipes are located within the propeller shaft.

Question: Rotation of the Controllable Pitch Propeller (CPP) blades is achieved through axial movement of what component in the hub body assembly?
Which of the following propulsor types represents the proper terminology for a Kort nozzle?
Which of the following propulsor types represents the proper terminology for a Voith-Schneider drive?
When an electricity generating plant features shaft-driven generators what type of propulsor is generally used for main propulsion?
Which of the following propulsor types represents the proper terminology for a Z-drive?
Which of the following propulsor types represents the proper terminology for electric propulsion where the drive motors are outside the ship's hull?
Which of the following propulsor types does not require the use of a separate rudder for steerage?
Concerning transverse fixed tunnel thrusters what statement is true?
Response 1: Transverse fixed tunnel thrusters are oriented fore-to-aft usually located at the stern of a vessel and used for docking undocking and low-speed maneuvering.
Response 2: Transverse fixed tunnel thrusters are oriented athwartships usually located at the bow of a vessel and used to supplement main propulsion for higher sustained speeds.
Response 3: Transverse fixed tunnel thrusters are oriented athwartships usually located at the bow of a vessel and used for docking undocking and low-speed maneuvering.
Response 4: Transverse fixed tunnel thrusters are oriented fore-to-aft usually located at the stern of a vessel and used to supplement main propulsion for higher sustained speeds.

Question: Concerning steerable internal duct thrusters what statement is true?
Response 1: The thrust direction of the steerable internal duct thruster is determined by the direction of rotation of the pump.
Response 2: The thrust direction of the steerable internal duct thruster is determined by reversing the pitch angle of the pump impeller.
Response 3: The thrust direction of the steerable internal duct thruster is determined by the orientation of the pump inlet guide vanes.
Response 4: The thrust direction of the steerable internal duct thruster is determined by the orientation of the water discharge vectoring ring.

Question: With respect to the vectoring ring of a steerable internal duct thruster what statement represents the operating principle of the vectoring ring?
Response 1: The vectoring ring is used to control the orientation of the inlet guide vanes to the pump inlet.
Response 2: The vectoring ring is used to control the orientation of the deflector vanes of the pump discharge.
Response 3: The vectoring ring is used to control the speed and direction of rotation of the pump.
Response 4: The vectoring ring is used to control the orientation of the vanes on the pump impeller.

Question: What statement represents the fundamental difference between an azimuthing thruster and a podded propulsor?
Response 1: With an azimuthing thruster the prime mover is located inside the hull and with a podded propulsor the prime mover is located outside the hull.
Response 2: With an azimuthing thruster the prime mover is located outside the hull and with a podded propulsor the prime mover is located inside the hull.
Response 3: With an azimuthing thruster the thruster is not steerable and with a podded propulsor the propulsor is steerable.
Response 4: With an azimuthing thruster the thruster is steerable and with a podded propulsor the propulsor is not steerable.

Question: With respect to a "pusher" type azimuthing thruster what statement is true?
Response 1: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the azimuthing thruster's propeller is directly abaft of the gear unit but the gear unit is in the wake of the azimuthing thruster's propeller.
Response 2: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the gear unit is directly abaft of and in the wake of the azimuthing thruster's propeller.
Response 3: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the gear unit is directly abaft of the azimuthing thruster's propeller but the azimuthing thruster's propeller is in the wake of the gear unit.
Response 4: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the azimuthing thruster's propeller is directly abaft of and in the wake of the gear unit.

Question: With respect to a "tractor" type azimuthing thruster what statement is true?
Response 1: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the gear unit is directly abaft of and in the wake of the azimuthing thruster's propeller.
Response 2: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the azimuthing thruster's propeller is directly abaft of and in the wake of the gear unit.
Response 3: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the gear unit is directly abaft of the azimuthing thruster's propeller but the azimuthing thruster's propeller is in the wake of the gear unit.
Response 4: With an azimuthing angle of 0 the azimuthing thruster's propeller is directly abaft of the gear unit but the gear unit is in the wake of the azimuthing thruster's propeller.

Question: By what means is electric current conveyed to the electric drive motor of a podded propulsor?
Response 1: Current is conveyed from the source to a set of stationary brushes then through a single rotating slip ring and then on to the motor windings.
Response 2: Current is conveyed from the source to a set of stationary slip rings then through a set of rotating brushes and then on to the motor windings.
Response 3: Current is conveyed from the source to a set of stationary brushes then through a set of rotating slip rings and then on to the motor windings.
Response 4: Current is conveyed from the source to the stator of a synchronous transmitter and by synchro action to the rotor of a synchronous receiver.

Question: What type of propulsor is typically used in electric motor driven transverse tunnel bow thrusters to limit the starting current of the single speed drive motor?
What is the primary advantage of transverse bow and stern tunnel thrusters when installed on ships?
Response 1: They provide increased overall propulsive reverse thrust.
Response 2: They provide increased maneuverability at low ship speeds.
Response 3: They provide increased overall propulsive forward thrust.
Response 4: They provide increased maneuverability at high ship speeds.

Question: Which set of operating conditions would be most problematic in terms of the deterioration of the insulation resistance of the drive motor of an electric motor driven transverse tunnel bow thruster?
Response 1: Frequently used thrusters where the bow thruster machinery compartment is particularly cold.
Response 2: Frequently used thrusters where the bow thruster machinery compartment is particularly warm.
Response 3: Infrequently used thrusters where the bow thruster machinery compartment is particularly cold.
Response 4: Infrequently used thrusters where the bow thruster machinery compartment is particularly warm.

Question: Of the following propulsion modes which one would operate with a geared-drive featuring a single reduction?
The control of exhaust temperature on a solid waste/sludge incinerator is critical. How this temperature is normally controlled?
Response 1: The exhaust temperature is controlled by regulating by the admission of combustion air into the combustion chamber.
Response 2: The exhaust temperature is controlled by regulating the admission of auxiliary fuel to the burner.
Response 3: The exhaust temperature is controlled by regulating the exhaust gas flow.
Response 4: The exhaust temperature is controlled by regulating the admission of relatively cool ambient air into the exhaust stream.

Question: How is solid trash and garbage generally admitted to a solid-waste incinerator on most ships?
Response 1: The trash is admitted via a ram feed system.
Response 2: The trash is admitted via screw feed system.
Response 3: The trash is admitted manually via a loading door.
Response 4: The trash is admitted via a chute.

Question: In burning oily-waste sludge in a solid-waste/sludge incinerator what statement is true?
Response 1: Cooling of the sludge is required to obtain the correct viscosity and auxiliary fuel is required if the water content of the sludge is too low to support combustion on sludge alone.
Response 2: Heating of the sludge is required to obtain the correct viscosity and auxiliary fuel is required if the water content of the sludge is too high to support combustion on sludge alone.
Response 3: Cooling of the sludge is required to obtain the correct viscosity and auxiliary fuel is required if the water content of the sludge is too high to support combustion on sludge alone.
Response 4: Heating of the sludge is required to obtain the correct viscosity and auxiliary fuel is required if the water content of the sludge is too low to support combustion on sludge alone.

Question: In accordance with the international MARPOL Annex VI regulations which of the listed substances is prohibited from being burned in a shipboard incinerator?
In accordance with the international MARPOL AnnexVI regulations what is the minimum allowable flue gas outlet temperature for a continuous-fed shipboard incinerator while in operation?
In accordance with the international MARPOL Annex VI regulations what is a permissible alternative to burning oil residue sludge in an appropriate incinerator?
Response 1: The oil sludge residue may be burned in a boiler OR engine and it AND may be burned only in unrestricted waters (other than in port in harbors or estuaries).
Response 2: The oil sludge residue may be burned in a boiler OR engine AND it may be burned without restriction in terms of vessel location.
Response 3: The oil sludge residue may be burned in a boiler only AND may be burned only in unrestricted waters (other than in port in harbors or estuaries).
Response 4: The oil sludge residue may be burned in a boiler only AND may be burned without restriction in terms of vessel location.

Question: In the hydraulic anchor windlass system illustrated if the power to the electric motor is on but the wildcat turns slowly or not at all even without a load being applied and nearly normal pressure is indicated on the high side of the system the probable cause is that the __________. Response 3: manual transfer valve is in the wrong position for the main pump being operated

Question: In the hydraulic anchor windlass system illustrated the main pressure relief valve opens as the load increases its strain on the system. The probable cause is the __________. See illustration GS-0160.

Response 3: Sparking at the winch motor brushes.

Question: When the control handle is in the 'off' position what is the status of the solenoid actuated brake of an electric winch?
Response 1: de-energized and the brake is released

Response 4: automatically govern the hoisting speed of the load

Question: As part of a routine maintenance program for deck machinery motor controllers what should be done?

Response 2: remove covers exposed to the weather and drain water each week

Question: If deck machinery is expected to be idle for an extended period of time what should be done?

Response 1: automatic operation of the winch is desired

Question: Winch gears must be maintained in proper alignment to prevent ______.
As it pertains to the automatic hydraulic brake of a horizontal electro-hydraulic anchor windlass what statement is true?
Response 1: The brake is hydraulically set and spring released and the brake automatically sets when the pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 2: The brake is spring set and hydraulically released and the brake automatically sets when the pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 3: The brake is spring set and hydraulically released and the brake automatically releases when the pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 4: The brake is hydraulically set and spring released and the brake automatically releases when the pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.

Question: As it pertains to the automatic electric brake of a horizontal electro-mechanical anchor windlass what statement is true?
Response 1: The brake is electrically set and spring released and the brake automatically releases when power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 2: The brake is spring set and electrically released and the brake automatically sets when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 3: The brake is spring set and electrically released and the brake automatically releases when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 4: The brake is electrically set and spring released and the brake automatically sets when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.

Question: A horizontal electro-mechanical anchor windlass is equipped with two warping heads two wildcats two manual brake hand wheels two clutch control levers and a multipoint lever-operated pedestal-mounted controller. What statement is true as it pertains to the operation of the windlass clutch control levers?
Response 1: The clutch control levers are used to engage and disengage the wildcats only. They have no control over the warping heads.
Response 2: The clutch control levers are used to engage and disengage the warping heads only. They have no control over the wildcats.
Response 3: The clutch control levers are used to engage and disengage both the warping heads and the wildcats.
Response 4: The clutch control levers are used to either engage and disengage the warping heads or the wildcats depending upon the windlass design.

Question: A horizontal electro-mechanical anchor windlass is equipped with two warping heads two wildcats two manual brake hand wheels two clutch control levers and a multipoint lever-operated pedestal-mounted controller. What statement is true as it pertains to the operation of the pedestal-mounted controller?
Response 1: The pedestal-mounted controller allows the wildcats to rotate in either direction of rotation but the warping heads in only one direction of rotation at discrete speeds from zero to maximum.
Response 2: The pedestal-mounted controller allows both the warping heads and the wildcats to rotate in either direction of rotation at discrete speeds from zero to maximum.
Response 3: The pedestal-mounted controller allows both the warping heads and the wildcats to rotate in only one direction of rotation at discrete speeds from zero to maximum.
Response 4: The pedestal-mounted controller allows the warping heads to rotate in either direction of rotation but the wildcats in only one direction of rotation at discrete speeds from zero to maximum.

Question: A horizontal electro-mechanical anchor windlass is equipped with two warping heads two wildcats two manual brake hand wheels two clutch control levers and a multipoint lever-operated pedestal- mounted controller. What statement is true as it pertains to the operation of the manual brake hand wheels?
Response 1: The manual brake hand wheels control band brakes that are associated with both the wildcats and the warping heads.
Response 2: The manual brake hand wheels control band brakes that are associated with the warping heads only.
Response 3: The manual brake hand wheels control band brakes that are associated with the wildcats only.
Response 4: The manual brake hand wheels control band brakes that are associated with either the wildcats or the warping heads depending upon the windlass design.

Question: A horizontal electro-mechanical anchor windlass is equipped with two warping heads two wildcats two manual brake hand wheels two clutch control levers and a multipoint lever-operated pedestal- mounted controller. What statement is true as it pertains to the operation of the warping heads and wildcats?
Response 1: The warping heads can be rotated in either direction of rotation without rotating the wildcats by disengaging the wildcat clutches. As long as electric power is applied to the electric drive motor the wildcats will rotate.
Response 2: The wildcats can be rotated in either direction of rotation without rotating the warping heads by disengaging the warping head clutches. As long as electric power is applied to the electric drive motor the wildcats will rotate.
Response 3: The warping heads can be rotated in either direction of rotation without rotating the wildcats by disengaging the wildcat clutches. As long as electric power is applied to the electric drive motor the warping heads will rotate.
Response 4: The wildcats can be rotated in either direction of rotation without rotating the warping heads by disengaging the warping head clutches. As long as electric power is applied to the electric drive motor the warping heads will rotate.

Question: In attempting to start the hydraulic pump drive motor of a horizontal electro-hydraulic anchor windlass what condition would prevent the electric motor from starting?
Response 1: Failure to start could be the result of an electrical interlock associated with the hydraulic pump stroke control being in other than the neutral position.
Response 2: Failure to start could be the result of an electrical interlock associated with the wildcat clutches being disengaged.
Response 3: Failure to start could be the result of an electrical interlock associated with hand wheel operated wildcat band brakes being set.
Response 4: Failure to start could be the result of an electrical interlock associated with the hydraulic pump stroke control being in the neutral position.

Question: As it pertains to raising and lowering an anchor with a horizontal electro-hydraulic or electro-mechanical anchor windlass what statement is true?
Response 1: The anchor can be either raised or lowered under power with the windlass by disengaging the wildcat clutch. The anchor can be lowered by gravity by controlling the anchor chain payout with the wildcat manual brake with the wildcat clutch engaged.
Response 2: The anchor can only be raised (and not lowered) under power with the windlass by disengaging the wildcat clutch. The anchor can be lowered by gravity by controlling the anchor chain payout with the wildcat manual brake with the wildcat clutch engaged.
Response 3: The anchor can only be raised (and not lowered) under power with the windlass by engaging the wildcat clutch. The anchor can be lowered by gravity by controlling the anchor chain payout with the wildcat manual brake with the wildcat clutch disengaged.
Response 4: The anchor can be either raised or lowered under power with the windlass by engaging the wildcat clutch. The anchor can be lowered by gravity by controlling the anchor chain payout with the wildcat manual brake with the wildcat clutch disengaged.

Question: As it pertains to the automatic electric brake of a capstan what statement is true?
Response 1: The brake is electrically set and spring released and the brake automatically releases when power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 2: The brake is spring set and electrically released and the brake automatically releases when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 3: The brake is spring set and electrically released and the brake automatically sets when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.
Response 4: The brake is electrically set and spring released and the brake automatically sets when electric power is removed from the electric drive motor.

Question: Which capstan drive arrangement requires a flexible coupling between the reduction gear output shaft and the capstan head input shaft?
Response 1: The drive arrangement where the drive motor electric brake gear reducer and capstan head are all located on the weather deck.
Response 2: The drive arrangement where the drive motor electric brake gear reducer are hung from the underside of the weather deck and only the capstan head is located on the weather deck.
Response 3: The drive arrangement where the drive motor electric brake gear reducer are mounted on the deck below the weather deck and only the capstan head is located on the weather deck.
Response 4: A flexible coupling is required on all three drive arrangements listed above.

Question: Concerning a conventional mooring winch what statement is true?
Response 1: A high capacity brake is required to hold a load approaching the breaking strength of the mooring line but it is required to slip at a lower tension to avoid mooring line breakage.
Response 2: A high capacity brake is required to hold a load equal to the breaking strength of the mooring line. For reasons of safety no slippage of the brake is permitted.
Response 3: A high capacity brake is required to hold a load exceeding the breaking strength of the mooring line. For reasons of safety no slippage of the brake is permitted.
Response 4: A low capacity brake is required to hold a load far below the breaking strength of the mooring line but it is required to slip at a lower tension to avoid mooring line breakage.

Question: As it pertains to a "constant-tension" mooring winch what statement is true?
Response 1: A constant-tension mooring winch is set to automatically render but not recover mooring line using the prime mover when the mooring line tension varies above a certain preset tension.
Response 2: A constant-tension mooring winch is set to automatically recover but not render mooring line using the prime mover when the mooring line tension varies below a certain preset tension.
Response 3: A constant-tension mooring winch is set to automatically render but not recover mooring line using the brake when the mooring line tension varies above certain preset tension.
Response 4: A constant-tension mooring winch is set to automatically render and recover mooring line using the prime mover when the mooring line tension varies outside of narrow preset adjustable tension limits.

Question: As it pertains to the automatic hoist winch brake of an electro-hydraulic cargo-handling pedestal-type deck crane what statement is true?
Response 1: The brake is hydraulically set and spring released and the brake automatically releases when the hoist pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 2: The brake is spring set and hydraulically released and the brake automatically sets when the hoist pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 3: The brake is hydraulically set and spring released and the brake automatically sets when the hoist pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.
Response 4: The brake is spring set and hydraulically released and the brake automatically releases when the hoist pump is brought to zero stroke or there is a loss of servo power hydraulic pressure.

Question: As it pertains to the luffing motion limits associated with an electro-hydraulic cargo-handling pedestal-type deck crane what statement is true?
Response 1: When the hoist block is raised to a maximum permissible height with respect to the boom the luffing pump shall be placed on stroke and the luffing winch brake released.
Response 2: When the hoist block is raised to a maximum permissible height with respect to the boom the luffing pump shall be stroked to zero and the luffing winch brake set.
Response 3: When the boom is raised to a maximum permissible height or lowered to a minimum permissible height the luffing pump shall be stroked to zero and the luffing winch brake set.
Response 4: When the boom is raised to a maximum permissible height or lowered to a minimum permissible height the luffing pump shall be placed on stroke and the luffing winch brake released.

Question: As it pertains to the hoist motion limits associated with an electro-hydraulic cargo-handling pedestal-type deck crane what statement is true?
Response 1: When the boom is raised to a maximum permissible height or lowered to a minimum permissible height the hoist pump shall be placed on stroke and the hoist winch brake released.
Response 2: When the hoist cable is payed out to a nearly empty drum condition or when the hoist block is raised to a maximum permissible height relative to the boom the hoist pump shall be placed on stroke and the hoist winch brake released.
Response 3: When the hoist cable is payed out to a nearly empty drum condition or when the hoist block is raised to a maximum permissible height relative to the boom the hoist pump shall be stroked to zero and the hoist winch brake set.
Response 4: When the boom is raised to a maximum permissible height or lowered to a minimum permissible height the hoist pump shall be stroked to zero and the hoist winch brake set.

Question: For an electro- hydraulic cargo-handling pedestal-type deck crane what event would result in an immediate stop to all crane motions including slewing hoisting and luffing?
Response 1: All motions are stopped by the action of the boom maximum outreach and minimum outreach limit switches.
Response 2: All motions are stopped by the action of the slewing platform limit switches.
Response 3: All motions are stopped by the loss of electric power to the crane.
Response 4: All motions are stopped by the action of the safe working load cutout switch or the slack wire limit switch.

Question: What statement is true concerning the door interlock devices associated with a winding drum or traction drive passenger elevator onboard ship?
Response 1: Door interlocks are used to prevent elevator operation if the doors are still open and only allow elevator operation if the doors are proved closed.
Response 2: Door interlocks are used to prevent elevator operation if the doors are still closed and only allow elevator operation if the doors are proved open.
Response 3: Door interlocks are used to prevent elevator operation in a shipboard emergency when elevators are not to be used.
Response 4: Door interlocks are used to over-ride elevator emergency status in a shipboard emergency when elevators are required to be used.

Question: What statement is true concerning the platform interlock devices associated with a winding drum or traction drive cargo elevator onboard ship?
Response 1: Platform interlocks are used to over-ride elevator emergency status in a shipboard emergency when elevators are required to be used.
Response 2: Platform interlocks are used to prevent elevator operation in a shipboard emergency when elevators are not to be used.
Response 3: Platform interlocks are used to prevent door operation if the platform is at other than a deck level and only allow door operation when the platform is proved at a deck level.
Response 4: Platform interlocks are used to prevent door operation if the platform is proved at a deck level and only allow door operation when the platform is at a position other than a deck level.

Question: If a spring-set electric solenoid-released brake on a winch fails to hold a load properly when the solenoid is de-energized what must be done?
Response 1: The solenoid coil must be replaced as it is faulty.
Response 2: The brakes linings must be checked for wear and adjusted or replaced accordingly.
Response 3: The spring must be replaced as it has lost its compression force.
Response 4: The brake drum must be checked for wear and replaced as needed.

Which bearing will carry the load on two small points diametrically opposite to each other?

Response 3: They have a greater tolerance for high speed applications.

Question: Machinery with ball bearings designed to be filled with grease should have the relief plug temporarily removed while grease is being added. This plug should remain out until the machinery has been operated and sufficiently warmed up to ensure that __________.

Response 3: all air pockets are vented from the grease
Response 4: all excess grease is expelled from the housing

Question: Machinery with ball bearings designed to be filled with grease should have the relief plug temporarily removed while grease is being added. This plug should remain out until the machinery has been operated and sufficiently warmed up to ensure that __________.
Response 1: a path for expansion is provided for the grease

Response 3: contaminated grease is flushed from the bearing housing

Question: The best method of fixing a winch motor bearing of the sealed type that is running hot is to __________.

Response 4: apply a light oil to the bearing housing

Question: When removing roller bearings from a shaft the force of the puller should be applied to the bearing __________.

Response 2: apply even pressure to the outer race

Question: Which of the following statements concerning antifriction bearings installed on pumps is true?

Response 2: The outer race should be free to turn its housing.
Response 3: Alignment is not a critical factor in their installation.
Response 4: They are usually pressed on to their shafts.

Question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning antifriction bearings installed on pumps?
Response 1: The inner race should be free to turn on the shaft.
Response 2: The outer race should be free to turn in its housing.
Response 3: Alignment is not a critical factor in their installation.
Response 4: They are usually pressed onto their shafts.

Question: Antifriction bearings can be removed undamaged from a shaft by using an arbor press or wheel puller with a________.

Response 3: maintaining a continuous fluid level over half of the outer race
Response 4: installing oil rings on the ball bearings

Question: A dented race in an antifriction bearing could be caused by __________.

Question: If a ball bearing installed on a pump is completely packed full of grease this can result in __________.

Response 1: moisture emulsification of the bearing grease

Question: If a ball bearing for a centrifugal pump is completely packed with grease __________.

Question: Ball bearings may become overheated if they are __________.

Response 1: the bearings will require immediate flushing
Response 2: dirt will accumulate inside the bearings
Response 3: excess lubrication will result in slippage

Question: The main bearings of a reciprocating air compressor are tapered roller bearings. When mounted these bearings are given a 'cold' end clearance to __________.
Response 2: allow for longitudinal expansion of the crankshaft as the unit warms up
Response 3: prevent longitudinal thrust in the crankshaft
Response 4: reduce torsional vibration in the crankshaft

Question: The size of ball and roller bearings can be identified by the ______.
An example of an anti-friction bearing is a ______.

Response 1: apply even pressure to the outer race
Response 2: apply pressure evenly to both the inner and outer races

Response 4: tap the outer race with a mallet

Question: A ball bearing will overheat if ______.

Question: Which of the following bearing types would be an example of a rolling-element bearing which substitutes fluid friction for rolling contact friction?

Response 3: vibration while the bearing is not in operation

Question: A roller bearing should normally be filled to what fraction of its space cavity?

A ball or roller bearing has an interference fit with the housing in which it is being installed with a hydraulic or arbor press. Upon what surface should the sleeve of the press be applied?

Response 1: Heating the bearing in an oil-bath bearing heater.

Question: Rolling element bearings may experience fatigue failure after a length of service. What is the first evidence of the beginnings of fatigue failure?
Response 1: Discoloration of the races or rolling elements.

Response 3: The presence of small cracks in the rolling elements.

Question: As shown in the illustration what would be the recommended grease replenishment interval for a 5 1/2 inch radial ball bearing operating under normal load at approximately 1000 rpm? See illustration GS-0176.

Question: Dirt should not be allowed to contaminate a grease lubricant because the __________.
Response 2: dirt will cause corrosion of bearing
Response 4: dirt is very abrasive when mixed with grease

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the term 'base' in reference to the classification of lubricating grease?
Response 1: Texture of the grease under load.

Response 3: Type of soap used in its production.

Question: Which of the listed types of soap grease offers the maximum chemical stability and resistance to separation at temperatures between 250F (121.1C) and 300F (148.8C)?
Greases are generally produced by __________.
Response 1: reducing the temperature of an oil below its cloud point to create the gelatinous texture

Response 3: reducing tallow 50F below its pour point then mixing a base metal such as barium into solution
Response 4: saponifying an aluminum base to which tallow and oil are mixed into solution under a controlled temperature

Question: A grease lubricated ball bearing or roller bearing will run cooler if the grease __________.

Response 3: is thinned with a suitable lubricating oil
Response 4: is heated prior to packing the bearing

Question: Which indicator is used to determine the hardness of a grease?
When referring to greases penetration number is __________.
Response 1: how many seconds was required for a cone to penetrate the sample
Response 2: the temperature at which a cone would begin to penetrate the sample
Response 3: the temperature at which the grease would become sufficiently fluid to fill the voids of a standard ball bearing
Response 4: the depth to which a cone would penetrate a sample of grease in 5 seconds

Question: A grease drop point is __________.
Response 1: how far a standard metal cone will penetrate into the sample in five seconds when dropped
Response 2: how uniform and thick the spread of an ounce of grease is when dropped from a height of five feet
Response 3: the temperature that a sample of grease begins to liquefy
Response 4: the length of time a 50 gram sphere will be held in place from the underside of a surface coated with 25 millimeters of the grease sample

Question: A drop test is carried out on a sample of grease by __________.
Response 1: allowing a suspended cone to drop into a sample of grease for five seconds and determining the depth of penetration
Response 2: dropping a one ounce grease sample from one meter and observing the resulting spread pattern uniformity of thickness and consistency of texture
Response 3: allowing a sample of grease to drop into a cup at ambient temperature and determining the time necessary for this to occur
Response 4: determining the temperature at which a grease sample liquefies when heated and drops from a cup through a bottom orifice

Question: An organic solid lubricant such as graphite is suitable as an oil additive when used in __________.

Response 2: antifriction bearings on general service pumps

Response 3: remove the grease fitting and leave open to allow excess grease to escape
Response 4: save the used grease for chemical analysis

Question: In a compression type automatic grease cup the lubricant is forced into the bearing by __________.

Response 1: 10-25% of the original void space in the bearing
Response 2: 25-50% of the original void space in the bearing
Response 3: 50-75% of the original void space in the bearing
Response 4: 75-95% of the original void space in the bearing

Question: What percent of a roller bearing should normally be filled with grease?

Response 2: high temperatures to develop as result of churning

Question: A ball bearing will overheat if __________.
Response 2: filled with grease to 65% of the total open spaces within the bearing
Response 3: in use for a long time

Question: What type of grease is the most commonly used aboard ship?
Packing extremely soft grease into a roller bearing will cause ______.
Response 2: high temperatures to develop as result of churning

Question: A grease gun is generally used to lubricate a ______.
Greases used for most marine applications would have what National Lubricating Grease Institute (NLGI) grade?
What is the primary indication of a grease lubricated bearing that is over-lubricated in terms of the quantity of grease in the housing?
Response 1: The bearing temperature would tend to produce unusual vibrations.
Response 2: The bearing temperature would tend to run cooler than normal for the load.
Response 3: The bearing would tend to produce a noticeable change in sound.
